choices.text: Selenocysteine, incorporated cotranslationally via the UGA codon
Hydroxylysine, formed by hydroxylation of lysine residues post-translation
Selenocysteine, incorporated cotranslationally via the UAA codon
Selenocysteine incorporated post-translationally via the UAG codon

questions.text: An amino acid is incorporated into enzyme of glutathione peroxidase. This amino acid is encoded by a codon that typically signals translation termination but, under specific conditions, is repurposed to allow incorporation during the elongation phase of protein synthesis. The process requires a specialized insertion sequence in the mRNA. Which of the following best describes this amino acid and how it is incorporated?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Selenocysteine, incorporated cotranslationally via the UGA codon

 

  • Selenocysteine is known as the 21st amino acid and is unique in that it is incorporated cotranslationally, not post-translationally. 
  • It is encoded by the UGA stop codon, which is redefined in the presence of a SECIS (Selenocysteine Insertion Sequence) element in the mRNA. 
  • A specialized tRNA (Sec-tRNA) and elongation factors are involved in its insertion.
  •  It is found in key antioxidant enzymes such as glutathione peroxidase and thioredoxin reductase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hydroxylysine, formed by hydroxylation of lysine residues post-translation: Hydroxylysine is generated by post-translational modification, not by recoding a stop codon, and is important in collagen cross-linking, not glutathione peroxidase.

 

Option C. Selenocysteine, incorporated cotranslationally via the UAA codon: This is incorrect because selenocysteine uses UGA, not UAA, which is a different stop codon.

 

Option D. Selenocysteine incorporated post-translationally via the UAG codon: This is incorrect because selenocysteine is cotranslationally incorporated during elongation, not post-translationally, and via UGA, not UAG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Selenocysteine is incorporated cotranslationally into proteins via the UGA codon and a SECIS element, distinguishing it from amino acids that arise through post-translational modifications.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve injuries is the instrument shown below is used for?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial nerve

 

  • The radial nerve is responsible for extension of the wrist, fingers, and thumb, and sensation over the back of the hand and parts of the forearm.
  • Often injured in the mid-shaft of the humerus (e.g., in humeral shaft fractures) or at the elbow/forearm.
  • "Wrist drop" (inability to extend the wrist), "finger drop" (inability to extend the fingers), weakness of thumb extension and abduction, and sensory loss in the dorsum of the hand.
  • A dynamic wrist extension splint or cock-up splint is commonly used to support the wrist in extension in cases of radial nerve palsy to prevent contractures and aid function.
  •  Sensory testing (light touch, two-point discrimination), motor strength testing against resistance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median Nerve:

 

  • The median nerve is responsible for pronation of the forearm, flexion of the wrist and fingers (thumb, index, middle, and half of the ring finger), and sensation over the palmar aspect of the thumb, index, middle, and half of the ring finger. It's also crucial for thumb opposition.
  • Frequently compressed at the wrist (carpal tunnel syndrome), or injured in the forearm or elbow (e.g., supracondylar humeral fractures).
  • "Hand of benediction" (inability to flex the index and middle fingers, especially when attempting a fist), loss of forearm pronation, thenar muscle atrophy.
  • Low Median Nerve Injury (e.g., Carpal Tunnel Syndrome): Weakness/atrophy of the thenar muscles ("ape hand" deformity - loss of thumb opposition and abduction), numbness/tingling in the first 3.5 digits (thumb, index, middle, radial half of ring finger), especially at night.
  • A wrist splint (often neutral) is used for carpal tunnel syndrome to reduce pressure on the nerve.
  • Phalen's test, Tinel's sign, thenar atrophy assessment, sensory testing.

 

Option C. Ulnar Nerve:

 

  • The ulnar nerve is responsible for most of the intrinsic muscles of the hand (interossei, hypothenar muscles), some wrist flexion, and sensation over the little finger and half of the ring finger (both palmar and dorsal aspects).
  • Commonly injured at the elbow (cubital tunnel syndrome) or at the wrist (Guyon's canal syndrome).
  • "Claw hand" deformity (hyperextension of MCP joints and flexion of IP joints of the 4th and 5th fingers), weakness of finger abduction/adduction, difficulty with pinch, atrophy of interossei and hypothenar muscles, numbness/tingling in the 4th and 5th digits.
  • Splints may be used to prevent clawing in severe cases.
  • Froment's sign (weakness of adductor pollicis), Wartenberg's sign (inability to adduct the little finger), sensory testing.

 

Option D. Volkmann's Ischemic Contracture:

 

  • This is not a nerve injury in itself, but rather a severe complication (ischemic contracture) of an injury (usually a supracondylar fracture of the humerus or forearm compartment syndrome) that causes acute ischemia (lack of blood supply) to the forearm muscles and nerves. 
  • The ischemia leads to muscle necrosis and fibrosis, resulting in a fixed flexion deformity of the wrist and fingers.
  • Increased pressure within the forearm compartments due to swelling or bleeding, compressing blood vessels and nerves.
  • Severe pain, pain on passive stretching of fingers, pallor, pulselessness, paresthesias (early nerve involvement), and paralysis (late sign). If not treated quickly, it progresses to contracture.
  • While instruments might be used in its treatment (e.g., fasciotomy instruments for acute compartment syndrome, or splints/orthoses for managing established contractures), it's a syndrome of muscle and nerve damage, not a single nerve injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cock-Up Splint is a classic splint used to manage the "wrist drop" deformity caused by radial nerve palsy. 
  • This is a very common association taught in medical education.

questions.text: During a forensic examination of a deceased newborn, the forensic resident ties off the bronchus and then places the lungs in water to observe whether they float or sink, to help determine if the infant had ever breathed. What is this postmortem test called?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrostatic test

 

  • In a forensic setting, when the pathologist ties the bronchus and places the lungs in water to check their floating or sinking, this is referred to as the hydrostatic test.
  •  This test is performed during the autopsy of a newborn to help establish whether the infant was born alive or stillborn. 
  • If the lungs contain air (meaning the infant had taken breaths), they will float in water. 
  • If the lungs are still solid and unexpanded (indicating no breathing at all), they will sink. 
  • Tying the bronchus prevents air leakage and preserves the true buoyancy of the lung tissue during this procedure. 
  • This test is critical in evaluating cases of suspected infanticide or unexplained perinatal death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diatoms test: The diatoms test is used to support the diagnosis of drowning. It involves detecting diatom shells (types of algae) in the organs and bone marrow to show inhalation of water during life, not the floating or sinking of lungs. Therefore it does not involve tying the bronchus or placing the lungs in water, making this incorrect.

 

Option B. Gettler test: Gettler’s test is employed in cases of drowning to estimate the chloride content of the blood in the right and left heart chambers, not to evaluate lung buoyancy by water flotation. Hence this option is incorrect for the procedure described.

 

Option D. Plocquet’s test: Plocquet’s test estimates the weight ratio of the lungs to the body weight of the fetus to infer whether breathing occurred, but it does not involve tying the bronchus and checking flotation. Therefore, Plocquet’s test is not correct in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hydrostatic test is a forensic method in which the bronchus is tied and the lungs are placed in water to observe their floating or sinking, helping to determine whether a newborn took a breath before death.

questions.text:
Which of the following are features of Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome as per the Rotterdam criteria? 

 

  1. Oligo-ovulation or anovulation
  2. Hyperprolactinemia
  3. Clinical or biochemical signs of hyperandrogenism
  4. Polycystic ovaries on ultrasound
questions.solution:
Ans. D) a, c, d

 

  • The Rotterdam Criteria (2003) state that 2 out of 3 of the following must be present to diagnose PCOS:

 

a. Oligo-ovulation or anovulation: Menstrual irregularities such as oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea are common in PCOS due to chronic anovulation.

 

c. Clinical or biochemical signs of hyperandrogenism: Clinical signs include hirsutism, acne, male-pattern hair loss. Biochemical evidence includes raised serum testosterone or DHEAS.

 

d. Polycystic ovaries on USG: Defined as ≥12 follicles (2–9 mm) in at least one ovary or increased ovarian volume >10 mL.

 

  • Exclusion of other conditions is essential (e.g., CAH, Cushing's, hyperprolactinemia).

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement b. Hyperprolactinemia: Incorrect. This is excluded before diagnosing PCOS. Hyperprolactinemia can cause amenorrhea but is a different disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PCOS is diagnosed using the Rotterdam criteria, which require 2 out of 3: anovulation, hyperandrogenism, or polycystic ovaries. 
  • Hyperprolactinemia must be ruled out.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements regarding the management of a trauma patient. 

 

  1. Tranexamic acid reduces the risk of mortality only in patients with penetrating trauma but not blunt trauma
  2. All patients with signs of shock should receive tranexamic acid within 3 hours of injury
  3. Crystalloids are preferred over blood and blood products for resuscitation of severely hypovolemic patients with trauma
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Statement 2

 

All patients with signs of shock should receive tranexamic acid within 3 hours of injury: This statement is correct. The CRASH-2 trial also indicated that tranexamic acid is beneficial when administered within 3 hours of injury to patients with signs of significant hemorrhage or shock.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 1. Tranexamic acid reduces risk of mortality only in patients of penetrating trauma with no role in blunt trauma cases: This statement is incorrect. Tranexamic acid has been shown to reduce the risk of mortality from bleeding in both penetrating and blunt trauma cases, as evidenced by the CRASH-2 trial.

 

Statement 3. Crystalloids are preferred over blood and blood products for resuscitation of severely hypovolemic patients of trauma: This statement is incorrect. In severely hypovolemic trauma patients, blood and blood products are preferred to restore circulating volume and oxygen-carrying capacity. Crystalloids can be used temporarily while awaiting blood products but are not the resuscitation fluid of choice in severe hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key points in trauma management include administering tranexamic acid within 3 hours to patients with signs of significant hemorrhage, using blood and blood products for the resuscitation of severely hypovolemic patients, and controlling life-threatening hemorrhage as a first step in the primary survey of trauma patients.

questions.text: Under the National Population Policy (NPP) 2000 of India, what was the targeted goal for maternal mortality ratio (MMR) to be achieved?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 100 per 100,000 live births

 

  • The National Population Policy (NPP) 2000 of India laid down several health and population stabilization goals, one of which was reducing the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) to below 100 per 100,000 live births. 
  • This target was part of a broader strategy to improve maternal and child health through institutional deliveries, antenatal care, skilled birth attendance, and emergency obstetric services.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The National Population Policy 2000 of India aimed to reduce maternal mortality to below 100 per 100,000 live births as a public health goal.
  • Under SDG target 3.1 – To reduce MMR <70 per 100,000 live births by 2030.

choices.text: It is caused exclusively by influenza A viruses
It is responsible for influenza pandemics
It is the result of gradual point mutations leading to seasonal epidemics
It is due to frameshift mutations of the viral genome

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the antigenic drift?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is the result of gradual point mutations leading to seasonal epidemics

 

  • Antigenic drift refers to the gradual accumulation of point mutations in the genes encoding the viral hemagglutinin and neuraminidase proteins. 
  • These minor genetic changes alter the viral antigens just enough to allow the virus to escape existing host immunity, leading to seasonal influenza epidemics. 
  • This happens in both influenza A and influenza B viruses.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is caused exclusively by influenza A viruses: Incorrect. Antigenic drift occurs in both influenza A and influenza B viruses.

 

Option B. It is responsible for influenza pandemics: Incorrect. Pandemics are typically caused by antigenic shift, not drift. It leads to epidemic and sporadic infections.

 

Option D. It is due to frameshift mutations of the viral genome: Incorrect. It results from point mutations, not frameshift mutations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Antigenic drift is a process of gradual point mutations in influenza virus genes that leads to seasonal epidemics and occurs in both influenza A and B.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman has been evaluated for infertility after several years of unsuccessful attempts at conception. Ovulation studies are performed and treatment is initiated. A medication is prescribed that has dual action, either stimulating or suppressing ovulation, depending on the dosing schedule. Which of the following medications is most consistent with this pharmacologic profile?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leuprolide

 

  • Leuprolide is a GnRH analog whose effects vary depending on the pattern of administration:
  • When administered in pulsatile fashion, it mimics physiologic GnRH secretion, stimulating LH and FSH release from the anterior pituitary, thereby inducing ovulation.
  • When administered continuously, it causes downregulation of GnRH receptors in the pituitary, leading to suppression of LH and FSH, which inhibits ovulation. This mechanism is therapeutically useful in conditions like endometriosis, uterine fibroids, and precocious puberty.
  • Thus, leuprolide's dual effect—either stimulating or inhibiting ovulation—depends strictly on its dosing schedule, which makes it unique among ovulation-related drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Letrozole: An aromatase inhibitor that reduces estrogen synthesis, removing negative feedback on the hypothalamus and pituitary, thereby increasing FSH levels to stimulate ovulation. However, it does not have inhibitory effects on ovulation; its role is limited to ovulation induction

 

Option C. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG): HCG mimics LH surge and is used to trigger ovulation after follicular development. It does not inhibit ovulation under any circumstance. Therefore, it lacks the dual-action profile described in the question.

 

Option D. Clomiphene: A selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that blocks estrogen receptors in the hypothalamus, reducing negative feedback and increasing FSH/LH release. It is used to stimulate ovulation but does not suppress it, regardless of dose or schedule.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leuprolide is a GnRH analog that can either stimulate or suppress ovulation based on its administration pattern.
  •  Pulsatile dosing stimulates the pituitary-gonadal axis, while continuous dosing suppresses it by downregulating GnRH receptors. 
  • This pharmacologic property is clinically significant in managing both infertility and hormone-responsive gynecological conditions.

choices.text: Represents the maximum velocity (Vmax) of the enzyme
Equals the reciprocal of the Michaelis constant (1/Km)
Equals the negative reciprocal of the Michaelis constant (−1/Km)
Represents the turnover number (kcat) of the enzyme

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the interpretation of the x-intercept of Lineweaver-Burk plot?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Equals the negative reciprocal of the Michaelis constant (−1/Km)

 

  • The Lineweaver-Burk plot is a double reciprocal plot used to linearize Michaelis-Menten kinetics. The equation is derived as:

 

 

 

  • This equation is in the form of y = mx + b, where:
    • y-intercept = 1/Vmax
    • x-intercept = −1/Km
    • slope (m) = Km/Vmax
  • Therefore, the x-intercept gives −1/Km, which is useful in estimating the affinity of the enzyme for its substrate.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, the x-intercept represents −1/Km, allowing for estimation of substrate affinity, while the y-intercept gives 1/Vmax, helping determine enzyme efficiency.

choices.text: Single dose of tetanus toxoid (TT)
Tetanus immunoglobulin + full course of TT
Tetanus immunoglobulin + single dose of TT

questions.text: A 34-year-old man reports to the emergency department 4 hours after sustaining a clean, non-penetrating wound while repairing a household appliance. He recalls receiving his last tetanus booster approximately 10 years ago. There is no sign of contamination or necrosis. What is the most appropriate next step in wound management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Single dose of tetanus toxoid (TT)

 

  • In patients with clean, minor wounds and a history of complete primary tetanus immunization, a booster dose of tetanus toxoid is indicated if the last dose was administered between 5-10 years ago
  • The wound in this case is clean and the patient presents early, so no tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) is required.
  • A single booster TT dose is sufficient to maintain protective immunity.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tetanus immunoglobulin + full course of TT: This is only required for dirty or major wounds in individuals with unknown immunization status or incomplete vaccination. This patient has a clean wound and a known immunization history (last dose 10 years ago), so this is unnecessary.

 

Option C. Full course of TT: This is indicated when primary immunization is incomplete or unknown, which is not the case here. The patient is previously immunized.

 

Option D. Tetanus immunoglobulin + single dose of TT: Again, TIG is reserved for high-risk wounds or unimmunized individuals. This patient has a low-risk wound and a complete vaccine history, so immunoglobulin is not needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For clean, minor wounds, a single booster dose of tetanus toxoid is recommended if the last dose was administered 5-10 years ago and the patient has completed the primary vaccination series.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child has serum creatinine of 0.5 mg/dL. Height = 120 cm. Calculate eGFR using Schwartz formula (k = 0.55).
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 132 mL/min/1.73 m²

 

  • The Schwartz formula is:
  • eGFR = (k × height in cm) / serum creatinine
    = (0.55 × 120) / 0.5
    = 66 / 0.5
    = 132 mL/min/1.73 m², which indicates normal kidney function for age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Schwartz formula estimates pediatric eGFR using the equation: (k × height in cm) / serum creatinine, with k = 0.55 for children over 1 year of age.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is undergoing an open abdominal surgery for bowel resection. During the procedure, the surgeon uses a retractor as shown below. Which of the following surgical instruments is most likely being used?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Morris retractor

 

A broad, flat, and heavy retractor specifically used to retract the abdominal wall muscles during deep abdominal procedures. It is curved and sturdy, ideal for providing exposure in deep surgical fields.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deaver retractor: Long and thin, used for deep retraction in thoracic and abdominal surgeries, but typically not broad and flat like the Morris.

 

 

Option B. Doyen retractor: Used primarily in gastrointestinal surgery to retract the intestines; not suitable for deep muscle retraction.

 

 

Option D. Langenbeck retractor: A small handheld retractor used for superficial soft tissue retraction, not suitable for deep muscular retraction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Morris retractor is a heavy, broad, curved instrument used for deep abdominal wall muscle retraction in open surgeries.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to present with fluid-filled vesicles or bullae?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lupus vulgaris
 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, typically presenting as slowly enlarging erythematous to violaceous plaques with central atrophy and scarring, most often over the face, neck, or extremities.
  •  It does not present with vesicles or bullae.
  • The lesions expand centrifugally, are firm, and may show “apple jelly” nodules on diascopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Impetigo: Impetigo, especially bullous impetigo, is caused by Staphylococcus aureus producing exfoliative toxins, and it presents with fluid-filled vesicles and bullae which rupture to form honey-colored crusts. Common in children, it's a classic bullous disorder.

 

Option B. Diabetes mellitus: Diabetes can be associated with Bullous diabeticorum, a spontaneous, non-inflammatory bullous disorder. It commonly affects the lower legs and feet and presents with clear-fluid-filled blisters without preceding trauma.

 

 

Option C. Porphyria: Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT), a type of porphyria, manifests as photosensitive bullous lesions on sun-exposed areas such as the hands and face. These are fluid-filled vesicles or bullae that can rupture, crust, and scar.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lupus vulgaris, a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, presents with indurated plaques and central scarring but does not exhibit vesiculobullous (fluid-filled) lesions, unlike impetigo, bullous diabeticorum, or porphyria cutanea tarda.

questions.text: A diagnostic researcher is evaluating a new blood biomarker to determine the best cutoff value that maximizes sensitivity and specificity in identifying early-stage pancreatic cancer. Which of the following statistical tools is most appropriate for establishing the diagnostic threshold?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Receiver operating characteristic curve

 

  • The ROC curve is the most appropriate method for determining the threshold for diagnosis. 
  • It plots sensitivity (true positive rate) against 1-specificity (false positive rate) for various cutoff points of a diagnostic test. 
  • The ideal cutoff is typically chosen near the top-left corner of the ROC space, representing a balance of high sensitivity and specificity. 
  • This curve allows clinicians and researchers to visualize and quantitatively assess the diagnostic accuracy and choose the best threshold for a test result.

 

ROC Curve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pearson coefficient: This is used to measure the strength and direction of linear correlation between two continuous variables. It does not provide threshold information or evaluate diagnostic test performance.

 

Option C. Analysis of variance: Analysis of variance (ANOVA) is used to compare means across multiple groups to determine if there are statistically significant differences. It has no role in setting a diagnostic test threshold.

 

Option D. Pre-test probability: This refers to the estimated likelihood of disease before a diagnostic test is conducted, based on clinical assessment or prevalence data. While important for interpreting results after testing, it does not help determine the test’s threshold.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ROC curve is the preferred method to identify the optimal diagnostic cutoff by evaluating a test's sensitivity and specificity across a range of values.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought for evaluation due to global developmental delay, poor eye contact, and microcephaly. Her mother reports that she had normal milestones until 6 months, after which she gradually lost hand skills and began showing repetitive hand-wringing movements. On examination, she has hypotonia, lack of verbal communication, and gait disturbances.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rett Syndrome

 

  • Global developmental delay – if the child is delay ≥2 domains of development
  • Almost exclusively in girls
  • Normal development followed by regression (usually between 6–18 months)
  • Loss of purposeful hand use with stereotyped hand-wringing
  • Microcephaly, poor social interaction, absent speech
  • Mutation in MECP2 gene on X chromosome
  • Gait disturbance, seizures, hypotonia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Angelman Syndrome:

 

  • Presents with happy demeanor, inappropriate laughter, ataxia, severe speech impairment, and seizures
  • Due to maternal deletion of 15q11–13
  • No hand-wringing or clear regression like Rett

 

Option C. Fragile X Syndrome:

 

  • Most common inherited cause of intellectual disability
  • Boys > girls
  • Large ears, long face, macroorchidism, hand-flapping, autistic behavior
  • FMR1 gene (CGG repeat) on X chromosome
  • Developmental delay but not regressive

 

Option D. Landau-Kleffner Syndrome:

 

  • Acquired epileptic aphasia
  • Child loses previously acquired language skills, typically after 3 years of age
  • EEG shows epileptiform discharges
  • No hand stereotypes or microcephaly

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rett Syndrome should be suspected in females with developmental regression, loss of hand skills, stereotyped hand-wringing, and neuroregression after initial normal development.
  •  It’s an X-linked dominant disorder caused by MECP2 gene mutation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old adolescent presents with a painful swelling involving the proximal tibia. Plain radiographs demonstrate a periosteal reaction with new bone formation in the diaphyseal region. Biopsy of the lesion is shown below, and immunohistochemistry reveals positivity for synaptophysin and MIC-2 (CD99). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ewing sarcoma

 

  • This 16-year-old adolescent with a painful upper tibial swelling showing periosteal reaction on X-ray involving the diaphysis, is a classic presentation of Ewing sarcoma, a highly malignant round cell tumor of childhood and adolescence.
  • Histopathology showing small round blue cells is a hallmark feature of Ewing sarcoma.
  • Immunohistochemical positivity for MIC-2 (CD99) is highly characteristic.
  • Synaptophysin positivity supports its neuroectodermal differentiation, as Ewing sarcoma is classified under the primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET) family.
  • Diaphyseal location and the described radiologic finding (periosteal new bone formation, sometimes described as “onion-skin” periosteal reaction) are also highly typical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metastatic neuroblastoma: Although neuroblastoma can metastasize to bone, it typically affects younger children and is not usually centered in long bone diaphysis with this pattern of periosteal reaction.

 

Option B. Osteoclastoma: Osteoclastoma (giant cell tumor) usually occurs in the epiphysis of long bones in young adults, not the diaphysis of adolescents, and lacks small round blue cells or CD99 positivity.

 

Option D. Osteosarcoma: Typically arises in the metaphysis, with malignant osteoid production, and shows different immunohistochemical profile (osteocalcin/osteonectin positive, not MIC-2/CD99).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ewing sarcoma typically affects the diaphysis of long bones in adolescents, shows small round blue cells on histology, and is characteristically positive for CD99 (MIC-2) and sometimes synaptophysin.

 

Note - Ewing sarcoma is characterized by specific chromosomal translocations, most commonly involving the EWS gene on chromosome 22 and the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11, resulting in the t(11;22) translocation.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a history of chronic exertional dyspnea and progressive lower limb edema died despite supportive therapy. At autopsy, the liver specimen is shown below. Which of the following was most likely the underlying cause leading to this hepatic change?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right-sided heart failure

 

  • The 64-year-old man had chronic exertional dyspnea and progressive lower limb edema, and ultimately died despite supportive therapy. 
  • At autopsy, the liver specimen showed the classic mottled red-and-tan appearance, also known as nutmeg liver. 
  • Histopathology confirmed congestion of the central veins with surrounding zone 3 hemorrhage.
  • This pattern results from chronic passive venous congestion of the liver, caused by right-sided heart failure. 
  • In right-sided heart failure, there is elevated central venous pressure, which is transmitted backward to the hepatic veins. 
  • The resulting venous congestion most severely affects the centrilobular (zone 3) hepatocytes, where blood flow is already lowest.
  • Over time, these areas undergo congestion and necrosis, while the periportal areas remain relatively unaffected, leading to the characteristic mottled appearance of nutmeg liver.
  • This autopsy finding is a hallmark of chronic passive hepatic congestion secondary to right-sided heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Budd-Chiari syndrome: Budd-Chiari syndrome is hepatic vein thrombosis, which leads to liver congestion as well — but typically presents with painful hepatomegaly, ascites, and rapid liver enlargement, not the chronic nutmeg pattern. It is a different mechanism from chronic heart failure–related congestion.

 

Option B. Chronic portal hypertension: Chronic portal hypertension results from elevated pressure in the portal vein system, usually due to cirrhosis. It causes splenomegaly, ascites, and portosystemic shunting but does not typically cause centrilobular congestion with nutmeg liver.

 

Option D. Hepatic steatosis: Hepatic steatosis is fatty infiltration of the liver, usually related to alcohol or metabolic syndrome, which gives the liver a yellow, greasy appearance, not a congested nutmeg pattern with zone 3 hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nutmeg liver seen on gross pathology at autopsy is a classic feature of chronic passive congestion of the liver due to right-sided heart failure, leading to congestion of central veins and zone 3 hemorrhagic necrosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of shoulder pain and weakness. She has a positive drop arm test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rotator cuff tear

 

  • The rotator cuff is a group of four muscles (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis) and their tendons that surround the shoulder joint. 
  • They help to stabilize the humerus in the shoulder socket and facilitate shoulder movement, especially rotation and abduction (lifting the arm away from the body). 
  • A tear can be partial or full thickness.
  • In a 60-year-old, tears are often degenerative due to chronic wear and tear, age-related changes in tendon vascularity, and repetitive overhead activities. 
  • Acute tears can also occur from trauma (e.g., a fall).
  • Clinical Presentation: 
    • Pain: Often worse with overhead activities, at night, or when lying on the affected side.
    • Weakness: Difficulty lifting the arm, especially against resistance.
    • Limited Range of Motion: Primarily active range of motion (patient trying to move the arm), while passive range of motion (someone else moving the arm) may be less affected, unless significant pain or stiffness is present.
    • Positive Drop Arm Test: This is performed by passively abducting the patient's arm to 90 degrees and then asking them to slowly lower it. 
    • A positive test occurs if the patient cannot smoothly control the lowering of the arm and it "drops" suddenly, or if they experience significant pain. This specifically indicates a tear of the supraspinatus tendon.
  • The patient's age, chronic pain and weakness, and the definitive positive drop arm test strongly point to a rotator cuff tear. This test is a classic indicator of supraspinatus pathology, which is the most commonly torn rotator cuff tendon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adhesive Capsulitis:

 

  • A condition characterized by significant pain and progressive stiffness and loss of both active and passive range of motion in the shoulder joint. It involves thickening and contraction of the joint capsule.
  • Often idiopathic (no clear cause), but can be associated with diabetes, thyroid disorders, or immobilization after injury.
  • Clinical Presentation: 
    • Pain: Often severe, especially in the initial "freezing" phase.
    • Progressive Stiffness: Characterized by a global loss of both active and passive range of motion in multiple planes (abduction, external rotation, internal rotation). This is a key differentiator from a rotator cuff tear where passive range of motion is often preserved.
  • While a 60-year-old can develop adhesive capsulitis, the primary finding in the case is weakness and a positive drop arm test. 
  • While adhesive capsulitis causes weakness due to pain and stiffness, the drop arm test is not typically positive in adhesive capsulitis in the way it is for a rotator cuff tear. 
  • The hallmark of adhesive capsulitis is restricted passive range of motion, which isn't explicitly mentioned as the primary issue.

 

Option C. Glenohumeral Osteoarthritis:

 

  • Degenerative "wear and tear" arthritis affecting the glenohumeral joint (the ball-and-socket joint of the shoulder). It involves loss of articular cartilage, osteophyte (bone spur) formation, and narrowing of the joint space.
  • Age-related degeneration, previous trauma, or inflammatory arthritis.
  • Clinical Presentation: 
    • Pain: Deep, aching pain in the shoulder, often worse with activity and relieved by rest.
    • Stiffness: Progressive loss of both active and passive range of motion, often described as a grinding or creaking sensation (crepitus).
    • Weakness: Can occur due to pain and disuse, but not typically the primary symptom or the cause of a positive drop arm test.
  • While age is a risk factor, the primary symptoms of osteoarthritis are pain and stiffness, especially with crepitus and restricted passive range of motion. 
  • While weakness can be present, the specific positive drop arm test points away from isolated osteoarthritis and more towards a structural issue like a tendon tear. 
  • Osteoarthritis is more a diagnosis of joint space narrowing and bone spurs on X-ray.

 

Option D. Scapular Winging:

 

  • A condition where the scapula (shoulder blade) protrudes abnormally from the back of the thorax, resembling a "wing." 
  • This is due to weakness or paralysis of the muscles that stabilize the scapula, most commonly the serratus anterior (due to long thoracic nerve injury) or the trapezius (due to accessory nerve injury).
  • Causes: Nerve injury (e.g., from trauma, surgery, or viral illness), muscle weakness, or instability.
  • Visible protrusion of the scapula, especially during arm elevation or pushing activities. Can cause pain and weakness, particularly with overhead activities.
  • While it causes weakness and can lead to shoulder pain, the primary finding for scapular winging is the visible deformity of the scapula. 
  • More importantly, it does not typically result in a positive drop arm test. The weakness pattern is different, impacting the ability to stabilize the scapula rather than directly impacting the ability of the rotator cuff to hold the arm in abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drop arm test specifically assesses the integrity of the supraspinatus tendon, a key component of the rotator cuff.

questions.text: If the DNA strand 5’-CATTCCATGGAATG-3’ is used as a template by RNA polymerase during transcription, what will be the sequence of the resulting mRNA?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5’-CAUUCCAUGGAAUG-3’
 

  • Transcription involves synthesizing mRNA using the template DNA strand.
  • Base pairing rules in transcription:
    • DNA A → RNA U
    • DNA T → RNA A
    • DNA G → RNA C
    • DNA C → RNA G
  • Step-by-step:
    • Given template DNA:  5’-CATTCCATGGAATG-3’
    • Now, RNA polymerase builds the mRNA complementary to the template mRNA: 5’-CAUUCCAUGGAAUG-3’
       

Educational Objective:

 

  • mRNA is built complementary and antiparallel to the DNA template strand, using U instead of T.

questions.text: During a laparoscopic TAPP inguinal repair, the following structures are visualised as shown. What does the letter “F” represent in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral hernia site

 

  • The site below the inguinal ligament and direct hernia site (D) is the site for femoral hernia. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fascia transversalis: Fascia transversalis forms the roof and is above the inguinal ligament

 

Option C. Femoral nerve: The Femoral nerve may lie in the triangle of pain

 

Option D. Triangle of disaster: The Triangle of Pain and Doom is collectively known as the Trapezoid of Disaster. 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 32-year-old man from Uttar Pradesh presents with prolonged fever, weight loss, and splenomegaly. CBC shows pancytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Visceral leishmaniasis

 

  • Prolonged fever, weight loss, splenomegaly, and pancytopenia in a patient from Uttar Pradesh (an endemic region for leishmaniasis) suggest visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), caused by Leishmania donovani.
  • Bone marrow biopsy showing macrophages with intracellular organisms and kinetoplasts (a distinctive DNA structure in Leishmania) confirms the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brucellosis: Causes fever and weight loss but typically presents with lymphadenopathy or hepatomegaly, not pancytopenia or kinetoplasts on biopsy.

 

Option B. Leptospirosis: Features fever, jaundice, and renal failure, but splenomegaly and pancytopenia are uncommon, and kinetoplasts are absent.

 

Option D. Disseminated histoplasmosis: Can cause fever, splenomegaly, and pancytopenia, but intracellular organisms are yeast forms, not kinetoplasts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Visceral leishmaniasis is endemic in Uttar Pradesh; kinetoplasts in macrophages are diagnostic.
  • Pancytopenia results from bone marrow infiltration by Leishmania.
  • Prompt treatment with liposomal amphotericin B is essential to prevent mortality.

choices.text: During closure of skin with interrupted sutures, a cutting needle is inserted at an angle of 90 degrees to the horizontal.
If the depth of the bite is x cm, then the next bite should be at 0.5x cm
To close the rectus sheath, the length of suture material should be 4x the length of the incision
During bowel anastomosis, the submucosa must always be included in each bite

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about suturing technique in surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) If the depth of the bite is x cm, then the next bite should be at 0.5x cm 

 

  • Spacing between bites should be equal to (x cm) or more (2x) than the depth to ensure proper tension and wound edge approximation. 
  • A spacing of 0.5x may lead to uneven closure or gaping.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. During closure of skin with interrupted sutures, a cutting needle is inserted at an angle of 90 degrees to the horizontal:  A cutting needle is designed to penetrate tough skin.  Inserting it perpendicularly (90°) ensures optimal wound edge eversion and minimal trauma.

 

Option C. To close the rectus sheath, the length of suture material should be 4x the length of the incision:  Known as the suture length to wound length ratio (SL:WL) or Jenkin’s rule.  A ratio of ≥4:1 reduces risk of wound dehiscence and incisional hernia.

 

 Option D. During bowel anastomosis, the submucosa must always be included in each bite: The submucosa is the strongest layer of the bowel wall. Including it ensures secure anastomosis and reduces leakage risk.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

  • Option B is incorrect due to flawed spacing logic in suturing.
  • Proper technique ensures secure closure, minimal complications, and optimal healing.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the casualty with a history of abdominal pain and vomiting for the past 4 hours. On examination, the patient has pyrexia and there is tenderness and rebound tenderness in the right iliac fossa. Which among the following is the preferred imaging modality in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ultrasound of the abdomen

 

  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute appendicitis.
  •  In the pediatric population, ultrasound of the abdomen is the preferred imaging modality to identify the presence of an inflamed appendix.
  •  It avoids the risk of radiation exposure. 
  • Ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging modality for suspected acute appendicitis in pediatric patients.
  •  It avoids radiation exposure and has good sensitivity and specificity, especially when performed by an experienced operator.
  • In adults, the best imaging modality is a CT scan. Modern CT is both sensitive and specific (approximately 95%) in the diagnosis of acute appendicitis and worldwide there has been a steady increase in its use for this purpose. 
  • CT has been shown to reduce the rate of negative appendicectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT scan: Computed Tomography (CT) is a highly sensitive and specific imaging modality for diagnosing acute appendicitis in adults. However, due to concerns about radiation exposure, it is not the first-line imaging choice in children.

 

Option C. MRI: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) can be used in the diagnosis of acute appendicitis, especially in pregnant women and in cases where ultrasound results are inconclusive. Its use is limited in the emergency setting due to less availability, higher cost, and longer scan times compared to ultrasound.

 

Option D. X-ray abdomen: An abdominal x-ray is not typically used to diagnose acute appendicitis as it has low sensitivity and specificity for the condition. However, it can be helpful in ruling out other causes of abdominal pain, such as an intestinal obstruction or perforation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging modality for suspected acute appendicitis in children due to its safety profile and good diagnostic accuracy, avoiding the risks associated with radiation exposure from CT scans.

questions.text:
Match the following female reproductive structures with their embryological origin: 

 

List A (Structures):

 

  1. Greater vestibular (Bartholin’s) glands
  2. Granulosa cells
  3. Round ligament
  4. Epoophoron and paroophoron

 

List B (Embryological Origins):

 

  1. Sex cords
  2. Mesonephric tubules
  3. Gubernaculum
  4. Urogenital sinus
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1–D, 2–A, 3–C, 4–B

 

  • 1–D. Greater vestibular (Bartholin’s) glands → Derived from the urogenital sinus
  • 2–A. Granulosa cells → Derived from the sex cords
  • 3–C. Round ligament → Derived from the gubernaculum
  • 4–B. Epoophoron and paroophoron → Remnants of mesonephric tubules

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Greater vestibular (Bartholin’s) glands → Derived from the urogenital sinus
  • Granulosa cells → Derived from the sex cords
  • Round ligament → Derived from the gubernaculum
  • Epoophoron and paroophoron → Remnants of mesonephric tubules

questions.text: A natural disaster affects a region, prompting health officials to coordinate immediate care and long-term public health strategies. In the context of disaster cycle phases, which of the following stages are typically part of the recovery phase?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Response and Rehabilitation

 

  • These are core components of the recovery phase in the disaster cycle.
    • Response refers to immediate actions like emergency medical aid and rescue operations.
    • Rehabilitation involves longer-term strategies to restore normalcy—such as rebuilding infrastructure and providing psychosocial support. Both are essential elements of disaster recovery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Response and Mitigation: While response is part of recovery, mitigation belongs to a different phase—the prevention phase—which aims to reduce the risk and impact of future disasters, not the current recovery.

 

Option C. Rehabilitation and Mitigation: Rehabilitation is correct, but mitigation is not directly part of the recovery phase. Mitigation efforts can be influenced by recovery assessments but are fundamentally forward-looking preventive strategies.

 

Option D. Mitigation and Preparedness: Both mitigation and preparedness fall under the pre-disaster phase, focusing on planning and risk reduction, not the actual recovery after an event.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The recovery phase of a disaster includes immediate response and long-term rehabilitation to restore community function and health services.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with limping gait and left hip pain. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Avascular necrosis

 

  • A condition resulting from the temporary or permanent loss of blood supply to a bone. 
  • Without blood, the bone tissue dies and eventually collapses. In the hip, it commonly affects the femoral head (the "ball" part of the hip joint).
  • Can occur at any age but is often seen in adults between 30-60 years.
  • Steroid use (most common non-traumatic cause), alcohol abuse, trauma (fractures/dislocations of the hip), sickle cell disease, lupus, Gaucher's disease, chemotherapy, radiation, kidney disease, etc. While not explicitly mentioned, many 60-year-olds might have underlying conditions or medication use that could predispose them to AVN.
  • Gradual onset of pain, initially intermittent, then constant. Pain often worsens with weight-bearing. Limping is common. Range of motion may be restricted, especially internal rotation and abduction, due to pain.
  • Early X-rays can be normal. Later stages show sclerosis (increased bone density), lucency (areas of bone death), subchondral collapse (crescent sign), and eventual flattening of the femoral head and joint space narrowing. MRI is the most sensitive imaging test for early AVN.
  • In a 60-year-old with hip pain and limping, AVN is a significant consideration, especially if there are risk factors (even if unstated). 
  • The progression can be relatively insidious, and the pain often worsens with weight-bearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TB Hip (Tuberculosis of the Hip):

 

  • Tuberculosis affecting the hip joint is a form of extrapulmonary tuberculosis. It's a chronic infectious disease that can lead to joint destruction.
  • While TB can affect any age, isolated TB hip in a 60-year-old in a non-endemic area without other systemic symptoms of TB (fever, night sweats, weight loss) is less common than other degenerative or ischemic conditions. It's more often seen in younger individuals or those from endemic regions, or with compromised immune systems.
  • Chronic pain, limping, muscle spasm, and progressive restriction of hip movement. There might be constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss).
  • Early X-rays might be normal, but later show joint space narrowing, subchondral erosions, and often a "cold abscess" (a collection of pus without the usual signs of acute inflammation).
  • While possible, the absence of systemic symptoms or a known TB history in a 60-year-old makes it less probable as a primary diagnosis compared to other more common hip pathologies in this age group. 
  • TB hip often progresses slower and might have more diffuse joint involvement on imaging.

 

Option B. Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA):

 

  • A chronic, systemic autoimmune disease that primarily causes inflammation of the synovial lining of joints. It's typically polyarticular (affecting multiple joints) and symmetrical.
  • Can occur at any age but often presents between 30 and 60 years. While it can affect the hip, it usually involves smaller joints of the hands and feet first and then progresses to larger joints.
  • Joint pain, stiffness (especially morning stiffness lasting over 30 minutes), swelling, tenderness, and warmth. 
  • Fatigue and generalized malaise are common. Hip involvement often comes later in the disease course and is typically bilateral.
  • X-ray Features: Symmetrical joint space narrowing, erosions, and periarticular osteopenia.
  • The presentation describes left hip pain (unilateral). While RA can affect the hip, it's typically part of a broader, polyarticular, and often symmetrical joint involvement pattern. The sole presentation of unilateral hip pain makes RA less likely than conditions primarily affecting one hip.

 

Option C. Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS):

 

  • A chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to stiffness and fusion of vertebrae. It's a type of spondyloarthritis.
  • Usually begins in late adolescence or early adulthood (typically before 40 years of age). It is rare for AS to present for the first time at 60 years old.
  • Chronic back pain and stiffness, especially in the morning and improving with exercise. 
  • Hip involvement can occur, often bilateral, and can be severe, but it's typically secondary to or concurrent with spinal involvement.
  •  Sacroiliitis (inflammation of the SI joints) is the hallmark. Spinal changes include squaring of vertebrae and eventual "bamboo spine." Hip involvement shows symmetrical joint space narrowing and erosions.
  • The age of onset (60 years old) makes new onset Ankylosing Spondylitis extremely unlikely. While a patient with pre-existing AS might have hip pain at 60, the primary presentation at this age would not typically be AS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Avascular Necrosis is the most plausible answer among the given choices for a 60-year-old presenting with unilateral hip pain and limping.
  •  It is likely due to typical age of onset, systemic features, or predominant unilateral hip pain presentation.

choices.text: It prevents clotting by chelating magnesium ions
It prevents clotting by inhibiting thrombin directly
It prevents clotting by removing calcium
It acts as a fixative to preserve cellular elements

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation is started on warfarin therapy. His physician orders laboratory monitoring to assess coagulation status. A vacutainer containing 3.2% sodium citrate is used to collect his sample. Which of the following best explains the role of sodium citrate in this tube?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It prevents clotting by removing calcium

 

  • The image shows a blue-capped vacutainer with 3.2% sodium citrate.
  • Sodium citrate acts by chelating calcium, which is essential for multiple steps of the coagulation cascade, thereby preventing clotting in the collected blood sample.
  • This is the standard tube for coagulation studies, including PT (prothrombin time) and APTT (activated partial thromboplastin time), to monitor anticoagulation therapy or screen for clotting disorders.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It prevents clotting by chelating magnesium ions: Incorrect. sodium citrate specifically binds calcium, not magnesium.

 

Option B. It prevents clotting by inhibiting thrombin directly: Incorrect. Heparin works this way, not sodium citrate.

 

Option D. It acts as a fixative to preserve cellular elements: Incorrect. Fixatives (like formaldehyde) are used for tissue preservation, not anticoagulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium citrate prevents blood clotting in collection tubes by chelating calcium, making it the anticoagulant of choice for coagulation assays such as PT and APTT.

choices.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, R is false
A is false, R is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Babies of diabetic mothers are at increased risk of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

 

Reason (R): Fetal hyperinsulinemia delays the maturation of type II pneumocytes.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A

 

  • Assertion - Correct. Babies born to diabetic mothers (especially if poorly controlled) are at higher risk of RDS even when born at term. This is due to delayed surfactant production.
  • Reason - Correct. In maternal diabetes, the fetus responds to maternal hyperglycemia with increased insulin production. Fetal hyperinsulinemia antagonizes the effect of cortisol, which normally stimulates type II pneumocytes to produce surfactant — a key substance that reduces alveolar surface tension and prevents collapse.
  • So, the reason correctly explains the assertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infants of diabetic mothers are at risk of RDS because fetal hyperinsulinemia delays surfactant production by inhibiting maturation of type II pneumocytes.

choices.text: It can be benign or malignant
Commonly metastasizes to the axillary lymph nodes
It is a mixed neoplasm having both epithelial and mesenchymal elements
Treatment is wide local excision with a 2 cm margin

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about phyllodes tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Commonly metastasizes to axillary lymph nodes

 

  • Cystosarcoma phyllodes, also known as phyllodes tumors, are rare fibroepithelial neoplasms of the breast that can display a broad spectrum of behaviour, ranging from benign to highly malignant.
  • This statement is false. Phyllodes tumors typically metastasize hematogenously, most commonly to the lungs, not via the lymphatic system to the axillary lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It can be benign or malignant: This statement is true. Phyllodes tumors can be benign, borderline, or malignant based on histological features such as stromal cellularity, atypia, mitotic activity, and the nature of the tumor borders. It is malignant if it has >10 abnormal metastasis.

 

Option C. It is a mixed neoplasm having both epithelial and mesenchymal elements: This statement is true. Phyllodes tumors are characterized by their biphasic nature, having both stromal (mesenchymal) and epithelial components.

 

Option D. Treatment is wide local excision with a 2 cm margin: This statement is true. The treatment of choice for phyllodes tumors is wide local excision with clear margins (>2cm) to minimize the risk of local recurrence. Mastectomy may be considered for larger or recurrent tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cystosarcoma phyllodes are fibroepithelial neoplasms of the breast that can range from benign to malignant, are composed of both epithelial and mesenchymal elements, and typically metastasize through the bloodstream rather than the lymphatic system. 
  • The recommended treatment is wide excision with a margin to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: Which of the following antipsychotic medications would be most appropriate due to its relatively minimal impact on metabolic parameters such as weight gain and insulin resistance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ziprasidone

 

  • Ziprasidone is an atypical antipsychotic known for having the least metabolic side effects among second-generation (atypical) antipsychotics. 
  • It has minimal propensity to cause weight gain, dyslipidemia, or glucose intolerance, making it a favorable option for patients who are at risk for or already have metabolic syndrome. 
  • Its relatively favorable metabolic profile stems from its lower affinity for histamine (H1) and 5HT2C receptors, which are associated with weight gain and insulin resistance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clozapine: While effective for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, clozapine is notorious for causing severe metabolic side effects, including significant weight gain, hyperglycemia, and dyslipidemia. It also carries risks such as agranulocytosis and myocarditis, making it inappropriate for patients with metabolic concerns.

 

Option C. Risperidone: Risperidone is another atypical antipsychotic with moderate metabolic risk. It causes weight gain and can lead to hyperprolactinemia, but is not as severe as clozapine or olanzapine in terms of metabolic effects. Still, it is not the best choice for a patient with preexisting metabolic abnormalities.

 

Option D. Haloperidol: Haloperidol, a first-generation (typical) antipsychotic, does not cause significant metabolic derangements, but it is associated with a higher risk of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) and tardive dyskinesia. While its metabolic profile is benign, it is not as commonly used as atypicals unless EPS risks are outweighed by therapeutic benefits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ziprasidone is the atypical antipsychotic associated with the least metabolic side effects, making it a suitable option in patients with risk factors for metabolic syndrome or preexisting metabolic disease.
  • Note – Aripriprazole and Ziprasidone donot cause weight gain.

questions.text: Which of the following disease pathogenesis primarily involves the marked structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paralysis agitans

 

  • Marked structure is Substantia nigra of Midbrain, situated between crus cerebri in front and tegmentum behind. 
  • Cells of substantia nigra contain melanin, iron and synthesize dopamine which is carried through their axons (nigrostriatal fibres) to corpus striatum.
  • Destruction/Degeneration of substantia nigra will cause dopamine deficiency and result in Parkinsonism/Paralysis agitans

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pendular knee jerk: Lesion of paleocerebellum manifests in the form of disturbances of tendon reflexes, pedular knee jerk.

 

Option B. Visual agnosia: Lesion of secondary visual area (area 17)/visual association cortex result in a loss of ability to recognize objects -visual agnosia, seen in opposite field of vision.

 

Option D. Huntington’s chorea: Degeneration of GABA secreting neurons of striatum-caudate nucleus and putamen results in Huntington’s chorea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Degeneration of substantia nigra will cause dopamine deficiency and result in Parkinsonism/Paralysis agitans

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with menorrhagia, petechiae, and fatigue presents for evaluation. CBC: Hb 14 g/dL, WBC 8,500, Platelets 12,000. PT/INR normal. Peripheral smear is shown below. No hepatosplenomegaly. Direct Coombs test is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ITP

 

  • Immune thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Isolated thrombocytopenia without anemia/leukopenia = ITP.
  • Young woman + mucocutaneous bleeding signs.
  • Smear: normal morphology except low platelets (one large megakaryocyte can be seen in the center of the smear). 
  • Bone marrow would show ↑megakaryocytes.
  • PT/INR is normal, ruling out DIC.
  • No hemolysis → TTP unlikely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aplastic anemia: Would show pancytopenia.

 

Option C. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura: Schistocytes, renal dysfunction, fever, MAHA.

 

Option D. Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation: Abnormal coagulation profile, raised D-dimer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ITP presents with isolated thrombocytopenia in otherwise healthy individuals with normal coagulation profile and no systemic features.

questions.text: During fatty acid synthesis, a reaction is noted where a carboxyl group introduced earlier in the process is released. Which of the following steps in fatty acid synthesis involves the release of this carboxyl group (CO₂)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Condensation reaction

 

  • In fatty acid synthesis, acetyl-CoA is first converted to malonyl-CoA via acetyl-CoA carboxylase, which requires biotin and introduces a CO₂ molecule.
  •  However, this added CO₂ is not retained in the final fatty acid product. Instead, it is released in the condensation step when malonyl-ACP and acetyl-ACP combine via the enzyme β-ketoacyl-ACP synthase. 
  • The loss of CO₂ in this step drives the reaction forward, allowing chain elongation of the fatty acid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduction: This involves two steps: the first reduction converts the β-keto group to a hydroxyl group, and the second reduction saturates the final product using NADPH. No CO₂ is involved or released in either reduction step.

 

Option B. Dehydration: This step removes a water molecule from the β-hydroxyacyl intermediate, forming a double bond. There is no involvement of CO₂ in this step.

 

Option C. Hydration: Hydration refers to the addition of water, and it is not a part of fatty acid synthesis. Instead, hydration is a part of β-oxidation, the breakdown pathway of fatty acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In fatty acid synthesis, the CO₂ added to acetyl-CoA to form malonyl-CoA is lost during the condensation step catalyzed by  ketoacyl synthase, which drives the chain elongation process forward.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic requesting long-term contraception. She has two children and no plans for future pregnancy in the next five years. Which of the following is not an absolute contraindication to using this contraceptive device?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Past history of PID

 

  • A past history of PID, if successfully treated and without current symptoms or infection, is not an absolute contraindication to copper IUD insertion.
  •  Careful screening and evaluation are still necessary, but IUDs can be safely used in such patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unexplained vaginal bleeding: Unexplained vaginal bleeding is a contraindication until the cause is identified, as it may mask a more serious underlying pathology (e.g., malignancy or infection).

 

Option B. Distorted uterine cavity: A distorted uterine cavity (due to fibroids, congenital anomalies, etc.) is an absolute contraindication as it increases the risk of IUD malposition or perforation.

 

Option C. Pelvic tuberculosis: Genital TB is a contraindication due to risk of reactivation and infection associated with insertion of a foreign body like an IUD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Copper IUDs are highly effective long-term contraceptives. 
  • Absolute contraindications include unexplained vaginal bleeding, active pelvic infections, pelvic TB, and distorted uterine anatomy—but a past history of PID is not an absolute contraindication if the infection has resolved.

questions.text: Match the following anatomical structures with their best radiological views:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1–c, 2–a, 3–d, 4–b

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To correctly match common paranasal sinus structures with their standard radiological views used in ENT and radiology:
    • Water’s View (Occipitomental) → Maxillary sinus
    • Caldwell View (PA Axial) → Frontal sinus
    • Rhese View (Parieto-orbital Oblique) → Optic foramen/ethmoid oblique
    • Basal (SMV) View → Sphenoid sinus/skull base

questions.text: A preterm infant born at 28 weeks gestation is being monitored in the neonatal intensive care unit. The baby required oxygen therapy for the first two weeks after birth. During a routine ophthalmic examination, a retinal finding is observed where there is extraretinal proliferation of new blood vessels as shown below. Which of the following best corresponds to the current stage of retinopathy of prematurity in this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage 3 

 

  • Stage 3 of Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) is defined by extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation, meaning abnormal blood vessels grow from the ridge into the vitreous.
  • The image clearly shows this neovascular proliferation at the border of vascularized and avascular retina, without retinal detachment, which classifies it as Stage 3.
  • This stage is critical as it can progress rapidly and may require intervention such as laser photocoagulation or anti-VEGF therapy to prevent progression to retinal detachment (Stages 4 and 5).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: Demarcation line is the earliest visible stage, showing only a thin, flat white line separating vascularized and avascular retina. No ridge or extraretinal proliferation is present.

 

Option B. Stage 2:   A ridge is a raised demarcation with height and width, but no neovascular proliferation into the vitreous is seen, unlike Stage 3.

 

Option D. Stage 4: Partial retinal detachment involves retinal elevation and detachment, which is not seen in the current image. The retina remains attached in Stage 3.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Stage 3 ROP is characterized by extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation at the junction of vascularized and avascular retina, indicating a risk of progression to retinal detachment and necessitating timely treatment.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man involved in a high-speed car accident is evaluated in the emergency bay. He is awake, oriented, and hemodynamically stable except for a mild tachycardia. There are multiple abrasions and bruises on his torso, and he reports severe generalized abdominal pain. Point-of-care ultrasound using (eFAST) is performed, and the coronal view from the right upper quadrant is shown below. Based on this scan, what is the most appropriate interpretation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Positive FAST

 

  • The given ultrasound image is a classic right upper quadrant (RUQ) Morison’s pouch view from a FAST scan, showing a clear anechoic (black) stripe between the liver and the right kidney, representing free intraperitoneal fluid. 
  • In a trauma patient, this is highly suggestive of hemoperitoneum, indicating intra-abdominal bleeding, hence a positive FAST.

 

 

  • The presence of free fluid in the perihepatic space in a trauma scenario is treated as hemoperitoneum until proven otherwise.
  • The eFAST additionally screens for pericardial tamponade and pneumothorax, but this image focuses on intra-abdominal fluid collection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inconclusive FAST: Would apply if there were poor-quality images or artifact, but this scan clearly shows free fluid.


Option B. Negative FAST: Incorrect because there is definitive evidence of free fluid present.


Option D. Not applicable: Not relevant here since a clear FAST interpretation can be made.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a trauma patient, the presence of anechoic fluid in Morison’s pouch on eFAST strongly suggests hemoperitoneum and is interpreted as a positive FAST scan.

choices.text: Linking Maternal health to Reproductive health
Linking home and community-based services to facility-based care

questions.text: Which of the following actions is not included in the RMNCH+A (Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn, Child, and Adolescent Health) approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Referral to PHC/CHC

 

  • While referrals are a common component of healthcare delivery, referral to PHC/CHC specifically is not a defined strategic action under RMNCH+A.
  • The RMNCH+A approach is focused on continuum of care across life stages and healthcare platforms, and emphasizes linkages, integration, and inclusiveness—but does not prioritize referral to PHC/CHC as a central element of its framework.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Linking Maternal health to Reproductive health: This is a core principle of RMNCH+A. It integrates reproductive, maternal, newborn, child, and adolescent health services into a cohesive strategy.

 

Option B. Linking home and community-based services to facility-based care: This is explicitly promoted in the RMNCH+A approach to ensure continuity of care, particularly in rural or underserved areas.

 

Option D. Involvement of private organizations: The RMNCH+A strategy supports public-private partnerships and leverages private sector resources for expanding access and improving service delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The RMNCH+A approach promotes a continuum of care across life stages and service delivery platforms, but referral to PHC/CHC is not a specifically outlined strategic action in its framework.

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)
Hypercalcemia of malignancy due to PTHrP secretion

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with persistent cough, unintentional weight loss, and pleuritic chest pain for two months. On examination, there is tenderness and redness over superficial veins of his lower limbs that appears to change location over days. A biopsy of a lung lesion shows glands with mucin production. Immunohistochemistry demonstrates brown staining for TTF-1 and napsin A, positivity for CK7, and negativity for CK20. Which of the following syndromes is most strongly associated with this patient’s malignancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau's syndrome)

 

  • This patient has lung adenocarcinoma, as suggested by the histologic finding of gland formation with mucin production, and confirmed by immunohistochemistry (IHC) markers showing:
    • TTF-1 positive (thyroid transcription factor 1)
    • Napsin A positive
    • CK7 positive
    • CK20 negative
  • The brown color on IHC slides indicates positive staining.
  • Adenocarcinoma of the lung is the most common subtype of non-small cell lung cancer in smokers and nonsmokers alike. 
  • Importantly, this type of lung cancer is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes (PNS). One key PNS is migratory thrombophlebitis, also called Trousseau's sign, which is characterized by recurrent and migratory superficial thrombophlebitis due to hypercoagulability from tumor-related procoagulant factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH): This is associated with small cell lung carcinoma, not adenocarcinoma. It leads to euvolemic hyponatremia due to excess ADH secretion.

 

Option B. Hypercalcemia of malignancy due to PTHrP secretion: This is most classically associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, not adenocarcinoma.

 

Option D. Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome: This is another paraneoplastic syndrome related to small cell lung carcinoma, characterized by autoantibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels leading to proximal muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenocarcinoma of the lung is associated with migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau’s sign) as a paraneoplastic syndrome, and shows IHC positivity for TTF-1, napsin A, CK7, and negative for CK20.

questions.text:
Branches from second part of maxillary artery are: 

 

  1. Middle meningeal artery
  2. Masseteric artery
  3. Sphenopalatine artery
  4. Buccal artery
  5. Accessory meningeal artery
  6. Anterior tympanic artery
  7. Deep temporal artery
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4, 7

 

  • Maxillary artery is the larger terminal branch of external carotid artery. It is divided into three parts by lateral pterygoid muscle.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Branches of maxillary artery:

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy with not able to get up from sitting position and a sign shown below. What lab abnormality is expected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High CK 

 

  • The image depicts Gower’s sign, a classic finding in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).
  •  The child uses his hands to "climb up" his thighs to rise from the floor due to proximal muscle weakness, especially of the hip and pelvic girdle muscles.
  • Creatine kinase is markedly elevated in Duchenne muscular dystrophy due to ongoing muscle fiber breakdown.
  •  It is often the first and most sensitive marker of muscle damage in these children, sometimes elevated even before clinical weakness is apparent.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. High aldolase: While aldolase can also be elevated in muscular dystrophies, it is less specific and less sensitive than CK in DMD, and is typically not the first choice in screening.

 

Option C. Low CK: This would be inconsistent with muscle fiber breakdown; in fact, CK is usually 10–100 times normal in early DMD.

 

Option D. High AST only: AST may be mildly elevated due to muscle involvement, but isolated AST without CK elevation would not explain the clinical findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gower’s sign is characteristic of Duchenne muscular dystrophy and Beckers dystrophy, where early lab findings typically include markedly elevated serum CK due to progressive muscle fiber degeneration.

choices.text: After the patient wakes up from anesthesia
After resuscitation from cardiac arrest

questions.text: The position shown in the image, is commonly recommended under which of the following circumstances?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

  • The position shown in the image is known as the recovery position.
  •  It is used in multiple medical situations to help maintain an open airway and prevent aspiration if vomiting occurs. 
  • This position is commonly recommended for:

 

Option A. After the patient wakes up from anesthesia: To ensure the airway remains open and to prevent aspiration in a post-anesthesia patient who may still be recovering from the effects of sedation.

 

Option B. After a seizure: To keep the airway clear and protect the patient from potential aspiration, especially if postictal vomiting occurs.

 

Option C. After resuscitation from cardiac arrest: Once spontaneous circulation is restored and the patient is breathing but not fully conscious, to maintain airway patency and protect against aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The recovery position is a versatile and important position used across various medical disciplines. 
  • It is critical for ensuring patient safety in situations where consciousness may be impaired, helping to keep the airway open and reduce the risk of aspiration.

choices.text: Both surface tension and compliance - decreased
Both surface tension and compliance - increased

questions.text: A preterm baby born at 28 weeks gestation is brought to the NICU with symptoms of tachypnea, nasal flaring, grunting, and intercostal retractions within hours of birth. Chest X-ray shows a ground-glass appearance and air bronchograms, suggestive of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). Which of the following is true regarding the changes in surface tension and lung compliance in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surface tension - increased; Compliance - decreased

 

  • In neonatal RDS, there is deficient surfactant (produced by Type II pneumocytes).
  • Surfactant normally lowers alveolar surface tension and increases lung compliance.
  • In its absence, surface tension increases, causing alveolar collapse and reduced compliance.
  • Result: Lungs become stiff, leading to impaired gas exchange and respiratory distress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Surface tension - decreased; Compliance – increased: This is the normal physiology seen in term infants or those given surfactant therapy. Not true for a preterm baby with RDS.

 

Option C. Both surface tension and compliance – decreased: Surface tension is increased, not decreased, due to lack of surfactant. Compliance is indeed decreased, but this option is only partially correct.

 

Option D. Both surface tension and compliance – increased: This contradicts the pathology of RDS. Increased compliance would mean lungs are easily distensible—which is not the case in surfactant deficiency. Surface tension also does not decrease without surfactant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In neonatal RDS, surfactant deficiency increases alveolar surface tension and decreases lung compliance, leading to respiratory distress in preterm infants.

choices.text: Using a narrower confidence interval
Increasing the number of participants enrolled

questions.text: In the context of evaluating the efficacy of a new therapeutic intervention, researchers are concerned about failing to detect a true effect when one actually exists. Which of the following changes in study design is most likely to reduce the risk of this outcome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increasing the number of participants enrolled

 

  • Increasing the sample size reduces the chance of a Type II error (false negative), which occurs when a study fails to reject the null hypothesis despite a true effect being present.
  •  A larger sample size increases the statistical power of the study, which is the probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis.
  •  Power is mathematically defined as (1 - β), where β is the probability of a Type II error. 
  • Thus, increasing sample size effectively lowers β and strengthens the study’s ability to detect a real difference.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Using a narrower confidence interval: This relates to precision but does not directly address Type II error. Narrower intervals result from increased sample size or less variability, but adjusting the width of a confidence interval alone does not directly influence the likelihood of a false negative (Type II error).

 

Option B. Accepting the null hypothesis: This is a decision outcome, not a method to reduce error. Accepting the null is part of the conclusion process; it doesn’t alter the study’s power or error probability. It is an incorrect method to reduce Type II error.

 

Option D. Lowering the alpha error threshold (decreasing significance level): This would actually increase the probability of a Type II error, not reduce it. A lower α (e.g., from 0.05 to 0.01) makes it harder to reject the null, increasing the chance of missing a real effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To reduce the likelihood of Type II error, one should increase the sample size, thereby increasing the statistical power of the study.

choices.text: The diagnosis in the above case is inflamed and perforated meckels diverticulum (MD)
MD is attached to the mesenteric border 2 feet proximal to ileocaecal junction
It is a remnant of proximal part of vitellointestinal duct
Meckel scan with 99mTc-pertechnetate will diagnose MD than CT scan or ultrasound

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with colicky periumbilical pain that has migrated to the right iliac fossa, with guarding and CT evidence of free intraperitoneal air and thickened distal ileum. Which statement below is not true regarding the suspected lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MD is attached to the mesenteric border 2 feet proximal to ileocaecal junction

 

  • Meckel's diverticulum (MD) is characteristically located on the antimesenteric border of the ileum, not the mesenteric side.
