  • This is a key anatomical feature that helps differentiate MD from other ileal structures such as small bowel loops or inflammatory conditions like Crohn’s disease that affect the mesenteric border.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The diagnosis in the above case is inflamed and perforated meckels diverticulum (MD): True. The presentation of colicky umbilical pain shifting to the right iliac fossa along with signs of peritonitis (intraperitoneal air and guarding) strongly supports the diagnosis of inflamed and perforated Meckel’s diverticulum. It can mimic acute appendicitis and lead to diagnostic confusion.

 

Option C. It is a remnant of proximal part of vitellointestinal duct: True. MD is a remnant of the proximal part of the vitellointestinal (omphalomesenteric) duct, which normally obliterates during embryonic development. Persistence results in MD.

 

Option D. Meckel scan with 99mTc-pertechnetate will diagnose MD than CT scan or ultrasound: True. A Meckel scan using 99mTc-pertechnetate detects ectopic gastric mucosa, which is often present in symptomatic MD. It is more diagnostic than CT or USG, which may not reliably differentiate MD from small bowel loops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meckel’s diverticulum is a true diverticulum located on the antimesenteric border of the ileum; its embryologic origin and imaging features are key to diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with facial puffiness and urine that appears as shown below for 3 days. She also reports multiple joint pains for the last 2 months. BP is 156/94 mmHg. Urinalysis shows RBC casts, 3+ proteinuria. C3 is low. What is the most likely diagnosis given the clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lupus nephritis

 

  • This 25-year-old woman presents with facial puffiness and dark-colored urine for 3 days, which raises concern for glomerular disease.
  •  She also has a 2-month history of multiple joint pains, suggestive of a systemic autoimmune process.
  •  Her blood pressure is elevated (156/94 mmHg), and urinalysis reveals RBC casts and 3+ proteinuria, indicating glomerulonephritis. 
  • The key laboratory finding of low complement C3 levels is characteristic of immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis.
  • All these features – young female, systemic symptoms (joint pain), nephritic urinary findings (RBC casts, proteinuria), and low complement – strongly point toward Lupus nephritis, which is a renal manifestation of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE).
  • Lupus nephritis frequently affects women of childbearing age and is associated with hypocomplementemia due to immune complex deposition in the glomeruli. 
  • The presence of proteinuria (which can reach nephrotic levels), hematuria, RBC casts, and hypertension is common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgA nephropathy

 

  • Typically presents with gross hematuria following an upper respiratory tract infection within 1–2 days (synpharyngitic).
  • It does not usually present with systemic symptoms like joint pain.
  • Complement levels are normal in IgA nephropathy, which helps differentiate it from lupus nephritis.
  • Also, IgA nephropathy is more common in young males than females.
  • Therefore, this does not fit the clinical picture of a woman with systemic symptoms and low C3.

 

Option B. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)

 

  • Typically occurs in children or young adults 1–3 weeks after a streptococcal infection (skin or throat).
  • It presents with hematuria, RBC casts, proteinuria, and low C3, but the patient usually does not have systemic symptoms like joint pain.
  • Also, the time gap between infection and symptoms is important (post-infectious).
  • This patient has no recent history of sore throat or skin infection, and the chronicity of joint pain suggests an autoimmune rather than post-infectious process.

 

Option D. Membranous nephropathy

 

  • Commonly presents with nephrotic syndrome (heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema), rather than nephritic features like RBC casts.
  • It is more common in older adults and is not associated with low complement levels or systemic symptoms like arthritis.
  • It may be associated with autoimmune diseases (like SLE), but in lupus, membranous pattern (class V) would not typically present with RBC casts and low C3.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young woman presenting with facial puffiness, dark-colored urine, joint pains, hypertension, RBC casts, proteinuria, and low C3 levels, Lupus nephritis must be strongly suspected as the underlying cause of glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with clear watery rhinorrhea following a road traffic accident 2 weeks ago. The fluid is positive for beta-2 transferrin on biochemical testing. Neurologic examination is otherwise normal. The physician suspects a CSF leak secondary to a skull base fracture. Which of the following investigations is the most appropriate for precise localization of the CSF fistula in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT cisternography

 

  • CT cisternography involves intrathecal injection of contrast followed by high-resolution CT scanning. 
  • It is considered the gold standard for localizing CSF leaks, especially in traumatic skull base fractures, because it can demonstrate even small bony defects and track contrast through the leak site.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High-resolution CT paranasal sinuses: Can detect bony defects but cannot confirm an active CSF leak or show contrast flow through the leak.

 

Option B. Plain CT brain: Useful to detect fractures or hematomas, but not sensitive for CSF fistula.

 

Option D. MRI brain with contrast: Excellent for soft tissue and meningoencephalocele detection but less specific for localizing active leaks compared to CT cisternography.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CT cisternography is the best imaging investigation for accurately localizing cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leaks, particularly after traumatic skull base injury.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child from a rural community is brought in with sudden high-grade fever, frequent bloody diarrhea, and altered mental status. The parents report that he has been progressively drowsy and unresponsive over the past few hours. On examination, the child is febrile, dehydrated, and shows signs of toxic encephalopathy with no evidence of meningitis. Stool culture later confirms Shigella dysenteriae infection. Which of the following best explains this child’s clinical deterioration?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ekiri syndrome

 

  • Ekiri syndrome is a rare but severe complication of shigellosis, particularly with Shigella dysenteriae, in which a child develops toxic encephalopathy.
  • This syndrome presents with altered mental status, convulsions, and coma in association with the dysentery, due to metabolic and neurotoxic effects rather than direct bacterial invasion of the CNS.
  • It is an important differential in children with Shigella infection and sudden neurological deterioration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reye syndrome: This is associated with aspirin use in viral illnesses, typically presenting with hepatic dysfunction and encephalopathy, not bloody diarrhea. Viral infection → aspirin → encephalopathy 

 

Option C. Hemolytic uremic syndrome: Classically associated with enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC), presenting with acute renal failure, hemolysis, and thrombocytopenia, rather than encephalopathy.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: It is autoimmune vasculitis. Characterized by prolonged fever, mucocutaneous inflammation, and coronary involvement, unrelated to Shigella or toxic encephalopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ekiri syndrome is a toxic encephalopathy seen as a metabolic complication of shigellosis, classically presenting in children with sudden altered sensorium and severe dysentery.

questions.text: A 15-month-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic because he has not developed any teeth yet. He was born at term with normal birth weight. His growth and development are otherwise normal for age. Physical examination reveals no dysmorphic features. His mother reports he has been taking all his recommended vitamins. What is the most likely cause of this child's delayed dentition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Idiopathic

 

  • No teeth eruption by 13 month is known as Delayed dentition. 
  • In otherwise healthy toddlers with normal growth and development, delayed tooth eruption is commonly a benign and idiopathic variation. 
  • No specific pathology is typically found when there are no associated dysmorphic features or systemic abnormalities.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: Congenital hypothyroidism can delay tooth eruption, but it usually also causes poor growth, hypotonia, coarse facies, and developmental delay—all absent in this case.

 

Option B. Down syndrome: Children with Down syndrome may show delayed dentition, but they typically present with facial dysmorphism, hypotonia, and other characteristic findings, none of which are noted here.

 

Option D. Rickets: Nutritional rickets can delay dental eruption but is usually accompanied by poor growth, bony deformities (e.g., craniotabes, bowed legs), and radiographic findings of metaphyseal cupping or fraying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delayed tooth eruption in a developmentally normal, healthy child with no dysmorphic features or systemic signs is most often idiopathic and does not require intervention.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male visits the clinic for progressive enlargement of his hands and feet over several years, along with changes in facial features including a protruding lower jaw. On examination, he has coarse facial features, enlarged hands, and increased shoe size. Which of the following genes is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PIT1

 

  • This clinical picture describes acromegaly — progressive growth of hands, feet, and jaw due to excess growth hormone, usually from a pituitary adenoma (somatotroph adenoma). 
  • The PIT1 gene (also known as POU1F1) is a transcription factor essential for differentiation of pituitary cells, particularly somatotrophs that produce growth hormone. 
  • Mutations or dysregulation in pathways involving PIT1 can affect growth hormone secretion and pituitary function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SF1: Steroidogenic factor-1, involved in gonadal and adrenal development, not somatotroph differentiation.

 

Option B. GATA1: Regulates erythroid lineage (red blood cell precursors), unrelated to pituitary adenomas.

 

Option D. TPIT : It is associated with excessive secretion of ACTH, and development of Cushing syndrome and Nelson syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PIT1 (POU1F1) is a transcription factor involved in differentiation of pituitary somatotrophs, which secrete growth hormone; its dysfunction is implicated in disorders of growth hormone production.

questions.text: In a rural immunization outreach center, health personnel suspect that a batch of adsorbed vaccines (such as tetanus toxoid or hepatitis B) may have been exposed to freezing temperatures. Which of the following procedures should be conducted to evaluate if the vaccines have lost their potency due to freezing?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Shake test

 

  • Shake test is a field-based procedure employed to assess whether adsorbed vaccines (such as DPT, hepatitis B, or tetanus toxoid) have been damaged due to accidental freezing.
  • These vaccines contain aluminum-based adjuvants that sediment irreversibly after freezing. In the shake test, the suspected vial is shaken and compared with a control vial that has not been frozen. Shaking is done for 15 sec
  • If the sedimentation in the suspect vial is faster, the vaccine is considered compromised and unfit for use.
  • This test is particularly crucial in settings where maintaining the cold chain is challenging, especially in outreach or rural clinics where freezing can occur due to improper storage.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schick test: This is a diagnostic skin test that was historically used to detect susceptibility to diphtheria toxin, not to assess vaccine stability or freezing damage.

 

Option B. Quake test: This is not a recognized or validated medical test for any purpose, including evaluation of vaccines.

 

Option D. Habel test: Used specifically to assess the potency of the rabies vaccine, especially post-exposure prophylaxis. It has no role in identifying if a vaccine has been frozen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Shake test is the standard field method used to identify freezing damage in aluminum-adsorbed vaccines, such as DPT or hepatitis B, by detecting irreversible sedimentation changes post-freezing.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with recently diagnosed HER2-positive invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast is started on a chemotherapy regimen that includes a monoclonal antibody. A few months into therapy, she complains of progressive shortness of breath on exertion. Echocardiogram reveals a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 42%, down from her baseline of 60%. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trastuzumab

 

  • This patient's clinical picture is consistent with Trastuzumab-induced cardiotoxicity. 
  • Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody against HER2, used in HER2-positive breast cancer. 
  • One of its notable adverse effects is cardiomyopathy, leading to a decline in LVEF.
  • Unlike anthracycline-induced cardiotoxicity (which is dose-dependent and often irreversible), trastuzumab-induced cardiomyopathy is not dose-dependent and often reversible upon discontinuation of the drug.
  • Mechanism: Monoclonal antibody against HER2 receptor.
  • Toxicity: Cardiomyopathy, especially when used concurrently or sequentially with anthracyclines.
  • Mechanism of Cardiotoxicity: HER2 signaling is important for cardiomyocyte survival → blockade impairs myocardial repair mechanisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methotrexate:

 

  • Mechanism: Antimetabolite; inhibits dihydrofolate reductase.
  • Toxicity: Hepatotoxicity, mucositis, myelosuppression, and pulmonary fibrosis (rare).
  •  No significant cardiotoxicity.

 

Option B. Tamoxifen:

 

  • Mechanism: Selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM).
  • Toxicity: Risk of endometrial cancer, thromboembolism, menopausal symptoms.
  •  No direct cardiotoxic effects; in fact, it may have favorable effects on lipid profiles.

 

Option D. Cisplatin:

 

  • Mechanism: DNA cross-linking agent.
  • Toxicity: Nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity, neurotoxicity, and nausea/vomiting.
  • It is not classically associated with cardiomyopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody against HER2 used in HER2-positive breast cancer. 
  • It carries a risk of reversible cardiotoxicity, typically presenting as reduced ejection fraction or congestive heart failure, especially when used in combination with anthracyclines.
  •  Regular cardiac monitoring with echocardiography is essential during treatment.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the serologic diagnosis of acute Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection are correct? 

 

1. HBsAg is the earliest marker to appear in HBV infection.
2. IgG anti-HBc antibody is the most specific marker for acute infection.
3. HBeAg presence indicates high infectivity.
4. IgM anti-HBc is the best marker for diagnosing acute infection.
5. Core antigen is detectable in serum by standard serologic tests.
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) 1, 3 and 4 are correct

 

  • Statement 1. HBsAg is the earliest marker to appear in HBV infection: Correct. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) is indeed the earliest serologic marker to appear in acute HBV infection, even before symptoms arise.
  • Statement 3. HBeAg presence indicates high infectivity: Correct. HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen) is associated with high viral replication and infectivity. Its presence suggests that the patient is highly infectious.
  • Statement 4. IgM anti-HBc is the best marker for diagnosing acute infection. Correct. IgM anti-HBc (core antibody) is the best serologic marker for acute infection. It appears shortly after HBsAg and typically remains positive during the symptomatic phase.

 

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

  • Statement 2. IgG anti-HBc antibody is the most specific marker for acute infection. Incorrect. IgG anti-HBc indicates past exposure or chronic infection, not acute infection, and therefore is not the most specific marker for acute disease.
  • Statement 5. Core antigen is detectable in serum by standard serologic tests. Incorrect. HBcAg (core antigen) is found within the hepatocyte and is not detectable in serum by standard serologic tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IgM anti-HBc is the most specific serologic marker of acute hepatitis B infection, while HBsAg is the earliest detectable marker.
  •  HBcAg is not detectable in serum using routine tests.

choices.text: 2 Fc fragments and 1 Fab fragment
1 Fc fragment and 1 Fab fragment
2 Fab fragments and 1 Fc fragment
2 Fab fragments and 2 Fc fragments

questions.text: A laboratory researcher is analyzing immunoglobulin structure and treats purified IgG with papain. Following this digestion, which of the following fragments would she most likely recover?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 Fab fragments and 1 Fc fragment

 

  • Papain is a proteolytic enzyme that digests immunoglobulin G (IgG) above the hinge region. 
  • This digestion separates the antigen-binding portions (the two Fab fragments) from the constant region (the Fc fragment).
  • Each Fab fragment includes one entire light chain and part of the heavy chain, retaining its antigen-binding capacity, while the Fc fragment contains the remaining heavy-chain constant regions responsible for effector functions such as complement activation and Fc receptor binding.
  • Thus, papain treatment of IgG yields two Fab fragments and one Fc fragment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2 Fc fragments and 1 Fab fragment: Incorrect because there is only one Fc region in IgG; papain cannot generate two Fc fragments.

 

Option B. 1 Fc fragment and 1 Fab fragment: Incorrect because papain cleaves above the hinge to release two Fab fragments, not just one.

 

Option D. 2 Fab fragments and 2 Fc fragments: Incorrect because an IgG molecule has only one Fc region, so papain digestion cannot create two Fc fragments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Papain is a proteolytic enzyme that digests IgG to produce two Fab fragments and one Fc fragment, enabling separation of antigen-binding from effector functions.

questions.text: An older adult undergoing extended treatment for venous thromboembolism is prescribed an anticoagulant. The physician seeks an option that offers reliable dosing without the burden of frequent laboratory testing. Which of the following anticoagulants is most appropriate in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dalteparin

 

  • Dalteparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), used for long-term anticoagulation such as in deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism.
  •  LMWHs like dalteparin possess predictable pharmacokinetics and bioavailability, allowing for fixed dosing without the need for routine coagulation monitoring in most individuals. 
  • This makes it particularly convenient for outpatient use and long-term management of thrombotic conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unfractionated heparin: This requires frequent monitoring of activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) due to its variable pharmacokinetics and bioavailability. It is often used in inpatient settings where close monitoring is feasible.

 

Option B. Warfarin: As a vitamin K antagonist, warfarin has a narrow therapeutic index and numerous drug and dietary interactions, requiring regular monitoring of the International Normalized Ratio (INR) to ensure effective and safe anticoagulation.

 

Option D. Argatroban: This direct thrombin inhibitor is primarily indicated for patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). It necessitates aPTT monitoring and is mainly used in acute care hospital settings, not typically for long-term outpatient therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dalteparin, a low molecular weight heparin, is effective for long-term thromboprophylaxis and is advantageous in clinical settings where routine coagulation monitoring is impractical, due to its predictable dosing profile.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the ‘C wave’ of the jugular venous pulse (JVP) are correct? 

 

  1. It represents tricuspid valve bulging into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  2. It is caused by right atrial contraction.
  3. It indicates filling of the right atrium.
  4. It occurs due to passive emptying of the right atrium.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only a

 

  • The C wave reflects the bulging of the tricuspid valve back into the right atrium during isovolumetric contraction of the right ventricle.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement b. It is caused by right atrial contraction: Incorrect. Right atrial contraction produces the A wave, not the C wave.

 

Statement c. It indicates filling of the right atrium: Incorrect. The venous return fills up. Therefore, it shows the V wave.

 

Statement d. It occurs due to passive emptying of the right atrium: Incorrect. Passive emptying of the right atrium occurs during ventricular diastole, producing the Y descent, not the C wave.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

C wave reflects tricuspid valve bulging and passive right atrial filling during early ventricular systole.

questions.text: Identify the structure labelled by x in the following image of skeletal muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Titin 

 

  • The image depicts a sarcomere, the basic contractile unit of skeletal muscle, bordered by two Z-discs. 
  • Within this, we can see:
    • Actin (thin filaments) extending from the Z-discs toward the M-line.
    • Myosin (thick filaments) positioned centrally and overlapping with actin in the A-band.
    • The X-marked area spans from the Z-disc to the center of the sarcomere, tracing a filament that runs alongside actin and attaches to the thick myosin filament.
  • This is characteristic of Titin, a structural protein.

 

Titin:

 

  • Titin is a giant elastic protein, the largest known protein in the human body.
  • It spans half of the sarcomere, running from the Z-disc to the M-line.
  • It anchors the thick (myosin) filament to the Z-disc and maintains the central position of myosin within the sarcomere.
  • Titin also plays a major role in passive elasticity, sarcomere assembly, and length-dependent tension during muscle contraction and relaxation.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Actin:  Actin is a thin filament anchored at the Z-disc and does not extend to the M-line. It doesn’t connect to myosin filaments throughout the sarcomere like titin does.

 

Option B. Myosin: Myosin forms the central thick filaments located only in the A-band, from end to end of the thick filament. Myosin does not span from Z-disc to M-line, which is what the X-labeled structure does.

 

Option C. Desmin: Desmin is an intermediate filament protein. It is located outside the sarcomere, connecting adjacent Z-discs and aligning myofibrils. It plays a cytoskeletal role rather than being part of the sarcomere structure itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Titin is an elastic structural protein that spans from the Z-disc to the M-line in a sarcomere, stabilizing the thick myosin filaments and contributing to passive muscle elasticity.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman from Assam, India, presents with high-grade fever, chills, and rigors for the past 3 days. Peripheral blood smear and rapid antigen test confirm the diagnosis of Plasmodium vivax malaria. She is treated symptomatically and stabilized. The physician now plans to prescribe a drug to achieve radical cure and prevent relapse. She expresses concern about the duration of therapy due to her work schedule and difficulty in adhering to long-term medication. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacological agent to provide a single-dose radical cure in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tafenoquine

 

  • This patient has Plasmodium vivax malaria, which is known to cause relapses due to hypnozoites (dormant liver stage parasites).
  • The goal here is radical cure, which involves:
    • Clearing blood-stage parasites (causing current symptoms)
    • Eradicating liver-stage hypnozoites (to prevent relapse)
    • A newer 8-aminoquinoline antimalarial, structurally related to primaquine.
    • Active against liver hypnozoites of P. vivax and P. ovale.
    • Single oral dose achieves radical cure, improving compliance.
  • Important prerequisite: Must confirm normal G6PD levels, as it can cause hemolysis in G6PD-deficient individuals.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Artemether-lumefantrine:

 

  • Effective against blood-stage parasites (P. falciparum and P. vivax).
  • Does not eliminate hypnozoites, hence not suitable for radical cure.
  • Used in ACT regimens for falciparum malaria.

 

Option B. Primaquine:

 

  • Also an 8-aminoquinoline, active against hypnozoites.
  • Traditionally used for radical cure of P. vivax.
  • But requires a 14-day course, which can lead to poor adherence.
  • Also needs G6PD testing prior to initiation.

 

Option D. Chloroquine

 

  • Historically used for blood stages of P. vivax.
  • No activity against liver hypnozoites → not a radical cure
  • Additionally, in regions like Assam, chloroquine resistance is prevalent, making it less effective.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

  • Tafenoquine is the only option here that provides single-dose radical cure of P. vivax malaria.
  • Requires G6PD testing prior to use.
  • Improved adherence makes it ideal in patients with barriers to completing a 14-day regimen like primaquine.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is hospitalized for hospital-acquired pneumonia. Sputum cultures identify Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The medical team is evaluating antimicrobial options for coverage. Which of the following agents is not effective against Pseudomonas infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vancomycin

 

  • Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that acts by inhibiting cell wall synthesis. It is active mainly against Gram-positive organisms, including Staphylococcus aureus (including MRSA) and Enterococcus spp.
  • However, it has no activity against Gram-negative bacilli, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and is not used in pseudomonal infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tobramycin: An aminoglycoside with excellent activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Commonly used in combination with β-lactams or other agents for synergy.

 

Option B. Piperacillin-tazobactam: An extended-spectrum penicillin combined with a β-lactamase inhibitor. Highly active against Pseudomonas and used widely in hospital-acquired infections.

 

Option D. Rifampicin: Although not a first-line therapy, rifampicin can be used in combination regimens for biofilm-associated infections (e.g., prosthetic devices) involving Pseudomonas. However, it is not reliable as monotherapy due to rapid resistance development, but still has activity against the organism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vancomycin does not have activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and is not used for its treatment. It targets Gram-positive organisms only.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child from rural South America presents with fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and swelling around the right eye (Romaña sign). Blood smear reveals Trypanosoma cruzi trypomastigotes. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacologic treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Benznidazole

 

  • Benznidazole is an antiprotozoal agent used to treat Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis) caused by Trypanosoma cruzi. 
  • It generates reactive oxygen species that damage parasitic DNA and other macromolecules. 
  • It is typically used in the acute phase or early chronic phase of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suramin: Used for early-stage Trypanosoma brucei (African trypanosomiasis), not effective against T. cruzi.

 

Note - Melarsoprol is the DOC for late-stage African trypanosomiasis. 

 

Option C. Sodium stibogluconate: Used for leishmaniasis, not for Chagas disease.

 

Option D. Praziquantel: Effective against schistosomiasis and other flukes/tapeworms, not trypanosomiasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Benznidazole is the drug of choice for Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis), acting via the generation of toxic radicals that destroy T. cruzi parasites.

choices.text: Reassure her that laparo-hysteroscopy is normal & evaluate her for other causes of recurrent miscarriage
Proceed with hysteroscopic resection of uterine septum

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents with a history of three consecutive second-trimester miscarriages. She is evaluated with hysteroscopy and laparoscopy, which reveal the findings shown in the image. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Proceed with hysteroscopic resection of uterine septum

 

  • The hysteroscopic and laparoscopic images are diagnostic of a septate uterus, which is a congenital müllerian anomaly characterized by a fibrous or fibromuscular septum dividing the uterine cavity.
  •  A septate uterus is a common cause of recurrent pregnancy loss, especially in the second trimester, as seen in this case. 
  • The gold standard treatment is hysteroscopic septoplasty, which has excellent reproductive outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassure her that laparo-hysteroscopy is normal and evaluate for other causes of recurrent miscarriage: Incorrect. The patient has a clearly identified structural cause (septate uterus), which has a known association with miscarriages. Reassurance alone without correction is not appropriate.

 

Option C. Perform Strassman’s metroplasty: Incorrect. This surgery is indicated for a bicornuate uterus, not for a septate uterus. The two have different embryologic origins and management strategies.

 

Option D. Perform hysteroscopic resection of adhesions: Incorrect. Adhesiolysis is the treatment for Asherman’s syndrome (intrauterine adhesions), which presents with amenorrhea or hypomenorrhea, not with recurrent second-trimester losses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Septate uterus is a leading cause of recurrent second-trimester pregnancy loss.
  •  Hysteroscopic septum resection is the treatment of choice and significantly improves pregnancy outcomes.

questions.text: Match the column (Topic: Scores/Classification/criteria and their uses):
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-D, 2-A, 3-C, 4-B

 

  • 1-D. Milan criteria: Suitability for liver transplant in cirrhosis patients, where hepatoma should be single < 5 cm or up to 3 tumors each < 3 cm.
  • 2-A. Child-Pugh Score: Assesses liver disease severity; includes bilirubin, INR, ascites, encephalopathy. It guides surgical risk stratification in cirrhotic patients and decision-making for elective procedures.
  • 3-C. Forrest grade: Endoscopic appearance of peptic ulcer bleed and risk of rebleed.
  • 4-B. Rockall Score: Done after endoscopy to predict rebleed and mortality risk in UGIB. It incorporates age, shock, comorbidities, diagnosis, and endoscopic stigmata of recent hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Child Pugh and Milan criteria are applied in liver cirrhosis patients while Rockall and Forrest in UGI bleed.

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual recently married reports experiencing symptoms of low mood, anhedonia, and fatigue for several weeks. He also expresses a strong desire to stop smoking, as he is concerned about his health and future family planning. Which of the following pharmacological agents would be most appropriate to address both concerns?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bupropion

 

  • Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant that inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine, improving mood symptoms. 
  • It is also FDA-approved for smoking cessation, making it uniquely suitable for patients with comorbid depression and nicotine dependence. Its dual action makes it an ideal option for this patient’s needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agomelatin: A melatonergic antidepressant that improves circadian rhythm regulation and mood but has no role in smoking cessation.

 

Option C. Mirtazapine: An atypical antidepressant with sedative and appetite-stimulating effects. It does not aid in smoking cessation.

 

Option D. Varenicline: A partial agonist of nicotinic receptors, effective for smoking cessation, but it is not an antidepressant and does not treat depressive symptoms effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bupropion is the drug of choice in patients with both depression and nicotine dependence, due to its dual efficacy as an antidepressant and smoking cessation aid.

choices.text: The occiput posterior position is frequently associated with a gynecoid pelvis
The patient is best described as having an arrest of descent
The occiput is at the pelvic inlet

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida at 41 weeks gestation has been pushing for the past 3 hours with no change in fetal station. On examination, the cervix is fully dilated and effaced. The fetal head is at 0 station and in a persistent occiput posterior (OP) position. Which of the following best describes this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The patient is best described as having an arrest of descent

 

  • An arrest of descent is diagnosed when there is no descent of the presenting part for ≥2 hours in multiparous women or ≥3 hours in nulliparous women (as in this case) during the second stage of labor. 
  • This patient, a primigravida, has been pushing for 3 hours with no descent despite full cervical dilation and fetal head at 0 station, fulfilling the criteria for arrest of descent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The occiput posterior position is frequently associated with a gynecoid pelvis: Incorrect. OP position is most commonly associated with an anthropoid pelvis, followed by android pelvis. It is least common with a gynecoid pelvis.

 

Option B. The labor progress is normal: Incorrect. A second stage exceeding 3 hours in a primigravida (without an epidural) is considered prolonged. This case fits that definition.

 

Option D. The occiput is at the pelvic inlet: Incorrect. A station of 0 means the fetal head is at the level of the ischial spines, which is the mid-pelvis, not the pelvic inlet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arrest of descent is diagnosed in the second stage of labor when there is no descent of the presenting part for ≥2–3 hours depending on parity and epidural status.
  •  Persistent occiput posterior position and certain pelvic types can predispose to prolonged second stage and arrest disorders.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with gradual-onset breathlessness, dry cough, and fatigue for the past 6 months. He worked in a granite polishing unit for 30 years. On examination, clubbing and fine bibasal inspiratory crepitations are noted. Chest X-ray is shown below. PFT shows a restrictive pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Silicosis

 

  • Chronic occupational exposure to granite/quartz/sandblasting = silica inhalation.
  • CXR → Multiple bilateral pulmonary calcified micronodules, predominantly in the upper and posterior zones. There is also a tendency toward coalescence of the nodules in both pulmonary superior lobes. DDs would be coal worker’s pneumoconiosis and silicosis but the occupational history is more in favour of silicosis. 
  • PFT: restrictive with ↓DLCO.
  • Increased TB risk due to macrophage dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis: Shows hilar lymphadenopathy but in younger patients with systemic features.

 

Option B. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: Lower lobe honeycombing; no nodules or calcified lymph nodes.

 

Option D. Coal workers’ pneumoconiosis: Seen in coal workers, more diffuse nodules without eggshell pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Silicosis presents with upper lobe nodular opacities and classic eggshell calcifications on CXR in workers exposed to stone or sand.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of uncontrolled hypertension despite lifestyle modification and calcium channel blocker therapy is being evaluated for further treatment options. His physician considers a medication that directly inhibits the first rate-limiting step of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, thereby blocking the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I. Which of the following agents best fits this mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Remikiren

 

  • Remikiren is a direct renin inhibitor.
  •  It binds to the active site of renin and prevents it from converting angiotensinogen to angiotensin I, the first and rate-limiting step in the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) cascade. 
  • By inhibiting renin directly, Remikiren reduces plasma angiotensin I and II levels, ultimately lowering aldosterone secretion and blood pressure. 
  • Although not widely marketed, it exemplifies the pharmacologic class of direct renin inhibitors similar to aliskiren.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Losartan: An angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) that blocks the action of angiotensin II at AT1 receptors but does not inhibit renin itself.

 

Option C. Enalapril: An angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, which blocks conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, a downstream step in the RAAS.

 

Option D. Spironolactone: A mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist that inhibits aldosterone action at its receptor, thus preventing sodium retention and potassium loss, but it has no effect on renin directly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Remikiren is a direct renin inhibitor that blocks the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I, representing an early blockade point in the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and providing an antihypertensive effect.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with a neck mass and occasional diarrhea. Her family history is notable for thyroid cancer and adrenal tumors. Physical examination reveals a firm thyroid nodule. Fine-needle aspiration suggests neurosecretory granules with amyloid stroma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for CEA. Which of the following is the most likely associated genetic abnormality?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RET proto-oncogene mutation

 

  • This 38-year-old woman with a thyroid nodule, positive calcitonin immunostaining, neurosecretory granules, and amyloid deposition on histology has classic features of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC).
  •  MTC arises from parafollicular (C) cells of the thyroid, which secrete calcitonin.
  • Key clues:
    • Neurosecretory granules: typical of neuroendocrine tumors
    • Amyloid stroma: amyloid in MTC is derived from altered calcitonin molecules and stains with Congo red
    • Positive calcitonin: highly characteristic of MTC
    • Family history of thyroid and adrenal tumors: suggests a multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2) syndrome.
  • MEN 2 (especially MEN 2A and MEN 2B) is associated with activating point mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, a receptor tyrosine kinase gene on chromosome 10.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. BRAF point mutation:

 

  • Seen in papillary thyroid carcinoma, not MTC.
  • BRAF mutations activate the MAP kinase pathway and are common in papillary carcinoma, which arises from follicular cells.

 

Option C. RAS mutation:

 

  • More frequently associated with follicular thyroid carcinoma.
  • RAS mutations affect cell proliferation pathways but are not implicated in medullary thyroid cancer.

 

Option D. TP53 loss of function:

 

  • Associated with anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, a highly aggressive undifferentiated cancer.
  • TP53 is a tumor suppressor gene but not linked to MTC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma originates from parafollicular C cells, secretes calcitonin, is associated with amyloid deposition on histology, and is linked to RET proto-oncogene mutations, particularly in patients with MEN 2 syndromes.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with painless, non-axial proptosis of the left eye. He has a history of head trauma 15 years ago. CT scan shows an expansile lesion in the frontal sinus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Frontal mucocele

 

  • A frontal mucocele is a slowly expanding, mucus-filled cyst that arises due to chronic obstruction of the frontal sinus outflow tract, often years after trauma, surgery, or chronic sinusitis. 
  • This case describes painless, non-axial proptosis in a patient with a remote history of head trauma—classic for a frontal sinus mucocele. 
  • Over time, mucoceles cause gradual bony remodeling, expansion into the orbit, and anterior displacement of the globe (non-axial proptosis). 
  • CT imaging typically shows a well-demarcated, expansile lesion in the frontal sinus, possibly eroding surrounding bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontal meningioma: May cause neurologic symptoms, seizures, or personality changes; proptosis is usually late, due to intracranial mass effect.

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA): Affects adolescent boys, not adults. Presents with recurrent epistaxis and nasal obstruction, not proptosis.

 

Option D. Orbital pseudotumor: Presents with acute, painful, red eye, restricted extraocular movements, and acute onset, unlike the chronic painless nature seen in mucoceles.

 

Educational Objective:


Frontal mucoceles, often delayed complications of sinus trauma or surgery, present with painless proptosis due to slow expansion and orbital extension.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): In a patient with unilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss, Weber’s test lateralizes to the normal ear.

 

Reason (R): In sensorineural hearing loss, the cochlear nerve is damaged, making bone-conducted sounds poorly perceived on the affected side.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A

 

  • In unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, Weber’s test lateralizes to the normal ear because the damaged cochlea/nerve cannot perceive bone-conducted sound well.
  • The reason is correct: sensorineural hearing loss reduces both air and bone conduction on the affected side due to cochlear/nerve damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In unilateral sensorineural deafness, the damaged cochlea/nerve cannot perceive bone-conducted sound, so Weber’s test shifts to the normal ear.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after developing sudden hydrophobia, agitation, and aerophobia. He passed away after a rapidly progressive encephalitic illness. An autopsy sample of his brain tissue is sent for laboratory confirmation of rabies. Which of the following is the most appropriate method to demonstrate classic histopathologic evidence of the virus in this specimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Negri bodies using Sellar stain

 

  • Negri bodies are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies seen in neurons, classically in the hippocampus (Ammon’s horn) and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. 
  • These inclusion bodies represent aggregates of rabies viral nucleocapsids and are pathognomonic for rabies infection. 
  • The Sellar stain is traditionally used to identify them on autopsy brain samples, making it a key confirmatory histopathologic method for rabies after death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Indirect immunofluorescence for anti-rabies antibodies: This technique detects antibodies in serum or CSF, and is more useful in antemortem testing. It is not the gold standard for brain histology at autopsy.

 

Option B. Tzanck smear: Tzanck smear detects multinucleated giant cells for herpesvirus infections (like HSV or VZV) and has no role in rabies diagnosis.

 

Option D. RT-PCR for rabies virus: RT-PCR can detect viral RNA from saliva, skin, or CSF, but in brain tissue the Negri body demonstration remains the traditional and classic hallmark.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Negri bodies detected on Sellar stain from brain tissue are the classic hallmark of rabies diagnosis in postmortem evaluation and must be recognized for boards.

questions.text: A preterm baby born at 32 weeks gestation is found to have cold extremities, delayed capillary refill, and respiratory distress. Rectal temperature is 35°C. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Initiate thermal care and rewarming

 

  • Temperature <36.5°C is mild - moderate hypothermia
  • Preterm babies are prone due to thin skin, large surface area
  • Must rewarm using radiant warmers, skin-to-skin, or warm blankets

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start IV antibiotics:

 

  • May be needed if sepsis is suspected, but hypothermia alone doesn’t mandate it
  • First step is to correct temperature

 

Option B. Begin phototherapy:

 

  • Used for neonatal jaundice, not for hypothermia

 

Option D. Give oxygen and observe: 

 

  • Oxygen may be supportive, but without correcting temperature, other treatments will fail

 

Educational Objective:

 

Always treat hypothermia first in a preterm neonate to prevent complications like hypoglycemia, apnea, or sepsis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with leg pain, difficulty in walking. His x-ray is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osteosarcoma

 

  • Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor in children and adolescents. It is characterized by the production of immature bone (osteoid) by malignant osteoblasts.
  • The peak incidence is in the second decade of life (10-20 years old), perfectly aligning with a 17-year-old boy.
  • Most frequently occurs in the metaphysis (the region where the shaft joins the end) of long bones, especially around the knee (distal femur, proximal tibia) and proximal humerus.
  • X-ray Features: Variable, but often includes: 
    • Mixed lytic and blastic (bone-forming) areas: Destructive bone changes along with areas of new, abnormal bone formation.
    • Periosteal reaction: Lifting of the periosteum (outer membrane of the bone) by the tumor, leading to characteristic patterns like Codman's triangle (a triangular elevation of the periosteum) or a sunburst/spiculated appearance (radiating spicules of bone perpendicular to the cortex).
    • Soft tissue mass: Extension of the tumor beyond the bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing's Sarcoma:

 

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a highly malignant primary bone tumor. It originates from primitive neuroectodermal cells.
  • It primarily affects children and adolescents, typically between 10 and 20 years of age. So, a 17-year-old boy fits the age range.
  • Often affects the diaphysis (shaft) of long bones (like the femur or tibia), but can also occur in flat bones (pelvis, scapula, ribs).
  • Classic findings include an "onion-skin" appearance (layers of periosteal new bone formation), lytic (bone-destroying) lesions, and sometimes a large soft tissue mass.
  • While the age fits, osteosarcoma is generally more common, and the X-ray findings described for osteosarcoma (e.g., sunburst or Codman's triangle) are different from the classic onion-skin of Ewing's.

 

Option B. Chondrosarcoma:

 

  • Chondrosarcoma is a malignant tumor of cartilage-forming cells.
  • It is predominantly a tumor of adulthood, most commonly seen in individuals over 40 years old. It is very rare in adolescents.
  • Often arises in the pelvis, femur, humerus, ribs, and scapula.
  • Characterized by lytic lesions with calcifications within the cartilage matrix, often described as "rings and arcs" or "popcorn" calcifications.
  • The patient's age (17 years old) makes chondrosarcoma highly improbable.

 

Option D. Giant Cell Tumor:

 

  • A Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) of Bone is typically a benign, but locally aggressive, tumor characterized by multinucleated giant cells. While benign, it has a significant risk of local recurrence and can, in rare cases, metastasize.
  • Most commonly affects young adults, typically between 20 and 40 years of age. It is rare before skeletal maturity (i.e., before the growth plates close), making it less likely in an 11-year-old and borderline for a 17-year-old if the physes are still open.
  • Almost exclusively occurs in the epiphysis (the end part of a long bone) of long bones, extending into the metaphysis, most commonly around the knee (distal femur, proximal tibia).
  • Classically appears as an eccentric, purely lytic (bone-destroying) lesion within the epiphysis and metaphysis, often with a "soap bubble" appearance due to internal trabeculations. It typically lacks periosteal reaction.
  • The patient's age is on the younger side for a GCT, and more importantly, GCT is typically a lytic lesion without the aggressive periosteal reactions (like sunburst or Codman's triangle) often seen in osteosarcoma. It can cause pain and difficulty walking.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor in children and adolescents. 
  • It is characterized by the production of immature bone (osteoid) by malignant osteoblasts.

choices.text: Repositioning the airway to slightly extended "sniffing" position
Suctioning the oropharynx to remove visible secretions
Providing nasopharyngeal stimulation to trigger spontaneous breathing
Increasing peak inspiratory pressure if chest rise is still inadequate

questions.text: A neonate was delivered via emergency cesarean section due to fetal distress. The baby had poor respiratory effort at birth with an APGAR score of 4 at 1 minute. Initial steps were performed, but the baby remained apneic with heart rate of 80 bpm. Positive pressure ventilation (PPV) was initiated, but despite proper bag-mask technique, there was minimal chest rise and the heart rate remained at 85 bpm after 30 seconds of ventilation. The resuscitation team leader called for ventilation corrective steps to be performed in sequence. Which of the following is not a component of the ventilation corrective steps (MRSOPA) sequence during neonatal resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Providing nasopharyngeal stimulation to trigger spontaneous breathing

 

  • While stimulation may be used in the initial steps of neonatal resuscitation, it is not part of the MRSOPA sequence, which is specifically designed to optimize ventilation when PPV is not effective.
  •  MRSOPA focuses on correcting mechanical ventilation issues, not triggering spontaneous respiration through stimulation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Repositioning the airway to slightly extended "sniffing" position: The first step in MRSOPA is to ensure the head is in the proper "sniffing" position to optimize airflow during ventilation. Improper head positioning can lead to ineffective chest rise.

 

Option B. Suctioning the oropharynx to remove visible secretions: This step addresses potential airway obstruction from secretions and is the second step in the MRSOPA mnemonic.

 

Option D. Increasing peak inspiratory pressure if chest rise is still inadequate: If chest rise remains inadequate after initial adjustments, increasing inspiratory pressure is an accepted part of the MRSOPA sequence to improve ventilation effectiveness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ventilation corrective steps in neonatal resuscitation (MRSOPA) do not include stimulation; instead, they focus on optimizing airway position, open mouth, clearing secretions, adjusting the mask seal, ventilation pressure to ensure effective chest rise and alternate airway.

choices.text: Indian Council of Medical Research

questions.text: An outreach healthcare worker is assessing the effectiveness of ongoing public health campaigns aimed at improving preventive health behaviors in rural and urban districts across a country with a diverse population. In determining the organizational source responsible for these health education efforts at the national level, which of the following institutions would be most directly involved in such initiatives?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Central Health Education Bureau

 

  • The Central Health Education Bureau is the principal institution in India under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare tasked with designing, implementing, and promoting health education and awareness programs. 
  • It supports initiatives related to preventive health, behavior change communication, and information dissemination across populations. 
  • The CHEB plays a vital role in developing health communication strategies, especially relevant in community-based outreach and national public health campaigns.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. National Health Library: While the National Health Library may assist by offering access to health literature, it does not oversee or initiate community-based health education programs.

 

Option B. Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR): The ICMR's role is focused on biomedical and clinical research. It generates evidence that can guide policy, but it does not directly implement health education initiatives.

 

Option D. Central Bureau of Health Intelligence (CBHI): The CBHI deals primarily with health data surveillance and management, not public awareness or education efforts. Its core function lies in health informatics and statistical reporting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Central Health Education Bureau (CHEB) is the primary national-level body responsible for planning and promoting health awareness and education across various levels of healthcare in India.

questions.text: Which facial muscle from the options given below is supplied by the nerve that arises from the marked area in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Risorius

 

  • Risorius is facial muscle which is supplied by the facial nerve which causes the elevation marked.
  • The image shows the floor of the fourth ventricle and the facial colliculus is marked.
  • The facial colliculus is present in the superior part of floor of 4th ventricle, which presents as a small elevation produced by the root of the facial nerve winding around the nucleus of the abducens nerve. 
  • Columns are formed by groups of facial neurons, which innervate individual muscles and give branches of the facial nerve. 
  • Dorsal neurons innervate muscles in the scalp and upper face and ventral neurons supply the lower facial musculature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral rectus: It is an extraocular muscle that arises from the lateral part of the common tendinous ring. It is innervated by the abducens nerve.

 

Option B. Superior oblique: It is an extraocular muscle that arises from the body of the sphenoid. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve.

 

Option D. Levator palpebrae superiors: It is an extraocular muscle that arises from the lesser wing of sphenoid. It is innervated by the oculomotor nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risorius is supplied by the facial nerve.

choices.text: The fetus is small for gestational age due to chronic uteroplacental insufficiency
The fetus has asymmetric intrauterine growth restriction and needs immediate delivery
The fetus is constitutionally small and likely to have a good prognosis
The fetus is at high risk for intrauterine fetal demise and requires corticosteroids

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2P1 woman presents at 38 weeks of gestation for a routine antenatal visit. Her fundal height measures 31 cm, and a growth ultrasound shows estimated fetal weight at the 7th percentile with normal umbilical artery Doppler and appropriate biophysical profile. There is no oligohydramnios. Her previous pregnancy was uncomplicated. She is a nonsmoker, normotensive, and has normal blood glucose. Which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation of the fetal growth findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The fetus is constitutionally small and likely to have a good prognosis

 

  • A fetus is classified as small for gestational age (SGA) when its estimated weight is below the 10th percentile for gestational age.
  • However, not all SGA fetuses are pathologically growth restricted. In this case, the fetus has:
    • An estimated weight at the 7th percentile
    • Normal Doppler studies
    • Normal biophysical profile
    • No oligohydramnios
    • No maternal risk factors
  • These findings are consistent with a constitutionally small fetus, which is a normal variant. 
  • These fetuses are typically healthy and do not require early delivery unless other abnormalities develop.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The fetus is small for gestational age due to chronic uteroplacental insufficiency: This would typically present with abnormal Doppler flow, oligohydramnios, or other maternal/fetal risk factors—none of which are seen here.

 

Option B. The fetus has asymmetric intrauterine growth restriction and needs immediate delivery: Asymmetrical IUGR is associated with abnormal Doppler studies, oligohydramnios, or fetal distress—none present in this case.

 

Option D. The fetus is at high risk for intrauterine fetal demise and requires corticosteroids: Corticosteroids are given in preterm gestations (<34 weeks) when preterm delivery is likely. This patient is at term and has reassuring fetal well-being.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SGA fetuses are defined as having an estimated fetal weight below the 10th percentile for gestational age.
  •  When Doppler flow, amniotic fluid, and maternal factors are normal, it is often due to constitutional smallness rather than pathology, and prognosis is generally favorable.

questions.text: A 51-year-old female patient presents with cough, low-grade fever, and hemoptysis. Investigations reveal a cavitary lesion in the right lung apex, which on biopsy shows caseous necrosis. The underlying pathophysiology is best explained by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction

 

  • This 42-year-old woman has caseous necrosis on biopsy of a cavitary lung lesion, which is classic for tuberculosis.
  •  Tuberculosis granulomas form because of a delayed-type (Type IV) hypersensitivity reaction, driven by T-helper 1 cells activating macrophages to wall off Mycobacterium tuberculosis. 
  • The activated macrophages organize into granulomas, and central necrosis develops as caseous debris due to cell-mediated immune response, not from immediate antibody-complement reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immune complex deposition: This is associated with type III hypersensitivity (e.g., post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis) and does not cause caseous necrosis.

 

Option C. Fibrinoid deposition: Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in immune-mediated vascular damage (e.g., polyarteritis nodosa), not in pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Ischemic coagulative necrosis: Ischemic necrosis causes coagulative patterns typical of infarction, not caseous necrosis which is pathognomonic for granulomatous infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caseous necrosis seen in tuberculosis results from a type IV hypersensitivity reaction (delayed-type), mediated by T-cells and macrophages.

questions.text: During health policy planning, a regional authority must assess various healthcare interventions not only based on outcomes but also in terms of financial profitability. Which type of analysis allows direct monetary comparison of both costs and outcomes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cost-benefit analysis

 

  • This type of analysis is the only method among the listed options that translates both costs and benefits into monetary units. 
  • It allows for quantification of financial advantage, helping policymakers determine whether the benefits of an intervention outweigh the costs from an economic perspective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Network analysis: This focuses on mapping and analyzing relationships and workflows within systems. It does not quantify financial gains or compare costs and outcomes monetarily.

 

Option C. Input-Output analysis: Primarily used in economic modeling, this technique assesses interdependencies between sectors. It is not used to evaluate cost-benefit in healthcare settings.

 

Option D. Cost-effective analysis: This compares the cost per unit of health outcome, such as cost per life-year saved. While highly useful, it does not convert outcomes into monetary terms, hence financial advantage cannot be directly quantified.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cost-benefit analysis uniquely expresses both healthcare costs and outcomes in monetary terms, allowing direct financial comparison to assess advantage.

choices.text: To evaluate lower lid laxity in suspected ectropion
To assess tear film break-up time

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the purpose of this clinical maneuver?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To evaluate lower lid laxity in suspected ectropion

 

  • The images show the snap back test, in which the examiner pulls the lower eyelid away from the globe and observes whether it “snaps back” to its normal position.
    • If the eyelid is slow to return or remains everted, this indicates laxity of the lower lid, a common feature of involutional (senile) ectropion.
    • Ectropion causes watering, irritation, conjunctival exposure, and secondary keratitis due to improper apposition of the punctum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To assess the Bell phenomenon: This involves asking the patient to close their eyes while observing upward eye movement, unrelated to eyelid laxity.

 

 

Option C. To assess tear film break-up time: This is done with fluorescein dye and a slit-lamp, not this lid-manipulation test.

 

 

Option D. To evaluate punctal stenosis: Punctal stenosis is tested by syringing the nasolacrimal duct, not by lid manipulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Snap back test is performed to evaluate lower eyelid laxity in suspected ectropion.

questions.text: A 48-year-old agricultural worker is brought to the emergency department after collapsing in the field. On arrival, he is found to have excessive salivation, lacrimation, profuse sweating, diarrhea, pinpoint pupils, muscle weakness, bradycardia with a pulse of 56/min, and hypotension of 80/60 mm Hg. Laboratory analysis shows a plasma cholinesterase level of 52 U/mL. Which of the following therapeutic agents would be most appropriate to specifically reverse the muscle weakness in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pralidoxime

 

  • Pralidoxime is an oxime agent that reactivates acetylcholinesterase by removing the phosphoryl group attached to its active site by an organophosphate compound (common in insecticides). 
  • This restores normal cholinesterase function and allows breakdown of acetylcholine at both muscarinic and nicotinic synapses, thereby reversing not only muscarinic symptoms but also the nicotinic receptor–mediated effects such as skeletal muscle weakness and paralysis. 
  • In this farmer with evidence of organophosphate poisoning (miosis, bradycardia, diarrhea, muscle weakness, reduced cholinesterase), pralidoxime is essential to reverse the neuromuscular blockade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atropine: Atropine is a competitive muscarinic antagonist that counteracts the muscarinic symptoms of organophosphate poisoning (bradycardia, diarrhea, bronchorrhea, secretions), but does not reverse nicotinic receptor–mediated muscle weakness, which is the major cause of respiratory failure in organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option B. Edrophonium: Edrophonium is a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used for diagnosis of myasthenia gravis. Administering it would worsen cholinergic excess in this patient, so it is contraindicated.

 

Option D. Neostigmine: Neostigmine is another cholinesterase inhibitor that would increase acetylcholine further, aggravating the patient’s cholinergic crisis and worsening muscle weakness. It has no role in treating organophosphate toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In organophosphate poisoning, pralidoxime should be given to regenerate acetylcholinesterase and thereby reverse both muscarinic and nicotinic effects (including muscle weakness and respiratory muscle paralysis), while atropine should be co-administered to relieve muscarinic symptoms.

questions.text:
Which of the following infections can cross the placenta and cause fetal anomalies? 

 

a. Toxoplasmosis

b. Hepatitis B

c. Rubella

d. CMV (Cytomegalovirus)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a, c, d

 

  • These are part of the TORCH group of infections (Toxoplasma, Others, Rubella, CMV, Herpes), known for their ability to cross the placenta and cause congenital infections.

 

Statement a. Toxoplasmosis: Especially dangerous in 1st trimester → hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications.

 

Statement c. Rubella: Especially teratogenic in the first 10 weeks → causes congenital rubella syndrome: PDA, cataract, sensorineural deafness.

 

Statement d. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Most common congenital viral infection → microcephaly, periventricular calcifications, SN hearing loss.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement b. Hepatitis B:  Incorrect. Transmitted perinatally, not transplacentally. Vertical transmission occurs during delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Toxoplasmosis, Rubella, and CMV can cross the placenta. 
  • Hepatitis B is perinatally transmitted, not transplacentally.

questions.text:
A renal pathologist is reviewing light microscopy slides of kidney tissue from a patient with early acute tubular injury. Which of the following statements best characterizes the expected microscopic findings, and which statements are incorrect with regard to describing these changes? 

 

  1. Tubular epithelial cells show increased eosinophilic staining due to protein denaturation.
  2. There is decreased basophilic staining caused by a reduction in cytoplasmic RNA content.
  3. Plasma membranes of tubular cells appear rounded with blebbing and loss of apical cilia.
  4. Tubular basement membranes are disrupted with complete loss of tubular framework.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Statement 4 is incorrect

 

  • Tubular basement membranes are disrupted with complete loss of tubular framework is incorrect. 
  • In early acute tubular necrosis, the basement membrane is typically preserved, allowing regeneration.

 

Correct Statements:

 

  • Statement 1. Tubular epithelial cells show increased eosinophilic staining due to protein denaturation. Correct. Injured cells accumulate denatured proteins and lose RNA, leading to more eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  • Statement 2. There is decreased basophilic staining caused by a reduction in cytoplasmic RNA content. Correct. Loss of RNA decreases basophilia, matching the described feature.
  • Statement 3. Plasma membranes of tubular cells appear rounded with blebbing and loss of apical cilia: Correct and classically seen in acute tubular injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute tubular injury, light microscopy shows tubular epithelial cells with increased eosinophilic staining, decreased basophilia, membrane blebbing, preserved basement membranes, and nuclei showing mild pyknosis rather than total loss.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with refractory asthma and thick brown sputum. She has no fever. Total IgE is 2200 IU/mL, absolute eosinophil count is 1200/mm³. CXR is shown below. What is the best next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Do Aspergillus skin test

 

  • This clinical scenario is highly suggestive of Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA).
  • The ISHAM 2013 diagnostic criteria is as follows:

 

 

  • Since the patient has not yet undergone confirmatory testing for Aspergillus sensitization, the best next step is to perform the Aspergillus skin test (or specific IgE if skin testing is unavailable).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start high-dose inhaled corticosteroids: Not sufficient for ABPA, which requires systemic therapy. Inhaled corticosteroids may help asthma but do not treat ABPA.

 

Option B. Initiate oral corticosteroids and itraconazole: These are used to treat ABPA but making the diagnosis is the first step.

 

Option D. Add montelukast and levocetirizine: These are adjunctive treatments for asthma or allergic rhinitis and have no role in treating ABPA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected ABPA, Aspergillus sensitization testing (skin or specific IgE) is a mandatory diagnostic step according to ISHAM 2013 criteria. Treatment should follow confirmation of diagnosis, not precede it.

choices.text: A, B and D are correct
A, B, C, D are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the action potential are true?

 

  1. Action potentials are dependent on stimulus intensity and show graded responses.
  2. They are always depolarizing and self-propagate without change in amplitude.
  3. They can be summated if stimuli are strong enough.
  4. Action potentials have a refractory period and occur only after a threshold of ~15 mV depolarization from rest.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) B and D are correct

 

Statement B. They are always depolarizing and self-propagate without change in amplitude: Correct. Action potentials are depolarizing and self-propagating with constant amplitude.

 

Statement D. Action potentials have a refractory period and occur only after a threshold of ~15 mV depolarization from rest: Correct. Action potentials require a threshold depolarization (~15 mV) and exhibit a refractory period.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement A. Action potentials are dependent on stimulus intensity and show graded responses: Incorrect. Action potentials follow an all-or-none principle and are independent of stimulus intensity once threshold is crossed.

 

Statement C. They can be summated if stimuli are strong enough: Incorrect. Action potentials cannot be summated due to the presence of a refractory period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Action potentials are all-or-none, depolarizing events that self-propagate with constant amplitude, require a threshold, cannot be summated, and have a refractory period.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 34 weeks gestation presents with blood pressure of 160/110 mmHg, proteinuria (+++), headache, and visual blurring. On examination, she has brisk deep tendon reflexes. What is the most appropriate immediate step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer magnesium sulfate

 

  • This patient presents with signs of severe preeclampsia, a life-threatening hypertensive disorder of pregnancy.
  •  The key clinical features are: 
    • BP ≥160/110 mmHg: Meets the diagnostic threshold for severe preeclampsia.
    • Proteinuria +++: Indicates renal involvement (protein ≥300 mg/24 hours or ≥1+ on dipstick).
    • Neurological symptoms: Headache and visual disturbances (scotomata, blurred vision) are red flag signs indicating cerebral involvement and impending eclampsia.
    • Brisk DTRs: Suggest neuromuscular hyperexcitability, another marker of severe disease.
  • The most immediate risk here is seizure, which would categorize her condition as eclampsia. Therefore, seizure prophylaxis is the priority, and magnesium sulfate is the drug of choice.
  • Magnesium sulfate is started intravenously (Pritchard or Zuspan regimen) to prevent seizures in women with severe preeclampsia. It also provides some neuroprotection to the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer labetalol: Antihypertensives like labetalol or hydralazine are important but secondary here. Lowering BP reduces the risk of stroke, but in a patient with severe symptoms, seizure prophylaxis takes precedence.

 

Option B. Deliver the baby immediately: While delivery is the definitive treatment of preeclampsia, it should only be done after maternal stabilization (i.e., giving MgSO₄ and controlling BP). Abrupt delivery before stabilizing increases maternal and fetal risk.

 

Option D. Perform fundus examination: Not an emergency step. It's useful for assessing chronic hypertensive changes but is not a priority when there is active severe preeclampsia with CNS symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe preeclampsia, magnesium sulfate should be administered immediately to prevent seizures.

questions.text: What is the usual amount of transient fluid loss/insensible fluid loss per day in an average adult?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 500–600 mL

 

  • Insensible fluid loss refers to the continuous loss of fluid that is not easily measured, such as:
    • Evaporation from the skin (not sweat)
    • Water vapor lost through respiration
  • On average, adults lose about 500–600 mL/day via these insensible routes:
    • ~300 mL from lungs (exhaled air)
    • ~300 mL from skin (evaporation, not including sweat)
  • These losses are important to account for when calculating daily maintenance fluid requirements, especially in hospitalized or fasting patients, as they are not replaced through oral intake.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Insensible losses of 500–600 mL/day should be included in daily IV fluid maintenance calculations

questions.text: A 17-year-old adolescent girl presents with increasing lower abdominal fullness and an adnexal mass on pelvic ultrasound. She is otherwise healthy, and has no significant past medical history. Her laboratory tests reveal markedly elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and elevated alpha-1 antitrypsin levels. Histopathology of the mass is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endodermal sinus tumor

 

  • This patient is a 17-year-old adolescent with an adnexal mass, elevated AFP, and elevated alpha-1 antitrypsin levels.
  •  Histopathology reveals classic Schiller–Duval bodies, which resemble glomeruli and are pathognomonic for endodermal sinus tumor (yolk sac tumor). 
  • These tumors are aggressive malignant germ cell tumors most commonly seen in teenagers and young adults.
  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is the classic tumor marker for yolk sac tumors, and elevated alpha-1 antitrypsin may also be seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile granulosa cell tumor: This would classically secrete estrogen, leading to precocious puberty or menstrual irregularities, and shows Call–Exner bodies rather than Schiller–Duval bodies.

 

Option B. Mature cystic teratoma: Also called dermoid cyst, this is usually benign and contains elements from all three germ layers, with no elevated AFP or Schiller–Duval bodies.

 

Option D. Sertoli–Leydig cell tumor: These are sex-cord stromal tumors that usually secrete androgens, presenting with virilization, and do not show Schiller–Duval bodies or elevated AFP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An adolescent with an ovarian mass, elevated AFP, and Schiller–Duval bodies is diagnosed with an endodermal sinus tumor (yolk sac tumor).

questions.text:
Which of the following characteristics differentiate organic from inorganic lead toxicity?

 

  1. Organic lead compounds are more likely to cause CNS toxicity.
  2. Inhalational absorption is more significant for inorganic lead.
  3. Organic lead toxicity usually results from ingestion of lead-based paints.
  4. Lead encephalopathy is a hallmark of inorganic lead exposure only.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only 1 and 2

 

  • Statement 1. Organic lead compounds are more likely to cause CNS toxicity:  Organic lead compounds (e.g., tetraethyl lead) are highly lipophilic, readily cross the blood–brain barrier, and concentrate in neural tissue, making CNS toxicity (neuropsychiatric changes, cognitive deficits, encephalopathy) their predominant manifestation.
  • Statement 2. Inhalational absorption is more significant for inorganic lead: Inorganic lead salts (e.g., lead acetate, lead oxide) are poorly lipid-soluble but readily aerosolized in smelting, battery manufacture, or lead-based paint work, so inhalational absorption becomes a major route of entry in occupational settings.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

  • Statement 3. Organic lead toxicity usually results from ingestion of lead-based paints: Organic lead toxicity does not usually result from ingestion of lead-based paints—that exposure involves inorganic lead paints. Organic lead arises primarily from industrial solvents or gasoline additives.
  • Statement 4. Lead encephalopathy is a hallmark of inorganic lead exposure only: Both organic and inorganic lead exposures can produce encephalopathy. While organic lead more readily causes CNS damage, severe inorganic lead poisoning (especially in children) also leads to lead encephalopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Differentiate organic vs. inorganic lead toxicity:
    • Organic lead → lipophilic compounds → primary CNS effects.
    • Inorganic lead → insoluble salts → inhalation in industry → hematologic, GI, renal effects.

questions.text: Match the column:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a-1, b-2, c-3, d-4

 

  • a-1: Tracheal bifurcation – T4/T5 (sternal angle)
  • b-2: Esophageal hiatus – T10
  • c-3: Aortic hiatus – T12
  • d-4: Central tendon level – T8 (site of IVC passage)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diaphragmatic openings occur at key thoracic levels: IVC (T8), esophagus (T10), aorta (T12).
  • Tracheal bifurcation (T4/T5) at sternal angle.

choices.text: Green tea is associated with an increased likelihood of diabetes
There is a protective association between green tea consumption and diabetes
The value is close to 1, so there is no effect
The data are inadequate to suggest any correlation

questions.text: A population-based follow-up study investigates the relationship between daily green tea consumption and the development of diabetes mellitus over 5 years. The cohort included both individuals who consumed green tea regularly and those who did not. At the end of the study, the relative risk (risk ratio) for developing diabetes among green tea consumers compared to non-consumers was calculated to be 0.84. Which of the following best describes the interpretation of this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) There is a protective association between green tea consumption and diabetes

 

  • A relative risk (risk ratio) less than 1 indicates a reduced risk of the outcome in the exposed group (here, green tea drinkers) compared to the unexposed group.
  •  A value of 0.84 specifically means that green tea consumers had a 16% lower risk of developing diabetes compared to non-consumers, suggesting a protective association.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Green tea is associated with an increased likelihood of diabetes: This is incorrect because a risk ratio greater than 1 indicates increased risk. In this case, the value is less than 1, indicating decreased risk.
