Option C. The value is close to 1, so there is no effect: While 0.84 is somewhat close to 1, it still indicates a notable 16% risk reduction. Statistical significance would also depend on the confidence interval, but based solely on RR = 0.84, there is an effect.

 

Option D. The data are inadequate to suggest any correlation: The question clearly states that a cohort study was performed and a risk ratio was calculated, meaning data were adequate for assessing association, even if not causality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A relative risk less than 1 in a cohort study suggests a protective association between an exposure (e.g., green tea) and an outcome (e.g., diabetes mellitus).

 

Interpretation of Relative Risk (RR):

questions.text: A patient with focal seizures resistant to first-line anti-epileptic medications is started on an adjunctive therapy that specifically targets excitatory neurotransmission by blocking AMPA receptors. Which of the following drugs has this mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perampanel

 

  • Perampanel is a non-competitive antagonist of the AMPA receptor, a subtype of the ionotropic glutamate receptor. 
  • By inhibiting AMPA-mediated excitatory neurotransmission, it reduces neuronal excitability and is effective in controlling partial-onset and generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Valproate: Broad-spectrum antiepileptic; increases GABA levels and inhibits sodium and T-type calcium channels, but does not affect AMPA receptors.

 

Option C. Lacosamide: Enhances slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels; does not target AMPA.

 

Option D. Pregabalin: Binds to the α2δ subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels, reducing neurotransmitter release; not an AMPA antagonist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perampanel is a selective AMPA receptor antagonist used in adjunctive treatment of seizures by reducing glutamatergic excitatory signaling.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding complications of Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) are true? 

 

  1. Hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia can occur due to overfeeding
  2. Refeeding syndrome is associated with hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypomagnesemia
  3. LFT derangement occurs in 25% cases of long-term TPN use
  4. Air embolism is the most common complication during line insertion
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Only A, B, and C

 

  • Statement A. Hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia can occur due to overfeeding: True. Overfeeding with glucose can lead to hyperglycemia, hepatic steatosis, hyperlipidemia, hyperuricemia and other metabolic issues.
  • Statement B. Refeeding syndrome is associated with hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypomagnesemia: True. Refeeding syndrome involves shifts in electrolytes such as phosphorus, magnesium, and calcium.
  • Statement C. LFT derangement occurs in 25% cases of long-term TPN use: True. Long-term use of parenteral nutrition is associated with derangement of liver function tests in at least 25% of patients. Fatty liver is a common complication.

 

False Statement:

 

Statement D. Air embolism is the most common complication during line insertion: False. The most common complication of line insertion is an inad vertent pneumothorax, which occurs in around 0.5–1% of cases, most commonly during insertion of subclavian lines. It is managed by insertion of a chest drain, which can be removed once the pneumothorax has resolved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TPN complications can be categorized by cause: nutrient-related, overfeeding, IV line issues, sepsis, and motility disturbances.

choices.text: It accurately measures the construct of interest
It yields identical results under repeated testing conditions
It correctly rules out the disease in unaffected individuals
It accurately detects the disease in affected individuals

questions.text: A clinical epidemiologist is evaluating the reliability performance of a new diagnostic assay intended to detect latent tuberculosis infection. Which of the following best describes this property of the test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It yields identical results under repeated testing conditions

 

  • This defines reliability, which refers to the consistency or reproducibility of a test. 
  • A reliable test gives the same result when repeated under identical conditions.
  •  Reliability is crucial for ensuring precision, even if the test may or may not be measuring the right variable (which pertains to validity).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It accurately measures the construct of interest: This defines validity/accuracy, not reliability. Validity assesses whether a test measures what it is supposed to measure, which is a separate concept from repeatability.

 

Option C. It correctly rules out the disease in unaffected individuals: This describes specificity, the ability of a test to correctly identify true negatives.

 

Option D. It accurately detects the disease in affected individuals: This refers to sensitivity, which measures how well a test identifies true positives.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Reliability refers to a diagnostic test’s ability to produce the same results repeatedly under the same conditions. It reflects precision, not necessarily accuracy.

choices.text: The presence of a latent phase of the virus within human tissues
Maintenance of the virus through transovarial passage in the mosquito vector
Continuous replication in nonhuman vertebrate hosts
Survival through unhygienic waste accumulation around human dwellings

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the mechanism by which dengue virus survives during inter-epidemic period?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Maintenance of the virus through transovarial passage in the mosquito vector

 

  • Dengue virus persists between epidemics through transovarial transmission in Aedes mosquitoes. 
  • This means the infected female mosquito transmits the virus directly to its progeny via its eggs, allowing the virus to survive in the mosquito population even when human infections are absent. 
  • When environmental conditions favor a new mosquito hatch (e.g., monsoon rains), infected mosquitoes can transmit dengue to humans again, initiating a new epidemic cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The presence of a latent phase of the virus within human tissues: Incorrect. Dengue virus does not establish latency in human tissues like herpesviruses do.

 

Option C. Continuous replication in nonhuman vertebrate hosts: Incorrect. While other arboviruses may have non-human reservoirs, dengue virus primarily cycles between humans and Aedes mosquitoes.

 

Option D. Survival through unhygienic waste accumulation around human dwellings: Incorrect. Poor sanitation increases Aedes breeding sites but does not preserve the virus itself in the environment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dengue virus survives between epidemics via transovarial transmission within Aedes mosquitoes, allowing infected mosquitoes to maintain the virus through their eggs until conditions favor a new outbreak.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents because of persistent scalp rash, excessive thirst with frequent urination, and prominent eye bulging. Physical examination reveals lytic lesions over the skull on palpation. A skull radiograph confirms punched-out lytic lesions. Biopsy of the lesion shows histiocytes positive for CD1a and Birbeck granules on electron microscopy. Which of the following best describes this child’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malignant proliferation of Langerhans cells

 

  • This is a classic presentation of Hand-Schüller-Christian disease, one of the Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) variants, described by the triad of:
    • Scalp rash (often seborrheic-like)
    • Lytic skull defects
    • Diabetes insipidus (due to posterior pituitary involvement)
    • Exophthalmos (from retro-orbital infiltration)
  • Histologically, these are characterized by malignant proliferation of Langerhans cells, which are dendritic antigen-presenting cells.
  • They stain positive for CD1a, Langerin (CD207), and show Birbeck granules (tennis racket–shaped structures) on electron microscopy.
  • In Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH), including Hand-Schüller-Christian disease, the BRAF V600E mutation is frequently found.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malignant proliferation of B lymphocytes: Typical of lymphomas, not LCH.

 

Option C. Reactive proliferation of neutrophils: Seen in infections or inflammation, not in histiocytosis.

 

Option D. Proliferation of melanocytes: Refers to conditions like melanoma or benign nevi, not Langerhans histiocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hand-Schüller-Christian disease is a form of Langerhans cell histiocytosis characterized by malignant proliferation of Langerhans cells and classic triad of lytic skull lesions, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos in children.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of acute onset upper abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting for the past 3 days. He denies any prior surgeries. On examination, he is febrile with tachycardia and guarding in the epigastric region. An erect chest X-ray was performed and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hollow viscus perforation

 

  • The erect chest X-ray reveals the presence of free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum), which is a classic radiologic sign of gastrointestinal perforation, most commonly due to duodenal or gastric ulcer perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric volvulus: May show large gastric shadow or abnormal gas pattern, but not free air under diaphragm.

 

Option C. Liver abscess: May present with right upper quadrant pain and fever, but X-ray is usually normal or may show elevated diaphragm or pleural effusion, not pneumoperitoneum.

 

Option D. Acute pancreatitis: Is associated with history of pain radiating to back, alcohol binge or gall stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum) is a classic radiologic sign of gastrointestinal perforation.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of small, pruritic wheals surrounded by large areas of erythema. He reports that the lesions appear within minutes of physical exertion and hot baths and resolve within an hour. He also complains of mild dizziness and flushing during these episodes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cholinergic urticaria

 

  • Cholinergic urticaria develops due to acetylcholine release from post-ganglionic cholinergic sweat glands.
  • It is precipitated by stimuli that induce sweating, such as exercise, heat exposure, or emotional stress.
  • The characteristic lesions are small pruritic wheals (1-2 mm in size) surrounded by large erythematous areas, present all over the body.

 

 

  • Systemic symptoms may include flushing, dizziness, nausea, and shortness of breath.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Solar urticaria: Solar urticaria is triggered by sunlight exposure and does not have a direct relation to sweating or heat-induced sweating.

 

Option B. Cold urticaria: Cold urticaria occurs after exposure to cold temperatures or objects, presenting with wheals at exposed sites.

 

Option D. Pressure urticaria: Pressure urticaria develops after sustained pressure on the skin, such as from tight clothing or heavy objects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cholinergic urticaria is a condition triggered by sweating due to exercise, heat, or emotional stress.
  •  It presents as small, pruritic wheals surrounded by erythema, often with systemic symptoms like flushing and dizziness. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed using the pilocarpine stimulation test, and first-line treatments include hydroxyzine and cetirizine.

choices.text: Complete paralysis of horizontal gaze to both sides
Impaired horizontal gaze to the ipsilateral side of the lesion
Impaired horizontal gaze to the contralateral side of the lesion
Intact horizontal and vertical gaze due to redundancy in cortical control

questions.text: A 51-year-old man presents with difficulty moving his eyes horizontally. Neurologic examination reveals impaired horizontal gaze toward one side, while vertical gaze remains intact. Brain imaging identifies a focal lesion in the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF). Which of the following findings is most consistent with this lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Impaired horizontal gaze to the ipsilateral side of the lesion

 

  • The paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) is a crucial brainstem structure responsible for coordinating horizontal (lateral) gaze.
  • It provides input to the ipsilateral abducens nucleus, which innervates the lateral rectus muscle and connects to the contralateral oculomotor nucleus (via the MLF) for medial rectus coordination.
  • A lesion in the PPRF disrupts this horizontal gaze pathway, leading to loss of conjugate horizontal gaze toward the side of the lesion, while vertical gaze remains intact (as it is mediated by midbrain structures).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complete paralysis of horizontal gaze to both sides: This would require bilateral PPRF or bilateral abducens nucleus involvement, which is rare and not supported by the unilateral lesion described.

 

Option C. Impaired horizontal gaze to the contralateral side of the lesion: The PPRF controls gaze to the ipsilateral side. A lesion here would not affect gaze to the contralateral direction.

 

Option D. Intact horizontal and vertical gaze due to redundancy in cortical control: While vertical gaze might be spared, horizontal gaze relies heavily on PPRF circuitry, and there is no true redundancy that would prevent symptoms from a focal PPRF lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A lesion in the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) leads to impaired horizontal gaze toward the side of the lesion, while vertical gaze remains preserved.

questions.text: A deceased young woman is brought to the forensic examination unit. Based on the external findings shown in the image, what is the most probable mechanism of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Throttling

 

  • The image demonstrates bruises and abrasions on the front and sides of the neck, with oval-shaped contusions consistent with pressure from fingers, along with clustered abrasions suggestive of fingernail marks. 
  • These findings are classical for throttling, which is a form of manual strangulation. 
  • In throttling, force is applied by human hands directly around the neck, compressing the airway and vasculature, leading to asphyxia.
  •  The presence of finger pad bruises and fingernail abrasions on the lateral and anterior neck regions supports this conclusion.
  • There are no features suggesting a ligature mark or any typical suspension features of hanging. Also, no specific evidence of mugging (i.e., blunt trauma without characteristic neck marks) is noted. 
  • Therefore, based on the described and pictured neck bruising, throttling is the most probable cause of death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mugging: Mugging is a blunt assault or attack that may cause injury but does not usually produce patterned bruises on the neck from finger pads or fingernails, which are specific to throttling. Therefore mugging is incorrect for the described findings.

 

Option C. Hanging: Hanging involves suspension of the body by a ligature around the neck, producing an oblique, upward-directed ligature mark classically. There is no mention or photograph of such ligature furrow or suspension point; therefore hanging is excluded.

 

Option D. Ligature strangulation: Ligature strangulation produces a horizontal ligature mark encircling the neck, often associated with patterned abrasions from the ligature material. Since there is no evidence of such ligature marks, this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Throttling is a form of manual strangulation that produces finger pad contusions and fingernail abrasions on the neck due to direct hand pressure, leading to asphyxial death.

choices.text: Community-wide administration of DEC tablets
Indoor insecticide spraying for vector suppression
Periodic antibiotic treatment targeting symbiotic bacteria
Excision of lymphatic nodules harboring parasites

questions.text: A high-burden tropical district implements a population-based intervention to reduce the incidence of lymphatic filariasis. Based on global guidelines, which of the following is the most effective method to halt disease transmission in such endemic areas?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Community-wide administration of DEC tablets

 

  • Lymphatic filariasis is caused by filarial parasites transmitted via mosquito bites.
  •  The most effective strategy to interrupt transmission in endemic areas is mass drug administration (MDA) of diethylcarbamazine (DEC) to the entire at-risk population.
  •  This reduces the reservoir of microfilariae in the blood and halts further spread by the mosquito vector.
  • MDA with DEC is simple, low-cost, and endorsed by the WHO as a principal strategy in the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (GPELF).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Indoor insecticide spraying for vector suppression: While vector control helps reduce transmission risk, it is not the primary method and is considered supplementary to MDA.

 

Option C. Periodic antibiotic treatment targeting symbiotic bacteria: Doxycycline targets Wolbachia (endosymbiont of filarial worms) and is beneficial in chronic management, but it's unsuitable for MDA due to safety issues in children and pregnant women.

 

Option D. Excision of lymphatic nodules harboring parasites: Surgical removal is not a feasible population-wide strategy, as the parasites reside in deep lymphatics and may not be surgically accessible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mass drug administration (MDA) using diethylcarbamazine (DEC) is the most effective method for interrupting transmission of lymphatic filariasis in endemic areas under Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (GPELF)..

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man presents with palpitations. On evaluation, no structural heart disease is found, and his ECG reveals frequent ventricular ectopics. Which of the following are recognized properties of ventricular cardiac muscle? 

 

  1. Automaticity
  2. Conductivity
  3. Excitability
  4. Contractility
questions.solution:
Ans. D) a, b, c, d

 

  • Ventricular cardiac muscle exhibits several key physiological properties that enable the heart to function effectively as a pump:
    • Automaticity (a): The ability to initiate its own impulse without external stimulation (mainly in specialized pacemaker cells, but under pathological conditions, even ventricular tissue may exhibit automaticity).
    • Conductivity (b): Ability to conduct electrical impulses through myocardial fibers.
    • Excitability (c): Capacity to respond to an electrical stimulus.
    • Contractility (d): Ability to contract forcefully in response to an electrical impulse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular cardiac muscle exhibits automaticity, conductivity, excitability, and contractility—enabling impulse generation, propagation, response, and contraction essential for cardiac pump function.

choices.text: Other specified feeding and eating disorder

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student presents with a 1-year history of recurrent episodes of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting. She vomits after almost every meal and uses laxatives twice weekly. Her BMI is 16.2 kg/m². She is extremely preoccupied with her weight and believes she is "obese" despite visible signs of emaciation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anorexia nervosa

 

  • Despite the prominent binge-purge behaviors that might initially suggest bulimia nervosa, the key diagnostic feature here is the patient's BMI of 16.2 kg/m², which indicates significantly low body weight. 
  • Binge eating and Purging behaviours can be seen in both Anorexia Nervosa & Bulimia Nervosa and the key differentiating feature is BMI.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Bulimia nervosa: Patients with bulimia nervosa are typically within normal weight range or may be overweight.


Option C. Binge-eating disorder: This involves binge eating without compensatory behaviors like purging, and patients are often obese or overweight


Option D. Other specified feeding and eating disorder: Used when full criteria for specific eating disorders are not met; this patient meets full criteria for anorexia nervosa

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The critical differentiating factor between anorexia nervosa binge-purge type and bulimia nervosa is body weight - if BMI is significantly low (< 18.5 kg/m²), the diagnosis is anorexia nervosa regardless of purging behaviors.

questions.text: Based on the image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe placental insufficiency in IUGR

 

  • The Doppler image shows absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF) in the umbilical artery, a hallmark of severe uteroplacental insufficiency.
  • Normally, there should be continuous forward flow during diastole.
  • In IUGR (especially early-onset, <32 weeks), progressive placental resistance leads to:
    • ↓ Diastolic flow.
    • Absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in late/severe cases → fetal hypoxia.
  • AEDF indicates advanced FGR and placental resistance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal fetal growth: Incorrect. This Doppler is abnormal; normal flow has forward end-diastolic flow.

 

Option B. Early-onset IUGR with preserved flow: Incorrect. Preserved flow means diastolic component is still present.

 

Option D. Fetal macrosomia: Incorrect. Macrosomic fetuses have normal or increased flow, not absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Absent end-diastolic flow on umbilical artery Doppler indicates severe placental insufficiency in IUGR and is a sign of fetal compromise.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after intentional ingestion of a toxic substance. Gastric lavage is performed, and on adding silver nitrate to the gastric aspirate, the sample turns black. Which of the following poisons is most consistent with this observed chemical reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aluminium phosphide

 

  • Aluminium phosphide is a highly toxic compound often used as a fumigant pesticide, and it liberates phosphine gas on contact with water or gastric acid. 
  • During poisoning cases, if gastric lavage is collected and reacted with silver nitrate solution, the sample turns black due to the formation of silver phosphide.
  •  This color change is a classic bedside chemical test used to suggest the presence of aluminium phosphide in a suspected poisoning.
  • The toxic mechanism involves phosphine gas production, which inhibits cytochrome oxidase and leads to severe cellular hypoxia and multiorgan failure. 
  • The described black color on silver nitrate addition is a well-established toxicological clue pointing toward aluminium phosphide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mercury: Mercury poisoning does not produce a black color with silver nitrate on gastric lavage. Mercury toxicity generally results in gastrointestinal corrosion, renal damage, and neurotoxicity, but no classic test involving black color change in gastric aspirate with silver nitrate is described, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Barium: Barium poisoning usually causes hypokalemia and muscle paralysis. Barium sulfate is radiopaque, but barium compounds do not react with silver nitrate to produce a black color in gastric aspirate, so this is incorrect.

 

Option C. Lead: Lead poisoning is classically associated with Burton's lines on gums and anemia with basophilic stippling. There is no described black color change with silver nitrate on gastric aspirate in lead poisoning cases. Therefore, lead is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In aluminium phosphide poisoning, the gastric aspirate turns black on reaction with silver nitrate due to the formation of silver phosphide, which is a key toxicological diagnostic clue.

choices.text: The fungus that shows acute-angle branching with septate hyphae
The yeast that produces germ tubes in serum
The encapsulated fungus seen with India ink in CSF
The mold that causes angioinvasion and thrives in high glucose, low pH environments

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes presents to the emergency department with altered mental status and periorbital swelling. His wife reports he recently recovered from a mild COVID-19 infection treated with steroids. On examination, there is proptosis of the right eye and a black crusted lesion on the nasal septum. Which of the following fungi is the most likely culprit?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The mold that causes angioinvasion and thrives in high glucose, low pH environments

 

  • The patient's diabetes, recent steroid use, black nasal crust, and orbital signs are classic for rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis.
  • Microscopy shows broad, aseptate, ribbon-like hyphae with right-angle branching → characteristic of Mucor species.
  • Mucor thrives in acidic, glucose-rich environments like in diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. The fungus that shows acute-angle branching with septate hyphae: Has acute-angle branching, septate hyphae; common in lungs of neutropenic patients, not with black eschar in sinuses suggestis infection with aspergillus species. 

 

Option B. The yeast that produces germ tubes in serum: A yeast; forms germ tubes but doesn't invade nasal/orbital tissue in this way., suggests infection with Candida albicans. 

 

Option C. The encapsulated fungus seen with India ink in CSF: Causes meningitis, especially in HIV patients; shows encapsulated yeast in CSF (India ink), not filamentous hyphae in nasal tissue. Suggests infection with cryptococcus neoformans. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Mucormycosis is an angioinvasive fungal infection caused by Mucorales species, commonly seen in diabetics and immunosuppressed patients. 
  • It presents with rapidly progressive rhino-orbital-cerebral involvement, and microscopy shows broad, aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are incorrect regarding hereditary spherocytosis? 

 

  1. It most commonly results from an autosomal dominant defect involving ankyrin protein.
  2. The bone marrow is hypocellular with decreased reticulocyte count.
  3. Peripheral smear demonstrates spherocytes lacking central pallor.
  4. The investigation of choice is eosin-5’-maleimide (EMA) flow cytometry.
  5. Elective splenectomy is performed after administering suitable vaccines.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only statement 2 

 

Statement 2. The bone marrow is hypocellular with decreased reticulocyte count: Incorrect. The bone marrow is hypercellular with increased reticulocytes in response to chronic hemolysis, not hypocellular with low reticulocytes.

 

Correct statements:

 

Statement 1. It most commonly results from an autosomal dominant defect involving ankyrin protein: Correct. Hereditary spherocytosis is most commonly autosomal dominant due to ankyrin protein mutation, which disrupts red cell membrane stability.

 

Statement 3. Peripheral smear demonstrates spherocytes lacking central pallor: Correct. Peripheral smear shows spherocytes that lack central pallor because of membrane loss and reduced surface area-to-volume ratio.

 

 

Statement 4. The investigation of choice is eosin-5’-maleimide (EMA) flow cytometry: Correct. The investigation of choice is EMA (eosin-5’-maleimide) flow cytometry, which detects red cell membrane protein defects.

 

Statement 5. Elective splenectomy is performed after administering suitable vaccines: Correct. Elective splenectomy is done to control hemolysis, but only after giving suitable vaccines against encapsulated organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hereditary spherocytosis is an autosomal dominant pediatric hemolytic anemia caused by ankyrin defects.
  •  Bone marrow shows hypercellularity with reticulocytosis, the best diagnostic test is EMA flow cytometry, and splenectomy after vaccination is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Match the Following:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1, E-5

 

A. T cells → CD1 to CD8 (4): T cells classically express a range of CD antigens from CD1 to CD8. CD3 is considered a pan–T cell marker, but CD1 to CD8 collectively represent thymocyte maturation subsets, so the group “CD1 to CD8” is correct for T cells.

 

B. B cells → CD19 to CD23 (3): B lymphocytes characteristically express CD19, CD20, CD21, CD22, and CD23, making “CD19 to CD23” correct for B cell lineage identification.

 

C. NK cells → CD16, CD56, CD94 (2): Natural killer (NK) cells classically express CD16 and CD56 as the most recognized markers, and CD94 is another NK-related receptor; hence “CD16, CD56, CD94” is correct for NK cells.

 

D. Memory T cell → CD45RO (1): Memory T cells express CD45RO, which is the isoform of CD45 present on previously activated T cells that have differentiated into memory T cells.

 

E. Leukocyte common antigen → CD45 (5): CD45 is referred to as leukocyte common antigen, present on essentially all leukocytes and used as a pan-leukocyte marker.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • T cells (CD1–CD8).
  • B cells (CD19–CD23).
  • NK cells (CD16, CD56, CD94).
  • Memory T cells (CD45RO).
  • Leukocyte common antigen (CD45).

questions.text: A DEXA scan done for a 62-year-old post-menopausal women shows a T score of -2.8. What does this infer?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osteoporosis; needs pharmacologic therapy

 

  • Bone mineral density (BMD) is interpreted using T-scores:
    • T > –1 → Normal
    • T –1 to –2.5 → Osteopenia
    • T ≤ –2.5 → Osteoporosis
    • A T-score of –2.8 qualifies as osteoporosis.
  • Postmenopausal women with osteoporosis need:
    • Calcium + Vitamin D
    • Bisphosphonates or other antiresorptives
    • Lifestyle modifications (exercise, avoid smoking/alcohol)

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Normal bone density: Incorrect. T-score must be > –1.

 

Option B. Osteopenia; lifestyle change only: Incorrect. This is beyond osteopenia.

 

Option D. Menopausal transition; monitor in 2 years:  Incorrect. Delay in therapy increases fracture risk. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A T-score ≤ –2.5 on DEXA scan confirms osteoporosis, especially in postmenopausal women, and requires pharmacologic treatment to prevent fractures

questions.text: A biochemistry laboratory is conducting qualitative analysis of amino acids. One particular test produces a red-colored complex upon heating with mercuric nitrate in nitric acid. This positive reaction specifically identifies the presence of an amino acid containing a phenol group. Which of the following amino acids is detected by this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tyrosine

 

  • Tyrosine is the only standard amino acid that contains a phenol group in its side chain (–OH group attached to an aromatic ring).
  •  Millon’s test specifically detects this phenolic group.
  •  Upon reaction with mercuric nitrate in nitric acid, and subsequent heating, it gives a red color, indicating a positive result for tyrosine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tryptophan: Contains an indole ring, not a phenol group, and does not give a positive Millon’s test.

 

Option C. Histidine: Contains an imidazole group; Millon’s test is not reactive with imidazole rings.

 

Option D. Phenylalanine: Has a benzyl side chain, but lacks a hydroxyl group on the ring and therefore does not respond to Millon’s test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Millon’s test is a qualitative test that detects tyrosine due to its phenol group, producing a red-colored complex when reacted with mercuric nitrate in nitric acid and heated.

questions.text: A decomposed body is found in a room. The face shows postmortem purging, but a ligature mark on the neck is still visible. What could be the possible cause of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hanging

 

  • In hanging the ligature mark is dry, hard, parchmentized, and avascular. Hence, this site of ligature mark is not easily obliterated due to decomposition.
  • Postmortem purging (fluid and blood from orifices) is consistent with the advanced decomposition.
  •  Postmortem purge refers to the leakage of blood-tinged fluid from the nose, mouth, or other orifices after death, particularly during decomposition.
  • It's caused by gas buildup and pressure from putrefaction forcing fluids from the lungs, stomach, or upper airways out through orifices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Manual strangulation/throttling: When human fingers, palms or hands are used to compress the neck, so no ligature mark.

 

Option B. Ligature strangulation: Mark is soft, not dry and hard, hence it will fade in decomposed body

 

Option D. Mugging: Holding the neck of victim in the bend of the elbow or knee of the assailant. It does not have any ligature mark.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hanging, the ligature mark may remain visible even in decomposed bodies due to skin drying, making it an important postmortem sign that can persist despite purging.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy diagnosed with ADHD has a strong family history of substance abuse, and his parents are concerned about addiction risk. Which medication would be the most appropriate first-line choice for managing his ADHD symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atomoxetine

 

  • Atomoxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor and the preferred choice for ADHD treatment in children with high vulnerability for addiction. 
  • Unlike stimulant medications (methylphenidate and amphetamines), atomoxetine is a non-stimulant with no abuse potential, making it ideal for patients with personal or family history of substance abuse. 
  • It is FDA-approved for ADHD treatment in children 6 years and older.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Methylphenidate: Although considered first-line for ADHD in general, it is a stimulant with abuse potential and would not be the best choice in a child with high addiction vulnerability

 

Option C. Dextroamphetamine: A potent stimulant with significant abuse potential, making it inappropriate for children at high risk for substance abuse

 

Option D. Clonidine: While it is a non-stimulant option with no abuse potential, it is generally considered second-line to atomoxetine for ADHD treatment.

 

Educational objective: 

 

  • In children with ADHD who have personal or family history of substance abuse, non-stimulant medications like atomoxetine should be prioritized over stimulants to minimize addiction risk.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman from Jharkhand presents with 3 weeks of low-grade fever, dry cough, and weight loss. She also has irregular menses. CXR is shown below. Mantoux is negative. BAL fluid CB-NAAT is negative and CD4 count is elevated. Endometrial biopsy is positive for granulomas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sarcoidosis

 

  • Young female + hilar LAN + negative TB tests + elevated CD4 in BAL fluid + granulomas in tissue samples = sarcoidosis.
  • Negative Mantoux & negative BAL CB-NAAT excludes TB. 
  • Reticulonodular infiltrates and hilar lymphadenopathy → stage II sarcoidosis.
  • BAL CD4/CD8 ratio of > 2.5 is suggestive of sarcoidosis. 
  • Endometrial symptoms may mimic TB. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculosis: Common in India but Mantoux/CB-NAAT negative. 

 

Option C. Endometrial carcinoma: Systemic symptoms less likely; biopsy would show neoplasia.

 

Option D. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis: No exposure history; HRCT not consistent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with systemic symptoms, high ACE, and TB exclusion suggests sarcoidosis in Indian females.

choices.text: Ectopic thyroid in anterior sternocleidomastoid muscle

questions.text: Which of these represents lateral aberrant thyroid?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Level VI cervical node

 

  • Level VI cervical nodes are located in the central compartment of the neck, which includes the pretracheal, paratracheal, and prelaryngeal (Delphian) nodes. 
  • This area is in close proximity to the thyroid gland, and historically, the term "lateral aberrant thyroid" has been used to describe thyroid tissue that is found in unusual locations, including cervical lymph nodes.
  •  It was thought to be ectopic thyroid tissue but is often metastatic thyroid carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Level V cervical node:  Level V cervical nodes refers to the lymph nodes located in the posterior triangle of the neck, bounded by the sternocleidomastoid muscle, the trapezius, and the clavicle. 

 

Option C. Ectopic thyroid in anterior sternocleidomastoid muscle: Ectopic thyroid tissue is thyroid tissue found outside of its normal location. While it can be located anywhere along the path of the thyroglossal duct (which runs from the base of the tongue to the thyroid gland's final position in the neck), its presence within the anterior sternocleidomastoid muscle is not typically referred to as lateral aberrant thyroid.

 

Option D. Mediastinal node: While thyroid tissue or metastatic thyroid carcinoma can be found in the mediastinal nodes, this is not the conventional description for lateral aberrant thyroid.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

“Lateral aberrant thyroid" historically referred to ectopic or metastatic thyroid tissue found in the level VI cervical nodes, although it is now understood that these are typically metastatic thyroid carcinomas rather than benign ectopic thyroid tissue.

questions.text: A 28-year-old migrant worker is evaluated for chronic diarrhea and mild weight loss. Stool microscopy is given below. Which of the following helminths most likely shows this reproductive pattern?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

  • Strongyloides stercoralis is ovo-viviparous, meaning the eggs hatch into rhabditiform larvae within the female worm before being released, so the larvae are immediately infective in the intestine. 
  • This mechanism helps Strongyloides sustain autoinfection and chronic infection in humans. The characteristic finding on stool microscopy is the detection of rhabditiform larvae, not eggs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascaris lumbricoides: This organism is oviparous, releasing eggs in feces, which then develop in soil.

 

 

Option B. Enterobius vermicularis: Also oviparous, releasing eggs that are deposited in the perianal area.

 

 

Option D. Trichinella spiralis: Viviparous (larvae born alive), but does not produce ova or eggs that hatch within the worm; the larvae directly penetrate intestinal mucosa to encyst in muscle.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Strongyloides stercoralis is an ovo-viviparous parasite that releases larvae rather than eggs, facilitating persistent intestinal autoinfection.

questions.text: A 1 year 2 months old 10 kg child with severe dehydration needs rehydration as per WHO plan C. What volume of fluid should be given over half hour?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 300 mL

 

  • In severe dehydration, WHO Plan C guides rapid fluid replacement.
  • In severe dehydration we use ringer lactate solution + 5% dextrose @100 mL/kg
  • For children ≥12 months, give 30 mL/kg in first 30 minutes, followed by 70 mL/kg over the next 2.5 hours to prevent shock and restore perfusion effectively.
  • Quick Summary of Plan C:
    • For infants <12 months: 30 mL/kg in 1 hour, then 70 mL/kg in 5 hours.
    • For children ≥12 months: 30 mL/kg in 30 min, then 70 mL/kg in 2.5 hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In severe dehydration, WHO Plan C guides rapid fluid replacement.
  • For children ≥12 months, give 30 mL/kg in first 30 minutes, followed by 70 mL/kg over the next 2.5 hours to prevent shock and restore perfusion effectively.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents with non-healing ulcers on his right foot and persistent rest pain in the same limb. On examination, pedal pulses are weak. An ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) is measured and found to be 0.3. Arterial Doppler reveals a blockage of the superficial femoral artery. What is the preferred management of this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Revascularization

 

  • This patient presents with critical limb threating ischemia, indicated by:
    • Rest pain and non-healing ulcers
    • ABPI of 0.3, which is severely reduced (normal ≥0.9)
    • Blocked superficial femoral artery, a major artery supplying the lower limb
  • Revascularization is the mainstay of treatment in such cases to restore blood flow and prevent amputation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amputation of affected toes: Not first-line management unless tissue is necrotic and non-salvageable. Amputation may be necessary if revascularization fails or infection threatens life, but it's not a primary approach.

 

Option B. EVLA (Endovenous Laser Ablation): Used for varicose veins, not for arterial occlusion. Irrelevant in this context of arterial ischemia, where arterial flow restoration is key.

 

Option C. Medical management: Includes antiplatelets, statins, and glycemic control. Essential adjunct therapy but insufficient alone for critical limb ischemia with ABPI 0.3 and arterial blockage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ABPI <0.4 indicates severe arterial disease; this requires prompt revascularization.
  • Medical therapy alone or toe amputation is not appropriate as initial management for critical limb threating ischemia.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents with worsening breathlessness, orthopnea, and mild ankle edema. He is NYHA class III. Echocardiography shows an ejection fraction of 35%. He is already on bisoprolol and furosemide has been started for reducing congestion. Blood pressure is 102/66 mmHg, creatinine 1.4 mg/dL, and potassium is 5.2 mEq/L. CXR is shown below. What is the best additional drug as of now that can improve long-term outcomes in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Empagliflozin

 

  • This is heart failure with reduced EF (HFrEF) in a diabetic patient.
  • Despite being on an beta-blocker, he remains symptomatic. Adding furosemide is appropriate in this case, as the patient is congested. 
  • ARNI/ACEi/ARB and MRAs are useful in HFrEF to improve long term outcomes but are C/I if initial S.K+ is > 5 mEq/L. 
  • SGLT2 inhibitors like empagliflozin improve survival, reduce hospitalizations, and are well-tolerated even with mild renal impairment.
  • CCBs are NOT useful in standard HF management. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spironolactone: Useful but cannot be initiated since S. K+ is > 5 in this case.

 

Option B. Sacubitril-Valsartan: Very useful but cannot be initiated since S. K+ is > 5 in this case. 

 

Option D. Verapamil: Negative inotrope—worsens HFrEF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Empagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is a disease-modifying therapy in HFrEF and especially useful in diabetics with stable renal function.

questions.text: Match the column (Topic: Abnormalities of Placenta and Cord)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a-1, b-3, c-2, d-4

 

Explanation

 

a. Placenta accreta → 1. Loss of retroplacental clear zone on ultrasound

  • Placenta accreta is an abnormal adherence of the placenta to the uterine wall due to defective decidua basalis.
  • Ultrasound hallmark: Loss of the retroplacental clear zone, thinning of the myometrium, and turbulent lacunar flow.

 

b. Circumvallate placenta → 3. “Pizza” shape with raised edges

  • A circumvallate placenta has rolled edges due to a smaller chorionic plate.
  • Grossly, it resembles a “pizza” with raised, thickened margins, often associated with bleeding and fetal complications.

 

c. Battledore placenta → 2. Coin-like marginal insertion visible on gross exam

  • Battledore placenta refers to a marginal cord insertion, where the cord inserts near the edge of the placenta.
  • On gross examination, this appears coin-like at the margin.

 

d. Vasa previa → 4. Color Doppler shows vessels over internal os

  • In vasa previa, fetal vessels run through membranes overlying the cervical os, unprotected by Wharton's jelly.
  • Color Doppler imaging reveals fetal vessels crossing the internal os, a key diagnostic feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta accreta shows loss of retroplacental clear zone on ultrasound;
Circumvallate placenta appears as “pizza” shaped with raised edges;
Battledore placenta is identified by coin-like marginal insertion on gross exam; Vasa previa is diagnosed by Color Doppler showing fetal vessels over internal os.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with severe ocular pain, redness, and reduced vision for 2 days. Slit-lamp examination confirms a corneal ulcer. The ophthalmologist plans to perform corneal scraping to identify the causative organism. Which topical anesthetic agent is the best choice for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proparacaine

 

  • This 32-year-old woman has a corneal ulcer confirmed on slit-lamp examination. Before corneal scraping, a topical anesthetic is needed to anesthetize the corneal surface.
  • Proparacaine is the preferred topical anesthetic for ophthalmic procedures like corneal scraping.
  • It is available as 0.5%
  • It has minimal corneal toxicity compared to other agents, a rapid onset, and sufficient duration of action for short procedures.
  • Proparacaine is also better tolerated and causes less stinging than alternatives.
  • Corneal scraping is done using 15 no. surgical blade from the leading edge of the ulcer (not from the base or healing side of ulcer). The sample is subjected to gram stain, KOH stain, blood agar and Sabouraud agar. 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prilocaine: Primarily used for regional or infiltration anesthesia, not topical ocular use.

 

Option B. Bupivacaine: Long-acting local anesthetic used for nerve blocks, unsuitable for topical corneal anesthesia.

 

Option D. Lignocaine: Lignocaine (lidocaine) can be used topically but more irritating to the ocular surface than proparacaine, and less favored for delicate corneal procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Proparacaine is the topical anesthetic of choice for ocular surface procedures such as corneal scraping due to its rapid onset, safety, and minimal corneal toxicity.
  • Proparacaine as anesthetic agent also used during cataract surgery, applanation tonometry, forced duction test, syringing-probing, foreign body removal.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is evaluated for primary amenorrhea. She has well-developed breasts but scanty axillary and pubic hair. Physical examination reveals a short blind-ending vagina and absence of a cervix. Ultrasound confirms the absence of a uterus, and MRI reveals intra-abdominal gonads. Karyotyping shows a 46,XY genotype. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome

 

  • This is a classic presentation of Complete Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (CAIS), caused by an X-linked mutation in the androgen receptor.
  •  These patients have a 46,XY karyotype, cryptorchid testes, and produce normal male levels of androgens, but their tissues are unresponsive to androgens. 
  • Hence:
    • Breast development occurs due to peripheral aromatization of testosterone to estrogen.
    • Axillary/pubic hair is scanty or absent due to androgen resistance.
    • Uterus and upper vagina are absent due to anti-Müllerian hormone from Sertoli cells.
    • Testes are present but undescended (cryptorchid).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Turner syndrome:  Is 45,XO and typically presents with streak gonads and lack of secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Option B. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome:  Has normal pubic/axillary hair and 46,XX karyotype.

 

Option D. 5-alpha-reductase deficiency: Shows ambiguous genitalia and virilization at puberty, but not complete breast development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complete Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome presents with 46,XY karyotype, absent uterus, breast development, and minimal pubic/axillary hair due to androgen resistance.

questions.text: A public health researcher is analyzing data comparing smoking status (smoker vs non-smoker) and the development of chronic bronchitis (present vs absent) among adults. Which of the following statistical tests is most appropriate to evaluate the association between these two categorical variables?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chi-square test

 

  • The chi-square test is the correct choice for evaluating the association between two categorical variables, especially when organized in a 2x2 contingency table.
  •  It checks for statistically significant differences between expected and observed frequencies. 
  • This is highly relevant in clinical research involving binary outcomes like presence or absence of disease or exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mann-Whitney U test: This is a non-parametric test used for comparing two independent groups when the data is ordinal or continuous but not normally distributed. It does not apply to categorical variables structured in a 2x2 table.

 

Option B. ANOVA (Analysis of Variance): Used to compare means of three or more groups involving continuous variables, ANOVA is not appropriate for assessing relationships between two categorical variables.

 

Option D. Pearson correlation coefficient: This measures the linear relationship between two continuous variables, not categorical variables. Hence, it is not suited for evaluating associations in a 2x2 categorical setup.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To test the association between two categorical variables arranged in a 2x2 contingency table, the Chi-square test is the most statistically appropriate method.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman is found to have an aberrant right subclavian artery on imaging done for evaluation of dysphagia. Which of the following embryological structures, if it regresses abnormally, would most likely result in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

  • The right fourth aortic arch artery normally contributes to the formation of the proximal part of the right subclavian artery. 
  • If this arch regresses abnormally, the right subclavian artery cannot arise from its usual location. 
  • Instead, it arises distal to the left subclavian artery (as the last branch of the aortic arch) and passes behind the esophagus to reach the right side, leading to an aberrant right subclavian artery. 
  • This may cause dysphagia lusoria, where esophageal compression results in difficulty swallowing.

 

 

  1. Right third arch artery (Right common carotid artery)
  2. Right fourth arch artery (Right subclavian artery)
  3. Left fourth arch artery (Arch of aorta)
  4. Left sixth arch artery (will disappear)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right third arch artery: This structure contributes to the common carotid artery and the proximal internal carotid artery, not the subclavian artery. Its regression would not lead to an aberrant subclavian artery.

 

Option C. Left fourth arch artery: This gives rise to part of the arch of the aorta on the left side. Regression here could affect aortic arch morphology but not the right subclavian artery.

 

Option D. Left sixth arch artery: This forms the left pulmonary artery and the ductus arteriosus (ligamentum arteriosum postnatally). Its regression is unrelated to subclavian artery development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The aberrant right subclavian artery arises due to regression of the right fourth aortic arch, leading to the vessel arising from the descending aorta and coursing posterior to the esophagus.

choices.text: Direct ECT has been banned in children
Modified ECT has been banned in adults

questions.text: All of the following are correct regarding Mental Health Care Act 2017 except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Modified ECT has been banned in adults

 

  • The Mental Health Care Act 2017 does NOT ban modified ECT in adults. 
  • Direct ECT is banned
  • Modified ECT (with anesthesia and muscle relaxants) remains an accepted treatment modality for adults with severe mental illnesses. 
  • The Act specifically bans direct ECT (without anesthesia) and prohibits any form of ECT in minors, but modified ECT continues to be a legitimate treatment option for adults when indicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suicide attempt has been decriminalised: This is correct. The Act states that any person who attempts suicide shall be presumed to be under severe stress and should not be tried or punished

 

Option B. Psychosurgery has been banned: This is correct. The Mental Health Care Act 2017 explicitly bans psychosurgery

 

Option C. Direct ECT has been banned in children: This is correct. The Act bans ECT for minors and also bans direct ECT (unmodified ECT without anesthesia)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mental Health Care Act 2017 protects patient rights by banning direct ECT, prohibiting ECT in minors, banning psychosurgery, and decriminalizing suicide attempts, while still allowing modified ECT as a treatment option for adults.

questions.text: Which of the following complication is most expected during third to seventh day after myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ventricular free wall rupture

 

  • Between 3 to 7 days post-myocardial infarction (MI), the risk of ventricular free wall rupture is highest. 
  • This is due to the macrophage-mediated removal of necrotic debris, which weakens the infarcted myocardial wall before scar tissue formation occurs. As a result, the myocardial tissue becomes structurally vulnerable to rupture.
  •  Ventricular rupture can lead to cardiac tamponade, which presents with sudden hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and jugular venous distension — features consistent with Beck’s triad of tamponade physiology.
  • In this clinical scenario, the patient developed acute hemodynamic compromise on day 5 post-MI, which is classic for ventricular rupture, making it the most likely complication in the third to seventh day window.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intracardiac thrombus formation: Thrombosis (intracardiac mural thrombus) is a known complication after MI, but it is more common in areas of akinetic myocardium, especially in large anterior infarcts. While mural thrombus can occur around the 3–7 day period, it does not typically cause acute tamponade and sudden hemodynamic collapse, making it less likely the cause in this patient with hypotension and features of tamponade.

 

Option C. Autoimmune pericarditis: This refers to Dressler syndrome, which is an autoimmune pericarditis occurring weeks after myocardial infarction, not usually in the third to seventh day window. Dressler syndrome is characterized by fever, pleuritic chest pain, and a pericardial friction rub, rather than sudden tamponade. Therefore, autoimmune pericarditis is incorrect in this time frame and setting.

 

Option D. Conduction disturbances: Arrhythmias and conduction abnormalities are among the most common early complications of MI but tend to happen within the first 24–48 hours. While arrhythmias can still occur later, they do not classically present with cardiac tamponade physiology. Thus, although conduction disturbances are possible, they are not the most likely cause of tamponade in a patient 3–7 days post-MI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular free wall rupture is the most feared complication 3–7 days after myocardial infarction due to macrophage-mediated tissue degradation before collagen scar formation.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, and difficulty breathing. He is a known alcoholic. On exam: HR 108/min, BP 90/60 mmHg, RR 28/min, and SpO₂ 91%. Labs show amylase 560 U/L, lipase 720 U/L. CXR shows a left pleural effusion. What is the most likely ABG finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) pH 7.3, HCO3- 14, Anion gap 25, PaCO2 25

 

  • The clinical picture is consistent with acute alcoholic pancreatitis. Patients usually tend to develop systemic hypoperfusion/shock lactic (high anion gap) acidosis. 
  • Thus, the best matching option is A, which reflects:
    • Acidosis (pH ~7.3)
    • Low HCO₃⁻
    • High anion gap (25)
    • Compensatory low PaCO₂

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. pH 7.3, HCO₃⁻ 15, Anion gap 10, PaCO₂ 25: Normal anion gap is not consistent with this clinical scenario.

 

Option C. pH 7.3, HCO₃⁻ 25, Anion gap 10, PaCO₂ 56: This suggests respiratory acidosis which is incorrect.

 

Option D. pH 7.3, HCO₃⁻ 25, Anion gap 10, PaCO₂ 25: Again, HCO₃⁻ is normal—not likely in this case. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with alcoholic pancreatitis - expect a high anion gap metabolic acidosis with compensatory low PaCO₂.

questions.text: An infant presents with inspiratory stridor that started in the first few weeks of life. The stridor worsens when lying supine or during crying and improves in the prone position. There are no desaturation episodes or feeding difficulties. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conservative management with follow-up

 

  • The infant’s history of inspiratory stridor beginning in the first weeks of life, worsening when supine or agitated and easing when prone, is characteristic of mild laryngomalacia, the commonest cause of congenital stridor. 
  • Most cases are self-limiting: symptoms peak around 4–6 months as laryngeal cartilage matures and resolve spontaneously by 12-18 months, maximum 24 months. 
  • In the absence of red-flag features (apnea, desaturation, poor weight gain, feeding difficulty or repeated pneumonia), the recommended approach is parental reassurance, positional advice (upright/prone when awake, elevated head end when supine) and periodic outpatient review.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheostomy: reserved for extreme upper-airway obstruction unresponsive to supraglottoplasty or when multiple airway anomalies coexist; not indicated in an otherwise thriving infant.

 

Option C. Supraglottoplasty: first-line surgery for severe laryngomalacia (stridor with apnea, cyanosis, failure to thrive, or aspiration). This infant has none of those features.

 

Option D. CT scan of the neck: imaging is unnecessary for typical laryngomalacia; CT is considered only when atypical findings suggest an additional fixed lesion or external vascular compression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Typical, uncomplicated laryngomalacia presents with positional inspiratory stridor in early infancy and is managed conservatively because most cases resolve by 18 months without surgery.

choices.text: Confirm with repeat ultrasound in 1 week

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 10 weeks of amenorrhea presents for a routine antenatal check-up. She has no vaginal bleeding or abdominal pain. An ultrasound reveals a gestational sac with no fetal pole and absent cardiac activity. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Confirm with repeat ultrasound in 1 week

 

  • This clinical scenario suggests a missed abortion (also called missed miscarriage): The fetus has died in utero, but the products of conception are retained and the patient may be asymptomatic.
  • Ultrasound shows: Empty gestational sac: Possibly an anembryonic pregnancy (blighted ovum).
  • No cardiac activity: If a fetal pole is present, cardiac activity should normally be detectable by 6.5–7 weeks on transvaginal USG.
  • However, the diagnosis must be made cautiously to avoid terminating a viable pregnancy due to misdated gestational age. Therefore, standard protocols recommend a repeat ultrasound after 7–10 days to confirm the absence of viability.
  • This aligns with RCOG and ACOG guidelines. Repeat scan ensures accurate dating and confirms nonviability before intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start misoprostol: Misoprostol is used to medically evacuate the uterus only after confirming missed abortion. Starting it now without confirmation risks aborting a potentially viable pregnancy.

 

Option B. Emergency D&C: D&C is reserved for confirmed missed abortion, not first-line without confirmation. Also, this is not an emergency — the patient is stable.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: Expectant management is an option after confirmation, not before. Observation now without repeat imaging may lead to missed or delayed management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In early pregnancy, a missed abortion must be confirmed with a repeat scan after 7–10 days before any intervention.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with persistent vomiting, lethargy, and failure to thrive. The symptoms began after introducing sugar and sweetened formula into the diet. Laboratory findings reveal hypoglycemia, elevated liver enzymes, and metabolic acidosis. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aldolase B

 

  • Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI) is caused by a deficiency of Aldolase B, an enzyme required for the breakdown of fructose-1-phosphate in the liver, kidneys, and intestines. 
  • When fructose or sucrose is ingested, fructose-1-phosphate accumulates, leading to phosphate depletion, inhibition of gluconeogenesis, and glycogenolysis. 
  • This results in hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, vomiting, and metabolic acidosis. Symptoms are triggered by the consumption of fructose-containing foods such as fruits, juices, and sweetened formula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fructokinase: Deficiency of fructokinase causes essential fructosuria, a benign condition with no significant clinical symptoms. It is unrelated to the severe symptoms seen in Hereditary Fructose Intolerance.

 

Option B. Aldolase A: This enzyme is involved in glycolysis and is present in muscles and erythrocytes. Its deficiency causes nonspecific muscle-related symptoms and is not associated with fructose metabolism.

 

Option C. Sucrase: Sucrase deficiency leads to intolerance to sucrose-containing foods but does not explain the hypoglycemia and liver dysfunction observed in HFI. It will produce gas and diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI) is caused by a deficiency of Aldolase B, leading to the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate, which inhibits gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, causing hypoglycaemia and metabolic acidosis.
  • Symptoms are triggered by fructose ingestion.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman from Lucknow presents with progressive weakness of the right arm and leg, facial numbness, and hoarseness of voice. She also reports occasional vertigo and hiccups. Examination shows decreased pain and temperature sensation on the left limbs and right face, with right-sided Horner's syndrome. MRI brain is shown below. What is the most likely vascular territory involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

 

  • Classic lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) presentation:
    • Ipsilateral facial sensory loss + Horner's syndrome
    • Contralateral body pain/temp loss
    • Dysphagia, hoarseness, hiccups → nucleus ambiguus
    • Ataxia, vertigo → cerebellar signs
  • PICA is a branch of the vertebral artery and the key culprit here.
  • MRI would show infarct in the lateral medulla and inferior cerebellum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior cerebral artery: ACA infarcts → leg-dominant weakness, not cranial nerve findings.

 

Option C. Middle cerebral artery: MCA → hemiparesis, aphasia, visual neglect.

 

Option D. Basilar artery: Basilar thrombosis → bilateral deficits, locked-in syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lateral medullary infarction (Wallenberg syndrome) is caused by PICA occlusion and presents with crossed sensory loss and cerebellar/cranial signs.

questions.text: A national pediatric health program aimed at preventing ocular complications due to vitamin deficiency in early childhood includes periodic oral administration of a concentrated vitamin supplement. What is the concentration of this supplement?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 lakh IU/ml

 

  • The Prevention of Nutritional Blindness due to Vitamin A Deficiency programme is a key initiative in child health under India's public health system. 
  • This program provides Vitamin A supplementation to children as prophylaxis against xerophthalmia and nutritional blindness. 
  • The formulation used contains 1 lakh IU/ml of Vitamin A, which is typically dispensed in specific age-based dosages as per national guidelines.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • National Programme for Prophylaxis against Blindness in Children caused by Vitamin A Deficiency: Prophylaxis against Vitamin-A deficiency is provided in form of oral 9 doses of Vitamin-A
    • 1st dose (1 lac IU) at 9 months age (along with measles vaccine)
    • 2nd dose (2 lac IU) at 15 months age
    • then a dose (2 lac IU) every 6 months till the age of 5 years
    • Total dose given: 17 lac IU

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with progressive enlargement of his hands and feet, prominent jaw protrusion, hyperhidrosis, and impaired glucose tolerance. Laboratory studies show elevated serum IGF-1 and failure of growth hormone suppression after an oral glucose load. MRI reveals a pituitary macroadenoma. Which of the following is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pegvisomant

 

  • Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist specifically designed to treat acromegaly in patients who are either resistant to or intolerant of somatostatin analogs like octreotide.
  •  Pegvisomant binds to GH receptors and blocks the downstream production of IGF-1, which mediates many of the symptoms of GH excess such as acral enlargement, insulin resistance, and excessive sweating.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Octreotide: A somatostatin analog that inhibits GH secretion at the pituitary level. While effective, it is not a GH receptor antagonist. It reduces GH production but doesn't block its action peripherally.

 

Option C. Bromocriptine: A dopamine agonist previously used for acromegaly, especially in prolactin co-secreting tumors. However, it is less effective than newer agents like somatostatin analogs and pegvisomant, and not a GH receptor antagonist.

 

Option D. Olcegepant: A calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonist investigated for migraine therapy, not for disorders of GH excess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used in the treatment of acromegaly by directly blocking GH receptors and reducing circulating IGF-1 levels, thus improving clinical symptoms and metabolic disturbances.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a chronic itchy lesion on his forearm. A skin biopsy is performed, and sent for histopathological examination.  Which of the following cell types is not typically found in the layer marked as D?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Langerhans cells

 

 

  • Langerhans cells are specialized dendritic antigen-presenting cells derived from the bone marrow (mesodermal origin) and are primarily located in the stratum spinosum of the epidermis. 
  • They are not typically found in the stratum basale (the layer marked as D). These cells contain characteristic Birbeck granules (with a “tennis racquet” appearance on electron microscopy) and are involved in cutaneous immune responses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratinocyte: Keratinocytes are the predominant cells of the epidermis and are found in all layers including the stratum basale. They originate from ectoderm and are responsible for synthesizing keratin.

 

Option B. Merkel cell: Merkel cells are mechanoreceptors found within the stratum basale and are involved in the sensation of light touch. They are typically present in regions of high tactile acuity.

 

Option C. Melanocytes: Melanocytes are pigment-producing cells also found in the stratum Basale. They synthesize melanin and transfer it to keratinocytes through their dendritic processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Langerhans cells are antigen-presenting cells located in the stratum spinosum and are not found in the stratum basale, which contains keratinocytes, Merkel cells, and melanocytes.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with infertility. On ultrasound, both ovaries are enlarged with multiple peripheral follicles. Serum testosterone is mildly elevated. Which of the following is the best initial treatment for ovulation induction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Letrozole

 

  • Letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor, is now considered the first-line treatment for ovulation induction in PCOS patients due to higher ovulation and live birth rates compared to clomiphene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin: Used as an adjunct, especially in obese patients or with insulin resistance.


Option B. Clomiphene citrate: Previously first-line, but now replaced by letrozole. due to multifollicular development by clomiphene. 


Option C. Gonadotropins therapy: Second-line, used when oral agents fail; higher cost and risk of OHSS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Letrozole is the first-line agent for ovulation induction in women with polycystic ovary syndrome due to its superior efficacy and safety profile.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic woman presents with worsening headache, vomiting, and new-onset diplopia. She is febrile and drowsy. Fundoscopy shows papilledema. A contrast-enhanced MRI is shown below. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start ceftriaxone + metronidazole

 

  • Ring-enhancing lesions + fever + focal signs = brain abscess.
  • Location in the MRI shown: Temporoparietal (common with hematogenous spread).
  • Metronidazole covers anaerobes; ceftriaxone for gram-negative.
  • Diabetics are predisposed due to immunosuppression.
  • Acyclovir for HSV encephalitis—not ring-enhancing.
  • ATT reserved for tuberculoma (more common in Indian children, not diabetics).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start IV acyclovir and observe: Ring-enhancing lesions not typical of HSV.

 

Option B. Initiate empirical antitubercular therapy: Tuberculomas appear solid, with calcification or conglomerates.

 

Option D. Neurosurgical aspiration for diagnosis: Done if abscess >2.5 cm or mass effect; not first line in stable patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brain abscesses in diabetics with ring-enhancing lesions are treated empirically with ceftriaxone and metronidazole after imaging.

questions.text: Identify the procedure displayed below:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oro-gastric tube insertion

 

  • Orogastric tube is inserted through the mouth into the stomach, especially in neonates who cannot tolerate nasal tubes.
  • Measure the length of orogastric tube = length from Tragus to angle of mouth to xiphoid process.

 

Other Options:



Option A. Intubation: Intubation is tracheal.


Option B. Nasogastric tube insertion: Nasogastric tube goes via the nose.


Option D. Oropharyngeal airway insertion: Oropharyngeal airway maintains airway patency, not used for feeding.

 

Educational Objective:


Orogastric tube passes through the mouth into the stomach, commonly used in neonates.

questions.text: Match the following components of the cell with their respective functions:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, 4-B

 

  • Mitochondria (1) – Energy production (D): Generate energy via aerobic respiration.
  • Golgi apparatus (2) – Packaging proteins and lipids into vesicles (C): Packages proteins and lipids into vesicles.
  • Cytoskeleton (3) – Structural stability (A): Provides structural stability.
  • Cytosol (4) – Intracellular flux (B):Involved in intracellular flux.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Mitochondria: Generate energy via aerobic respiration.
  • Golgi apparatus: Packages proteins and lipids into vesicles.
  • Cytoskeleton: Provides structural stability.
  • Cytosol: Involved in intracellular flux.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman undergoes elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. For cosmetic purposes, the surgeon decides to close the skin with a subcuticular suture. Which of the following suture materials is most appropriate for this type of closure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Poliglecaprone

 

  • Poliglecaprone (Monocryl) is a synthetic monofilament absorbable suture with high initial tensile strength and smooth passage through tissue, making it ideal for subcuticular suturing of skin, soft tissue approximation, and gastrointestinal/muscle surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silk: Is non-absorbable and braided, often avoided in subcuticular closures due to tissue reactivity.

 

Option B. Polypropylene: Polypropylene (Prolene) is non-absorbable and used for skin or vascular anastomosis, but not ideal for absorbable subcuticular closure.

 

Option D. Polyglactin: Polyglactin (Vicryl) is absorbable but braided, which can increase the risk of infection and is less ideal for subcuticular use compared to monofilament sutures. A variant of Vicryl known as rapid Vicryl. Rapid Vicryl remain in body for 2-3 weeks, so this can be used if monocryl is not available. 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Poliglecaprone (Monocryl), a monofilament absorbable suture, is preferred for subcuticular skin closure due to low tissue reactivity and good cosmetic outcome.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding for the past 6 months. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals a hyperechoic intracavitary lesion. Saline infusion sonography confirms a sessile endometrial mass with a single vessel supplying it on Doppler. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endometrial polyp

 

  • Endometrial polyps are benign overgrowths of endometrial glands and stroma. 
  • They appear as echogenic masses within the endometrial cavity on ultrasound and may be sessile or pedunculated. 
  • Saline infusion sonography enhances their visualization and is the investigation of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenomyosis: Appears as a bulky uterus with myometrial cysts and is not typically intracavitary.

 

Option B. Submucosal fibroid: Usually appears hypoechoic and may distort the endometrial cavity.

 

Option D. Endometrial hyperplasia: Causes thickened endometrium but does not form a discrete mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometrial polyps are common causes of abnormal uterine bleeding and appear as focal echogenic masses within the endometrial cavity, best evaluated with saline infusion sonography.

choices.text: DNA replication and rapid cell division
Peak metabolic activity with exponential growth

questions.text: A microbiologist observes a bacterial culture that has entered a phase characterized by nutrient depletion, slowed cell division, and activation of stress response pathways. Which of the following best describes the physiological activities predominant during this phase?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sporulation and exotoxin production

 

  • Bacterial growth curve:
    • Lag phase – Bacterial takes maximum nutrition and at the end bacteria reaches the maximum size
    • Exponential phase – Increased amount of viability and decreased size. The bacteria is metabolically active (staining, biochemical)
    • Stationary phase – Nutrition decreases, and stress will increase. Bacteria start forming spores, exotoxins, bacteriocins and antibiotics 
    • Decline/ death phase – Viability decreases, and death will increase. Nutrition has completely stopped. Involutional forms will be seen. 
  • The stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve is marked by nutrient limitation, accumulation of waste products, and a plateau in the number of viable cells due to a balance between cell division and cell death. 
  • In this phase:
    • Sporulation occurs in certain Gram-positive bacteria like Clostridium and Bacillus species as a survival mechanism.
    • Exotoxin production is also prominent in this phase, as bacteria respond to environmental stress.
  • These processes help bacteria adapt and persist in hostile conditions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA replication and rapid cell division: This describes the log (exponential) phase, not the stationary phase. Here, cells multiply at a constant rate.

 

Option B. Peak metabolic activity with exponential growth: Also, a feature of the log phase, when bacteria are most metabolically active.

 

Option D. Cell death exceeds cell division: This describes the death (decline) phase, where nutrient exhaustion and toxic buildup lead to a net loss in viable cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sporulation and exotoxin production are hallmark activities of the stationary phase in bacterial growth, triggered by environmental stress and nutrient limitation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and congestive heart failure is enrolled in a clinical trial for an investigational antihypertensive drug. The compound inhibits both angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) and neutral endopeptidase (neprilysin). A few days after initiation, the patient develops facial swelling without urticaria or rash. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Omapatrilat

 

  • Omapatrilat is an experimental drug that inhibits both ACE and neprilysin (a neutral endopeptidase). 
  • ACE inhibition increases bradykinin levels, and neprilysin inhibition further potentiates bradykinin, substance P, and natriuretic peptides. 
  • This dual action contributes to potent blood pressure-lowering effects. 
  • However, excess bradykinin accumulation significantly increases the risk of angioedema, particularly facial swelling without associated hives or itching.
  • Because of this high incidence of angioedema, Omapatrilat has not been approved for clinical use despite its theoretical benefits in heart failure and hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aliskiren: A direct renin inhibitor used to lower blood pressure. It does not inhibit ACE or neprilysin and does not cause bradykinin-related angioedema as frequently as Omapatrilat.

 

Option C. Sacubitril: Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor, used in combination with valsartan in heart failure (Entresto). While it can increase bradykinin, it is not combined with ACE inhibitors to avoid excess angioedema. When used with valsartan (an ARB), the risk is minimized.

 

Option D. Valsartan:  An angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB). It does not affect bradykinin levels and is therefore not associated with angioedema as commonly as ACE inhibitors or Omapatrilat.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Omapatrilat is a dual ACE and neprilysin inhibitor that significantly increases the risk of bradykinin-mediated angioedema. 
  • Despite its theoretical efficacy in hypertension and heart failure, its clinical use has been limited due to safety concerns.
