questions.text: During an exploratory laparotomy, the surgeon performs the Mattox maneuver. Which injury was he most likely trying to visualize?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abdominal aorta injury

 

  • The Mattox maneuver involves left medial visceral rotation to visualize the abdominal aorta.
  •  This maneuver allows the surgeon to access and visualize the retroperitoneum and structures adjacent to the abdominal aorta, making it particularly useful for identifying and managing injuries to the abdominal aorta. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver injury:  Liver injuries are often visualized during an exploratory laparotomy through standard surgical techniques such as liver mobilization and retraction.

 

Option B. Splenic injury:  Splenic injuries are typically visualized through careful exploration of the left upper quadrant during a laparotomy.

 

Option D. Inferior vena cava: Inferior vena cava injuries are typically visualized using a different maneuver called the Cattell-Braasch maneuver, which involves right medial visceral rotation. This maneuver allows the surgeon to access and visualize the retroperitoneum and structures adjacent to the inferior vena cava.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mattox maneuver is used as a surgical technique to visualize and manage injuries to the abdominal aorta during exploratory laparotomy.

questions.text: A child in your hospital is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According to the WHO criteria, SAM is defined best by:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Weight for height less than –3 SD

 

  • 3 parameters-
    • Decrease weight for height – Acute malnutrition
    • Decrease height for age – Chronic malnutrition 
    • Decrease weight for age – Acute on chronic malnutrition
  • According to WHO criteria, a child is classified as having SAM when:
    • Weight-for-height is < –3 SD of the median WHO growth standards,
    • OR MUAC < 115 mm,
    • OR presence of bilateral pedal edema.
  • Weight-for-age is not a valid indicator for SAM, as it doesn't distinguish between acute and chronic malnutrition.
  • Weight for height less than +2 SD indicates overweight, not SAM.

 

Educational Objective:
SAM is diagnosed when weight-for-height is below –3 SD, not weight-for-age.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of seizures and progressive neurological decline undergoes evaluation for a suspected intracranial mass. The image is shown below. Which of the following diagnostic modalities best corresponds to this graph?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MR Spectroscopy

 

  • The displayed graph depicts the relative concentrations of brain metabolites: NAA, choline, and creatine.
  • A pattern of elevated choline (marker of cellularity) and decreased NAA (neuronal integrity marker) is highly suggestive of a neoplastic process.
  • These metabolite peaks are specifically analyzed by MR Spectroscopy, a specialized MRI technique to evaluate tissue biochemistry.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positron Emission Tomography (PET): Provides metabolic data on glucose uptake using radiotracers but does not show detailed brain metabolite spectra.

 

Option B.  Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography (SPECT): Measures regional cerebral perfusion but cannot display NAA, choline, or creatine peaks.

 

Option D. Diffusion Tensor Imaging (DTI): Evaluates white matter fiber tracts, not chemical metabolite concentrations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MR Spectroscopy is the imaging method of choice for noninvasively evaluating the concentration of brain metabolites such as NAA, choline, and creatine.

questions.text:
Which of the following are contents of the carpal tunnel? 

 

a. Flexor digitorum profundus tendon

b. Flexor carpi ulnaris tendon

c. Median nerve

d. Flexor pollicis longus tendon
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a, c, d

 

  • Carpal tunnel contents: 9 tendons (4 FDP, 4 FDS, 1 FPL) + median nerve
  • Flexor carpi ulnaris lies outside the tunnel and runs medially.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The carpal tunnel contains 9 tendons and the median nerve; structures like flexor carpi ulnaris lie outside.

choices.text: The causative organism can be cultured in NNN medium
The infection exhibits both amastigote and trypomastigote forms in humans
The vector is the Glossina palpalis (Tsetse fly)
Romana’s sign is a classic feature of acute disease

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Chagas’ disease is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The vector is the Glossina palpalis (Tsetse fly)

 

  • Trypanosoma cruzi, the agent of Chagas’ disease, is transmitted by the reduviid bug (also called the kissing bug/triatomine bug), not the Tsetse fly (Glossina palpalis, which transmits Trypanosoma brucei, the cause of African sleeping sickness). 
  • Romana’s sign (painless unilateral periorbital edema) is indeed a diagnostic clue in acute Chagas’ disease.
  • T. cruzi exhibits two main forms in human tissue — the amastigote form (in cells) and trypomastigote form (in blood). 
  • It can also be cultured in specialized media such as NNN (Novy-MacNeal-Nicolle) medium.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The causative organism can be cultured in NNN medium: Correct. T. cruzi grows in NNN medium.

 

Option B.  The infection exhibits both amastigote and trypomastigote forms in humans: Correct. Amastigotes in tissue and trypomastigotes in the bloodstream are characteristic.

 

Option D. Romana’s sign is a classic feature of acute disease: Correct. Romana’s sign is a hallmark of acute Chagas’ disease. It leads to unilateral swelling of eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chagas’ disease (Trypanosoma cruzi) is transmitted by the reduviid (kissing) bug and should not be confused with African trypanosomiasis, which uses the Tsetse fly vector.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic with a persistent cough and occasional haemoptysis. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking. An urgent chest x-ray is reported as being normal. In patients who are subsequently diagnosed with lung cancer, what percentage of recent chest x-rays were reported as normal?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 10%

 

  • In around 10% of patients subsequently diagnosed with lung cancer, the chest x-ray was reported as normal. 
  • It is important not to get false reassurance from a normal chest x-ray report in patients with worrying symptoms (smoker with haemoptysis). 
  • This patient should have a CT scan to exclude a lung cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CXR can be normal in 10% of patients with Lung cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is primarily inactivated via Hofmann elimination, an organ-independent mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atracurium

 

  • Atracurium is a benzylisoquinolinium non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that is uniquely broken down by Hofmann elimination, a temperature- and pH-dependent chemical degradation occurring in the plasma. 
  • This breakdown is independent of liver or kidney metabolism, which makes atracurium a safe choice in critically ill patients with organ dysfunction. 
  • In addition, a portion of atracurium is metabolized by nonspecific esterases, but Hofmann elimination is its defining elimination pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancuronium: Pancuronium is a steroidal neuromuscular blocker that relies mainly on renal excretion, with some hepatic metabolism. It is not inactivated by Hofmann elimination, so its effects may be prolonged in renal failure.

 

Option C. Mivacurium: Mivacurium is metabolized by plasma pseudocholinesterase, not by Hofmann elimination, and is therefore subject to variability in patients with pseudocholinesterase deficiency.

 

Option D. Vecuronium: Vecuronium is largely metabolized by the liver and excreted via the bile, with a component of renal excretion as well, so it is not suitable for patients with severe hepatic dysfunction if cumulative effects are a concern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker inactivated primarily by Hofmann elimination, a temperature- and pH-dependent chemical process that does not rely on hepatic or renal pathways, making it a safe option for patients with liver or kidney impairment.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man from Maharashtra presents with progressive exertional dyspnea, orthopnea, and easy fatigability over 3 months. On examination, he has a tapping apex beat, loud S1, and a mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation at the apex. There is also a palpable P2 and mild pedal edema. ECG is shown below. What is the most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transthoracic echocardiography

 

  • The presentation is classic for rheumatic mitral stenosis.
  • Key clinical signs: loud S1, opening snap, mid-diastolic murmur.
  • ECG shows P mitrale; suggests left atrial enlargement.
  • TTE with Doppler is the diagnostic gold standard for:
    • Mitral valve area calculation
    • Transvalvular gradient
    • Presence of LA thrombus (via TEE if needed)
    • Pulmonary pressures
  • It helps assess eligibility for percutaneous balloon mitral valvotomy.
  • CXR may show straightening of left heart border due to LA enlargement.
  • Other options are supportive or used in complex scenarios.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coronary angiography: Useful pre-surgery in older patients, but not diagnostic for valvular disease.

 

Option C. Cardiac MRI: MRI is helpful in cardiomyopathies or ARVD but not needed here.

 

Option D. NT-proBNP assay: NT-proBNP supports heart failure diagnosis, not mitral stenosis evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TTE with Doppler is the investigation of choice to diagnose and grade mitral stenosis and determine treatment approach.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes presents with increasing fatigue and facial puffiness. BP is 160/100 mmHg. Urinalysis shows 3+ proteinuria. Fundus shows cotton wool spots and microaneurysms. Which among the following would not be recommended?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Renal Biopsy

 

  • Diabetic nephropathy is a clinical diagnosis in patients with:
    • Long-standing poorly controlled diabetes
    • Proteinuria (often in nephrotic range)
    • Diabetic retinopathy (strongly supports the diagnosis)
  • A renal biopsy is not recommended unless there are atypical features (e.g., hematuria, rapid decline in renal function, or absence of diabetic retinopathy).
  • Since this patient has classic features of diabetic nephropathy, a biopsy is unnecessary and invasive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ramipril: An ACE inhibitor that reduces intraglomerular pressure, proteinuria, and slows progression of diabetic nephropathy. 

 

Option C. Finerenone: A non-steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist shown to reduce cardiovascular and renal outcomes in patients with diabetic kidney disease.

 

Option D. Empagliflozin: An SGLT2 inhibitor, effective in improving glycemic control, reducing proteinuria, and providing cardiorenal protection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a diabetic patient with proteinuria and retinopathy, the diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy is clinical, and renal biopsy is not indicated unless atypical features are present. 
  • Treatment includes ACE inhibitors/ARBs, SGLT2 inhibitors, and MR antagonists like finerenone.

choices.text: A woman ovulates and conceives during two separate cycles, with one fertilization occurring after intercourse with a different partner in the second cycle
A woman ovulates once but is fertilized twice by sperm from the same partner during a prolonged sexual encounter
A woman has two eggs released from the same ovulatory cycle and are fertilized by sperms from two different partners
A woman has two fertilized eggs from the same ovulation cycle, from two different partners, but one implantation is delayed as compared to other

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios would be most likely to result in heteropaternal superfetation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A woman ovulates and conceives during two separate cycles, with one fertilization occurring after intercourse with a different partner in the second cycle

 

  • Heteropaternal superfetation is a rare phenomenon where a woman becomes pregnant during an already ongoing pregnancy, typically due to ovulation and fertilization occurring in a subsequent menstrual cycle after a previous conception. 
  • For this to occur, ovulation must continue despite existing pregnancy, and sperm from a different partner must fertilize the newly released ovum.
  • In option A, the woman ovulates and conceives during two separate cycles, and one fertilization occurs after intercourse with a different partner in the second cycle. 
  • This sequence captures the essential features of heteropaternal superfetation — different ovulatory events and fertilization by two different partners at different times. Thus, option a is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. A woman ovulates once but is fertilized twice by sperm from the same partner during a prolonged sexual encounter: This describes dizygotic twinning, where two eggs from a single ovulation are fertilized by the same partner. Since heteropaternal superfetation involves two cycles and two different partners, this is incorrect.

 

Option C. A woman has two eggs released from the same ovulatory cycle and are fertilized by sperms from two different partners: This describes heteropaternal superfecundation, not superfetation. Superfecundation occurs during the same cycle, whereas superfetation involves different ovulatory cycles. So this is not the correct answer for superfetation.

 

Option D. A woman has two fertilized eggs from the same ovulation cycle, from two different partners, but one implantation is delayed as compared to other: While this involves two partners, it still occurs in the same ovulatory cycle, making it an example of heteropaternal superfecundation with asynchronous implantation, not superfetation. Therefore, it is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heteropaternal superfetation refers to fertilization events occurring in two separate ovulatory cycles, with sperm from different partners, leading to pregnancy during an already ongoing pregnancy.

questions.text:
Which of the following structures form the boundaries of the femoral triangle? 

 

a. Inguinal ligament

b. Sartorius muscle

c. Adductor longus

d. Gracilis muscle
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a, b, c

 

  • Femoral triangle boundaries: 
    • Superior: Inguinal ligament
    • Lateral: Sartorius
    • Medial: Adductor longus

 

 

  • Gracilis is medial to adductor longus and not part of the triangle boundary.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The femoral triangle is bounded by the inguinal ligament, sartorius, and adductor longus.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is admitted following a fall that resulted in a large intramuscular hematoma after minimal trauma. He has a history of alcohol use disorder and poor nutrition. Laboratory evaluation reveals an elevated prothrombin time (PT) and normal platelet count. The patient is started on vitamin K therapy. Which of the following amino acids in his clotting factors requires modification for proper function following treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glutamate

 

  • Vitamin K is critical in the post-translational γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues in several coagulation proteins, including factors II (prothrombin), VII, IX, and X, as well as proteins C and S.
  • This γ-carboxylation occurs in the liver and enables the modified glutamate residues (now γ-carboxyglutamate or Gla) to bind calcium, a crucial step for anchoring clotting factors to phospholipid surfaces during the coagulation cascade.
  • Without this modification, clotting proteins are synthesized but remain non-functional, which clinically manifests as bleeding tendencies such as spontaneous hematomas.

 

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspartate: Although aspartate is an amino acid with a carboxylic side chain like glutamate, it is not the target of vitamin K–dependent γ-carboxylation. It is not modified in coagulation protein function.

 

Option B. Proline: Proline is hydroxylated during collagen synthesis, a process that requires vitamin C, not vitamin K. It plays no role in coagulation or post-translational γ-carboxylation.

 

Option D. Lysine: Lysine is subject to other post-translational modifications such as acetylation or hydroxylation (in collagen), but not γ-carboxylation, and is not involved in the vitamin K–dependent coagulation pathway.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

  • Vitamin K enables γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues in coagulation factors, which is essential for calcium binding and clotting function.

choices.text: Indicates active viral replication and high infectivity
Suggests superinfection with hepatitis E virus

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic for evaluation of abnormal liver enzymes detected on routine screening. Laboratory testing reveals the presence of both hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg). Which of the following best describes the implication of these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Indicates active viral replication and high infectivity

 

  • The presence of hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) demonstrates that the patient is currently infected with hepatitis B virus. HBsAg → positive in acute infection, and in chronic carriers.
  •  In addition, the detection of hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) signifies active viral replication and a high level of infectivity, meaning the patient is in an active phase of hepatitis B infection with significant risk of transmission to others. 
  • This combination (HBsAg + HBeAg positive) is a marker of high viral load and contagiousness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suggests previous immunization: Previous hepatitis B vaccination would result in positive anti-HBs antibodies, not HBsAg positivity, so this is incorrect.

 

Option C. Suggests superinfection with hepatitis E virus: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection is unrelated to HBsAg or HBeAg positivity and would require different serologic testing, so this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Suggests a past infection: A past infection will have anti-Hbs & anti-Hbe antibodies not HbsAg & HbeAg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HBsAg and HBeAg positivity together indicate active hepatitis B viral replication and a high degree of infectivity.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct match?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d

 

1-b. Gastrin – Stimulates gastric acid secretion: Secreted by G-cells of the stomach antrum; stimulates HCl (gastric acid) secretion.

 

2-c. Cholecystokinin (CCK) – Stimulates gallbladder contraction: Secreted by I-cells of duodenum; stimulates gallbladder contraction and pancreatic enzyme secretion.

 

3-a. Secretin – Stimulates pancreatic bicarbonate secretion: Secreted by S-cells of duodenum; stimulates secretion of bicarbonate from pancreas to neutralize acid.

 

4-d. Motilin – Increases gastrointestinal motility (MMC regulation): Secreted by M-cells of the small intestine; initiates migrating motor complexes (MMC) during fasting state to clear residual food.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Gastrin stimulates → gastric acid secretion. 
  • CCK → gallbladder contraction
  • Secretin → Stimulates pancreatic bicarbonate secretion
  • Motilin → Increases gastrointestinal motility (MMC regulation).

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with chronic lower back pain. CT of lower back shows the following findings. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spondylolisthesis

 

  • This is a condition where one vertebra slips forward over the vertebra below it.
  •  It most commonly occurs in the lumbar spine, particularly at L5-S1 or L4-L5.
    • Degenerative Spondylolisthesis: Most common in older adults (like a 56-year-old woman). It occurs due to chronic degeneration and laxity of the facet joints and intervertebral disc, without a pars interarticularis defect.
    • Isthmic Spondylolisthesis: Caused by a defect (spondylolysis) in the pars interarticularis (a part of the vertebral arch), more common in younger, active individuals.
  • Chronic lower back pain, often exacerbated by activity or standing, and relieved by rest or flexion. Can cause radicular symptoms (leg pain, numbness, weakness) if nerve roots are compressed. Limping gait due to pain and instability.
  • CT Clearly demonstrates the forward slippage of one vertebral body over another. It can also show the associated degenerative changes (facet joint arthritis, disc degeneration) or a pars interarticularis defect if it's isthmic. The degree of slippage can be measured.
  • The patient's age (56 years) and chronic lower back pain are highly consistent with degenerative spondylolisthesis. This condition directly leads to mechanical instability and pain, often causing a limping gait. A CT scan is excellent for visualizing vertebral alignment and identifying slippage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal Osteodystrophy:

 

  • This is a complex metabolic bone disease that occurs as a complication of chronic kidney disease (CKD). 
  • It encompasses a spectrum of bone abnormalities, including osteitis fibrosa cystica (due to hyperparathyroidism), osteomalacia, and adynamic bone disease.
  • Patients would have a known history of severe CKD. Bone pain can be widespread, not just localized to the lower back. 
  • They might have symptoms related to CKD (e.g., fatigue, nausea, swelling) or hyperparathyroidism (e.g., bone pain, fractures, muscle weakness).
  • Imaging findings can include osteopenia, bone resorption (especially subperiosteal resorption in phalanges and distal clavicle), brown tumors, or diffuse sclerosis ("rugger-jersey spine" due to alternating dense and lucent bands in vertebrae, particularly in the lumbar spine).
  • The case only mentions chronic lower back pain. There's no mention of kidney disease, widespread bone pain, or other systemic symptoms. 
  • While "rugger-jersey spine" can affect the lumbar region, it's a diffuse bone disease, not a focal structural issue typically causing isolated chronic lower back pain in the absence of CKD.

 

Option B. Spinal TB:

 

  • Spinal TB (Tuberculosis of the Spine / Pott's Disease) is an extrapulmonary manifestation of tuberculosis affecting the vertebral column. It is an infectious disease that leads to destruction of vertebrae and intervertebral discs.
  • Chronic back pain, often worse at night. Can cause neurological deficits (weakness, numbness) due to spinal cord compression. 
  • Constitutional symptoms like fever, night sweats, weight loss, and fatigue are often present, though can be subtle. It can occur at any age, but is more common in developing countries or immunocompromised individuals.
  • Characteristically shows destruction of the vertebral bodies (often involving two adjacent vertebrae and the intervening disc), prevertebral and paravertebral abscesses (fluid collections), and collapse of vertebrae leading to kyphotic deformity (gibbus deformity). There might be less sclerotic response compared to pyogenic infections.
  • While it causes chronic back pain, the absence of constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss) and the typical pattern of infection (vertebral body destruction, disc involvement, abscesses) would be specific on CT. Spondylolisthesis is a mechanical issue, not an infection.

 

Option D. Spinal Metastasis:

 

  • Cancer that has spread from a primary site (e.g., breast, lung, prostate, kidney, thyroid) to the vertebrae.
  • Back pain is a very common symptom, often constant, severe, and worse at night or with activity. Can lead to neurological deficits if the spinal cord or nerve roots are compressed.
  • Constitutional symptoms (unexplained weight loss, fatigue, fever) are common, and there's often a history of a primary cancer.
  • Can show lytic (bone-destroying) or blastic (bone-forming) lesions within the vertebral body, often without disc space involvement. Pathological fractures can occur. 
  • Epidural soft tissue mass may be present, compressing the spinal cord.
  • While possible in this age group, the primary presentation is often more severe pain, and there's usually a known history of cancer or other systemic signs. 
  • The CT findings would be of destructive bone lesions rather than a vertebral slippage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spondylolisthesis, particularly degenerative spondylolisthesis, is the most fitting diagnosis.
  •  The CT scan shows the forward slippage of a vertebra, which directly explains the symptoms.

questions.text: A hospitalized 66-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus and recent left knee arthroplasty presents with fever, joint swelling, and purulent discharge from the surgical site. Blood cultures and joint aspirate are positive for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The patient has renal impairment and a history of rash with vancomycin. Which of the following antibiotics offers effective coverage against MRSA and would be appropriate in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ceftobiprole

 

  • Ceftobiprole is a fifth-generation cephalosporin notable for its broad-spectrum activity, including:
  • MRSA coverage: Unlike earlier cephalosporins, ceftobiprole binds to PBP2a, the penicillin-binding protein responsible for methicillin resistance in S. aureus.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa: It also retains activity against this notoriously resistant gram-negative pathogen.
  • Due to these dual properties, ceftobiprole is particularly useful in hospital-acquired infections like complicated skin and soft tissue infections or hospital-acquired pneumonia where both MRSA and Pseudomonas may be concerns. It is also a valuable alternative when glycopeptides like vancomycin are contraindicated due to allergy or toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone: A third-generation cephalosporin with excellent gram-negative coverage but lacks activity against MRSA. Not suitable for this case.

 

Option C. Cefuroxime: A second-generation cephalosporin primarily effective against respiratory pathogens. It is ineffective against MRSA.

 

Option D. Cefazolin: A first-generation cephalosporin used for MSSA and streptococcal infections. It does not cover MRSA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ceftobiprole is a fifth-generation cephalosporin with broad-spectrum activity, including effective coverage against both methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, making it valuable in treating complex hospital-acquired infections.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman, para 2, who had undergone two previous cesarean sections, is now recovering from a laparoscopic hysterectomy performed for symptomatic uterine fibroids. On postoperative day 10, she reports continuous leakage of clear urine per vaginum. A 3-swab test is performed using methylene blue dye. The topmost swab is wet but not stained with dye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ureterovaginal fistula

 

  • The clinical picture of continuous urine leakage starting several days after surgery (post-op day 10) along with the 3-swab test showing a wet but unstained upper swab is diagnostic of a ureterovaginal fistula. 
  • In this condition, urine bypasses the bladder and leaks directly from the ureter into the vagina, hence not picking up methylene blue dye that was instilled in the bladder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vesicovaginal fistula: Incorrect. In this condition, the middle swab is stained with methylene blue dye, as the leakage occurs from the bladder into the vaginal vault.

 

Option C. Urethrovaginal fistula: Incorrect. This is suggested when the lowermost swab is stained with methylene blue. These are typically associated with injury at or near the urethra.

 

Option D. Vesicouterine fistula: Incorrect. This typically presents with cyclical hematuria (menouria) and may not cause continuous leakage of urine per vaginum. It is not diagnosed via the 3-swab test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The 3-swab test is a bedside diagnostic tool to differentiate types of genitourinary fistulas. 
  • A wet upper swab not stained with dye suggests a ureterovaginal fistula, which often presents several days after pelvic surgery such as hysterectomy.

choices.text: Soft palate, uvula, and pillars visible
Only the base of the uvula visible
Soft palate and base of the uvula visible
Hard and soft palate visible only

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents to a hospital in Jaipur for elective gallbladder surgery. During the preoperative assessment, the anesthesiologist conducts an airway examination to predict the ease of intubation. The anesthesiologist uses the Mallampati classification, which is based on the visibility of structures in the oral cavity. Which of the following best describes a Class III Mallampati score?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hard and soft palate visible only

 

  • The Mallampati classification is a system used to predict the difficulty of endotracheal intubation. 
  • It involves assessing the visibility of structures in the oral cavity when the patient opens their mouth and protrudes their tongue.
  •  A Class III Mallampati score, which indicates a potentially difficult intubation, is characterized by the visibility of only the hard and soft palates, with the base of the uvula and the tonsillar pillars not visible.

 

Other Options:

 

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The Mallampati classification helps in preoperative airway assessment to anticipate intubation difficulty.
  •  A Class III score is a significant indicator of a potentially challenging intubation scenario, warranting preparation for advanced airway management techniques.

choices.text: API (Annual Parasite Incidence) threshold-based interventions

questions.text: In urban settings with increasing malaria incidence, local health authorities are implementing control measures tailored to urban transmission patterns. Which of the following strategies forms the cornerstone of the Urban Malaria Scheme?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-larval operations

 

  • The Urban Malaria Scheme (UMS) is designed to target malaria transmission in urban areas, where larval breeding sites—such as stagnant water collections, construction sites, and urban drains—are widespread. 
  • In urban malaria scheme control should be carried out at three major schemes – Source reduction, Larvicidal (chemical - temephos and biological – gambusia fish) and engineering methods
  • Hence, anti-larval measures, such as the use of larvicides and environmental sanitation, form the core component of UMS. 
  • This is a proactive vector control measure specifically tailored to the urban landscape, where vector breeding is typically restricted and easier to target compared to rural areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drug-based treatment: While important in managing clinical malaria cases, drug-based interventions are not the primary strategy in UMS. They are used in conjunction with vector control but are not preventive in nature.

 

Option B. API (Annual Parasite Incidence) threshold-based interventions: API thresholds are more commonly used in rural or broader malaria control programs, not specific to the Urban Malaria Scheme. UMS interventions are not contingent on API but rather on vector control feasibility in urban environments.

 

Option D. Adult vector eradication measures: Anti-adult measures like fogging are part of overall vector control, but in the UMS, the emphasis is on anti-larval measures, as larval habitats are more localized and manageable in cities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Urban Malaria Scheme primarily relies on anti-larval operations as its central strategy for controlling malaria in urban environments.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with acute-onset chest pain radiating to the left arm. ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in certain leads. Coronary angiography shows an occlusion in a dominant artery supplying the posterior third of the interventricular septum and the AV node. Which of the following is the most likely dominant coronary artery in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right coronary artery (RCA)

 

  • In right-dominant circulation (seen in ~85% of individuals), the posterior descending artery (PDA) arises from the RCA, which also gives rise to the AV nodal artery in most cases.
  •  Occlusion of the RCA in such individuals can lead to infarction of the inferior wall of the heart (ST elevation in II, III, aVF), the posterior third of the interventricular septum, and the AV node, leading to bradyarrhythmias or heart block.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left anterior descending artery (LAD): This artery supplies the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum, the anterior wall of the left ventricle, and the apex. It is not responsible for AV node or posterior septum perfusion.

 

Option C. Left circumflex artery (LCX): In left-dominant circulation (~8% of people), the LCX gives rise to the PDA. However, this is not the most common scenario. In this patient, the inferior wall changes and AV node involvement suggest RCA dominance.

 

Option D. Posterior descending artery (PDA): While this artery does supply the posterior septum and AV node, it is a branch, not a main artery. The dominance is defined by which artery gives rise to the PDA—not PDA itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coronary dominance is determined by the artery that gives rise to the PDA. In right-dominant hearts (most common), the RCA supplies the PDA and the AV node, explaining inferior MI findings and conduction blocks in RCA occlusion.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of frequent episodes of involuntary urine leakage associated with a strong urge to void. She reports urgency, frequency, and nocturia, but denies any dysuria, hematuria, or signs of infection. She has no history of neurologic disease. After ruling out urinary tract infection and other causes, she is diagnosed with overactive bladder. Which of the following medications would be most appropriate to reduce her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxybutynin

 

  • Oxybutynin is an antimuscarinic agent that works by inhibiting M3 muscarinic receptors in the bladder detrusor muscle.
  •  This leads to relaxation of the detrusor, increasing bladder capacity and reducing involuntary contractions. It is the drug of choice for overactive bladder (urge incontinence) when behavioral therapies (e.g., bladder training) are not effective.
  • Oxybutynin helps to reduce:
    • Urinary urgency
    • Frequency
    • Nocturia
    • Incontinence episodes
  • It is especially helpful in patients without infection or structural abnormalities but with symptoms of detrusor overactivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tamsulosin: An α₁-blocker used primarily in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) to improve urinary flow in men with obstructive symptoms. It is not used for urge incontinence.

 

Option C. Finasteride: A 5α-reductase inhibitor used in BPH to shrink the prostate over time. It has no role in treating overactive bladder, particularly in women.

 

Option D. Desmopressin: A vasopressin analog used in central diabetes insipidus and nocturnal enuresis, not indicated for detrusor overactivity or daytime urge incontinence in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oxybutynin is a muscarinic receptor antagonist used to treat overactive bladder (urge incontinence) by reducing detrusor muscle overactivity and improving bladder control.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male alcoholic presents with hematemesis and melena. BP is 90/60 mmHg, HR 110/min. NG tube reveals bright red blood. After resuscitation, upper GI endoscopy is done and the findings are shown below. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endoscopic variceal ligation

 

  • Variceal bleed confirmed on endoscopy.
  • Endoscopic band ligation is the first-line treatment.
  • Resuscitate with fluids, blood; start octreotide + antibiotics.
  • Non-selective beta-blockers started after bleeding is controlled.
  • PPIs have no role in variceal bleeding.
  • Surgical shunt reserved for refractory cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral propranolol: Prophylaxis, not acute management.

 

Option B. IV pantoprazole and monitor: PPIs are not effective in variceal bleeds.

 

Option D. Surgical shunt procedure: Reserved for failed endotherapy or recurrent bleeds.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute esophageal variceal bleeding requires immediate endoscopic ligation along with vasoactive agents and antibiotics.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not pierced during the administration of epidural anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dura

 

  • During epidural anesthesia, the needle passes through the supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, and ligamentum flavum but does not penetrate the dura.
  •  The dura is only pierced during spinal anesthesia, where the needle goes further into the subarachnoid space to administer the anesthetic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supraspinous ligament: The supraspinous ligament is pierced as the needle progresses through the layers to reach the epidural space.

 

Option B. Interspinous ligament: The interspinous ligament is also pierced during this procedure as part of the approach through the midline of the back.

 

Option C. Ligamentum flavum: The ligamentum flavum, being the final ligament layer before reaching the epidural space, is pierced to allow the anesthetic to be administered around the dural sac but not into it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The needle does not pierce the dura mater in epidural anesthesia, distinguishing it from spinal anesthesia where the dura and arachnoid are intentionally penetrated to deliver anesthetic into the cerebrospinal fluid.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a significant smoking history comes to the emergency department complaining of blood in his urine and left-sided flank pain. A contrast-enhanced CT scan identifies a solid mass arising from the left kidney. A percutaneous core biopsy is obtained, and histopathology is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma

 

This 60-year-old man with hematuria, flank pain, and a renal mass on imaging, along with the provided histopathology showing tumor cells with pale cytoplasm, prominent cell borders, and perinuclear halos, is highly suggestive of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma (RCC).

 

Chromophobe RCC accounts for approximately 5% of all renal cell carcinomas and arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting duct. The characteristic histological features include pale, flocculent cytoplasm with prominent cell membranes creating a "plant cell-like" appearance, and distinctive perinuclear halos giving cells a koilocytoid appearance. The cells typically show variable sizes and are arranged in a solid architectural pattern.

 

Chromophobe RCC generally has a better prognosis than clear cell RCC and may be associated with Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome when presenting as multiple or bilateral tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bellini duct carcinoma: Also known as collecting duct carcinoma, this is a rare and aggressive RCC subtype that shows high-grade cytology with glandular or tubular architecture and desmoplastic stroma. The cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm with prominent nucleoli, not the pale cytoplasm with perinuclear halos seen here. Therefore, Bellini duct carcinoma is incorrect.

 

Option C. Clear cell renal cell carcinoma: This most common RCC subtype (70-80% of cases) would show truly clear cytoplasm due to abundant glycogen and lipid content, arranged in nests with a characteristic delicate branching vascular network ("chicken-wire" pattern). The absence of this vascular pattern and presence of prominent cell borders make clear cell RCC incorrect for this case.

 

Option D. Papillary renal cell carcinoma: The second most common RCC subtype would show papillary architecture with fibrovascular cores, often containing foamy macrophages and possibly psammoma bodies. The cells typically have basophilic cytoplasm rather than the pale cytoplasm with prominent cell borders seen here. Therefore, papillary RCC is not the correct diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize chromophobe renal cell carcinoma by its characteristic histological features including prominent cell borders, pale flocculent cytoplasm with perinuclear halos, and distinguish it from other RCC subtypes based on architectural patterns and cytoplasmic characteristics.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with mixed dyslipidemia is prescribed a medication that specifically blocks the intestinal absorption of dietary and biliary cholesterol by inhibiting the NPC1L1 transporter. Which of the following medications works by this mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ezetimibe

 

  • Ezetimibe acts by selectively inhibiting the NPC1L1 (Niemann-Pick C1-like 1) cholesterol transporter located in the intestinal brush border. 
  • This reduces the absorption of dietary and biliary cholesterol, leading to a decrease in hepatic cholesterol stores and an increase in clearance of cholesterol from the blood.
  •  It is often used as monotherapy or in combination with statins for the treatment of hypercholesterolemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atorvastatin: A HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor, it reduces endogenous cholesterol synthesis in the liver but does not affect NPC1L1 or intestinal cholesterol absorption directly.

 

Option B. Fenofibrate: A PPAR-α agonist, it primarily lowers triglycerides and increases HDL cholesterol. It acts via increased lipoprotein lipase activity and does not inhibit NPC1L1.

 

Option C. Pioglitazone: A thiazolidinedione used in type 2 diabetes, it enhances insulin sensitivity by acting on PPAR-γ receptors. It has no role in lipid absorption or NPC1L1 inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ezetimibe inhibits the NPC1L1 transporter in the intestinal brush border, thereby reducing cholesterol absorption and lowering plasma LDL cholesterol levels.

questions.text: A middle-aged individual presents with vertical diplopia and adopts a compensatory left head tilt. Ocular motility testing reveals right-sided hypotropia that worsens during right gaze (dextroversion) and also increases on right head tilt. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right Superior Rectus palsy

 

  • The superior rectus muscle is responsible for elevation, adduction, and intorsion of the eye. 
  • In a case of right superior rectus palsy, the affected eye shows hypotropia (eye deviated downward), especially evident when the eye moves into positions requiring elevation—such as right gaze (dextroversion) and right head tilt.
  • The patient’s compensatory left head tilt is a classic postural adjustment to minimize diplopia. Since the hypotropia worsens on dextroversion and right tilt, it points to right superior rectus involvement, as that muscle is most engaged in those gaze positions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left Medial Rectus palsy: Would affect adduction of the left eye but does not cause hypotropia or worsen in right gaze or tilt. Not compatible with the pattern described.

 

Option B. Right Inferior Oblique palsy: This would cause hypotropia that worsens in left gaze and left head tilt, not right. Thus, it doesn’t match the described presentation.

 

Option C. Right Lateral Rectus overaction: Overaction of lateral rectus would affect horizontal alignment, not vertical diplopia. Also, no hypotropia or worsening on head tilt would be expected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In vertical strabismus, a palsy of the superior rectus muscle presents as hypotropia of the affected eye, especially worsening in ipsilateral gaze and head tilt. 
  • This helps distinguish it from inferior oblique and superior oblique palsies.

choices.text: It is present in high concentration in maternal blood and fetal amnion
It is absent in cervico-vaginal secretions in women at term
If found in cervico-vaginal secretions before membrane rupture, it is a marker for preterm labor
It functions in intercellular adhesion during implantation

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida at 30 weeks presents with uterine contractions. She has no leakage of fluid or vaginal bleeding. A fetal fibronectin (fFN) test is performed using a cervico-vaginal swab. Which of the following statements about fetal fibronectin is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is absent in cervico-vaginal secretions in women at term

 

  • Fetal fibronectin is normally found in cervico-vaginal secretions in early pregnancy (before 22 weeks) and again after 34–36 weeks.
  •  Its presence between 22 and 34 weeks, especially in symptomatic women without membrane rupture, is abnormal and suggests increased risk of preterm labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is present in high concentration in maternal blood and fetal amnion: Correct. fFN is produced by fetal tissues and is found in maternal serum and amniotic fluid.

 

Option C. If found in cervico-vaginal secretions before membrane rupture, it is a marker for preterm labor: Correct. Detection of fFN between 22–34 weeks is considered a predictor of preterm birth risk.

 

Option D. It functions in intercellular adhesion during implantation: Correct. fFN plays a role in maintaining the integrity of the maternal-fetal interface through cell adhesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fetal fibronectin is a glycoprotein that helps maintain placental adherence and is normally found in cervico-vaginal secretions early and late in pregnancy.
  • Its presence between 22–34 weeks without membrane rupture suggests increased risk of preterm labor.

questions.text: A 2-week-old neonate presents with severe respiratory distress, feeding difficulties, and central cyanosis since birth. On examination, there is a single loud second heart sound and bounding peripheral pulses. The chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Persistent Truncus Arteriosus

 

  • Persistent truncus arteriosus is a congenital cyanotic heart disease where a single arterial trunk arises from the heart, supplying systemic, pulmonary, and coronary circulations.
  • It is associated with a large ventricular septal defect (VSD), leading to significant pulmonary over-circulation, which explains the cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vascularity on X-ray.
  • The sign seen on the chest x-ray is described as sitting duck sign, as seen in the image given.
  • Clinically, these infants develop early-onset heart failure due to excessive pulmonary blood flow.
  • The single loud S2 on auscultation is due to a single truncal valve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transposition of the great arteries: Shows egg-on-string cardiac silhouette with narrow mediastinum, which is not seen here.

 

Option B. Tetralogy of Fallot: Typically has decreased pulmonary vascularity and a boot-shaped heart.

 

Option C. Tricuspid atresia: Would show decreased pulmonary vascular markings if no large VSD/ASD is present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Persistent truncus arteriosus should be suspected in neonates with early heart failure, single S2, bounding pulses, and cardiomegaly with increased pulmonary vascular markings on X-ray.

choices.text: Years lost due to premature death
Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.text: Which of the following best describes what the YPLL indicator specifically measures?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Years lost due to premature death

 

  • Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL) is a public health metric that quantifies the burden of premature mortality.
  •  It calculates the number of years a person would have lived had they not died prematurely, often using a standard age cutoff (e.g., 65 or 75 years). 
  • YPLL is used to emphasize diseases and conditions that cause early deaths, such as injuries, cancers, and heart disease, and helps guide resource allocation and prevention strategies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Years lost to morbidity: This would refer to time lived with illness, not premature death. While important in public health, it is not what YPLL measures. This is more relevant to disability-adjusted life years (DALYs).

 

Option C. Years lost to disability: Similar to option A, this refers to time lived with disability, not early death. It is also a component of DALYs, not YPLL.

 

Option D. Years lost to poor quality of life: This is a subjective measure often used in quality-adjusted life years (QALYs), which adjust for both quantity and quality of life, unlike YPLL which focuses solely on death occurring earlier than expected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL) is a measure of premature mortality and highlights the impact of early deaths on public health by quantifying the years lost before a predetermined age threshold.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is admitted with fever, rash (shown in the image) and polyarthralgia. He has mild hepatomegaly and cervical lymphadenopathy. Labs: WBC 24,000/mm³ with 85% neutrophils, ESR 90 mm/h, ferritin 9500 ng/mL. ANA and RF are negative. Work up for tropical infections are negative as well. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adult-onset Still’s disease

 

  • Triad of Adult-onset Still’s disease (AOSD): daily spiking fevers, arthralgia, and evanescent salmon-colored rash.
  • Very high ferritin levels (>1000), leukocytosis with neutrophilia.
  • ANA/RF negative.
  • Associated with hepatitis, lymphadenopathy.
  • Exclusion of infections/malignancy is key. This disease is the diagnosis of exclusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Systemic lupus erythematosus: Positive ANA, more typical in young females.

 

Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis: RF usually positive, symmetric joint disease dominant.

 

Option D. Leptospirosis: Work up for tropical infections is negative and it include leptospirosis as well. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

AOSD should be considered in patients with spiking fever, arthralgia, hepatosplenomegaly, and hyperferritinemia with negative ANA/RF.

questions.text: A 42-year-old hospitalized man with a history of recurrent catheter-associated urinary tract infections is found to have significant growth of Proteus mirabilis on urine culture. During his previous admission three months ago, Proteus was also isolated. Which of the following laboratory tests would most appropriately determine the relatedness between the two Proteus strains?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diene’s phenomenon

 

  • Diene’s phenomenon is a swarming inhibition test that helps differentiate related strains of Proteus by observing their interaction on agar. 
  • Identical Proteus strains will swarm together without an inhibition line, whereas unrelated strains will form a demarcation line between them due to bacteriocin activity.
  • This is useful in infection-control investigations to distinguish relapse from reinfection in patients with recurrent Proteus infections.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elek’s immunodiffusion test: Used to detect diphtheria toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae — unrelated to Proteus.

 

 

Option B. Quellung capsular reaction: Detects capsular swelling for organisms like Streptococcus pneumoniae to determine serotypes, not for Proteus.

 

 

Option D. Nagler reaction: Used to identify Clostridium perfringens by demonstrating lecithinase activity on egg yolk agar.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diene’s phenomenon is a classic method to evaluate the relatedness of Proteus strains, important in tracing persistent or recurrent infections.

choices.text: Urgent Needle Decompression in the 5th ICS in the MAL.
Urgent Needle Decompression in the 2nd ICS in the MCL.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with acute onset chest pain and dyspnea. He is tall and thin. On auscultation, breath sounds are absent on the right side with hyper-resonant note on percussion. CXR is shown below. Vitals: BP 120/80 mmHg, HR 90/min, SpO₂ 98% and no jugular venous distension. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insert 8-14Fr Chest drain.

 

  • This is a classic case of primary spontaneous right pneumothorax in a tall, thin young man. 
  • The patient is hemodynamically stable -
    • Normal blood pressure
    • Normal heart rate
    • Good oxygen saturation
    • No JVD
  • These findings rule out tension pneumothorax, which would require immediate needle decompression.
  • According to clinical guidelines (such as from the British Thoracic Society):
  • In symptomatic, stable patients with a moderate-to-large pneumothorax, the preferred next step is to insert a small-bore (8–14 Fr) chest drain.
  • This allows effective re-expansion of the lung while minimizing procedural complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urgent needle decompression in the 5th ICS MAL: This is indicated for tension pneumothorax, which is not present here (no hemodynamic compromise).

 

Option B. Urgent needle decompression in the 2nd ICS MCL: Also used in tension pneumothorax scenarios. Inappropriate in a stable patient.

 

Option D. Discharge and review in OPD: Not appropriate. This patient is symptomatic and has a radiologically significant pneumothorax. Observation or outpatient management is only considered for small, asymptomatic cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a stable but symptomatic patient with a moderate-to-large spontaneous pneumothorax, the appropriate next step is to insert a small-bore chest drain. Needle decompression is reserved for cases of tension pneumothorax with clinical instability.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of intense throbbing pain on the left side of her head. The headache began a few hours ago and is associated with nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light (photophobia), and sound (phonophobia). She has a history of similar episodes in the past, but this time she seeks immediate relief due to severity. Which of the following recently approved medications is most appropriate for acute management in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rimegepant

 

  • 3 New Drugs approved for migraine – Gepants, Ditans and Mab. Gepants and Ditans are for acute attack and can be given orally, while Mab are used as prophylactic medicine and can be given through injection only. 
  • Rimegepant is a CGRP receptor antagonist (calcitonin gene-related peptide receptor antagonist) recently introduced for the acute treatment of migraine with or without aura in adults. 
  • It works by blocking CGRP receptors, which are involved in migraine pathophysiology. 
  • CGRP is a neuropeptide that causes vasodilation and inflammation in the trigeminovascular system, contributing to migraine pain. 
  • Rimegepant offers immediate relief of migraine symptoms such as throbbing headache, photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea/vomiting—as seen in this patient. It is taken orally and acts rapidly, making it ideal for acute attacks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fremanezumab: This is a monoclonal antibody targeting CGRP, but it is used for preventive treatment of migraine, not for acute relief. It does not provide immediate symptom resolution in a current attack.

 

Option B. Flunarizine: This calcium channel blocker is used prophylactically in migraine management. It is not indicated for acute treatment of migraine symptoms and does not offer rapid relief.

 

Option D. Propranolol: A non-selective beta-blocker that is also used for migraine prophylaxis. It is ineffective in managing acute migraine episodes and has a delayed onset of action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rimegepant is a newly introduced CGRP receptor antagonist used for the acute treatment of migraine attacks and offers immediate relief of symptoms such as throbbing headache, nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia.
  •  It is distinct from drugs like propranolol, flunarizine, and fremanezumab, which are used for prophylaxis rather than acute management.

choices.text: Clean hand of the attendant
New blade for cutting the cord

questions.text: A newborn care checklist is being evaluated to reduce the incidence of neonatal tetanus in underserved rural regions. Which of the following is not part of the WHO-endorsed "Five Clean Practices" aimed at preventing neonatal tetanus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clean airway

 

  • The "Five Clean Practices" are a set of essential hygiene principles used to prevent neonatal tetanus, especially in low-resource settings. These include:
    • Clean hands of the birth attendant
    • Clean surface where delivery occurs
    • Clean Cord stump
    • Clean blade for cutting the umbilical cord
    • Clean cord tie for securing the cord
  • The "clean airway" is not one of the recognized five clean practices specific to neonatal tetanus prevention. Although airway management is crucial in neonatal care, it is not part of this specific tetanus prevention framework.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The WHO's “Five Clean Practices” to eliminate neonatal tetanus do not include “clean airway.” The focus is on hygiene measures that prevent infection at and around the time of birth.
  • Cleans for safe delivery for prevention of NNT:

 

 

* 7 Cleans are proposed under RCH-III

questions.text: A compound is administered to a patient that inhibits the electron transport chain by blocking the transfer of electrons from NADH to CoQ (ubiquinone). Which of the following inhibitors is most likely to be responsible for this action?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amobarbital

 

  • Amobarbital (along with other inhibitors like rotenone and piericidin A) inhibits Complex I of the electron transport chain by preventing the transfer of electrons from NADH to CoQ. 
  • This blockage leads to impaired electron flow and decreased ATP production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.Malonate: Malonate inhibits Complex II, specifically blocking the succinate dehydrogenase activity, and thus impairs the conversion of succinate to fumarate.
 

Option C. TTFA: TTFA (Trienoyl Tri Fluoro Acetone) inhibits Complex II, not Complex I.


Option D. Antimycin A: Antimycin A inhibits Complex III by blocking the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol (QH2) to cytochrome c.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct match?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A–2, B–1, C–3, D–4

 

  • A–2. The Pre-Bötzinger complex – Generates pacemaker rhythmic signals for inspiration: Located in the ventrolateral medulla, is considered the primary respiratory rhythm generator. It contains a network of pacemaker neurons that produce rhythmic discharges, initiating the basic cycle of inspiration. This complex sets the fundamental automatic respiratory rhythm.
  • B–1. Pneumotaxic centre – Fine-tunes breathing rhythm by inhibiting inspiration: This centre is located in the pons and primarily modulates the rate and pattern of breathing by limiting inspiration, preventing over-inflation of the lungs. It fine-tunes the rhythm but does not initiate it.
  • C–3. Dorsal group of neurons in the medulla – Integrates sensory input, controls basic inspiration: The dorsal respiratory group (DRG) in the medulla integrates sensory input and controls the basic rhythm of inspiration, but it receives its timing cues from the Pre-Bötzinger complex.
  • D–4. Apneustic centre – Promotes prolonged inspiration: Located in the lower pons, this centre promotes prolonged inspiration. It is overridden by the pneumotaxic centre and does not act as a rhythm generator.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pre-Bötzinger complex in the medulla is the primary pacemaker for respiratory rhythm, while other centers like the pneumotaxic, apneustic, and dorsal medullary groups modulate the pattern and depth of breathing.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with concerns about a recurring, irregular white lesion on her tongue. She denies pain, bleeding, or difficulty swallowing but reports mild discomfort while eating spicy foods. On examination, her tongue is as shown below. There is no evidence of ulceration or systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Geographic tongue

 

This 35-year-old woman presents with a recurring, irregular white lesion on her tongue. She denies pain, bleeding, or difficulty swallowing, but experiences mild discomfort when eating spicy foods. The image reveals areas of erythema surrounded by a white, serpiginous border, primarily on the dorsum of the tongue.

 

These findings are classic for Geographic tongue, also known as benign migratory glossitis. It is characterized by areas of depapillation (loss of filiform papillae) that migrate over time, giving a map-like appearance. The lesions are not fixed, may recur, and are often asymptomatic but may become tender or irritated by spicy or acidic foods.

 

Importantly, the patient has no systemic symptoms or ulceration, which supports a benign and localized condition like Geographic tongue. This condition is self-limiting and does not require treatment beyond reassurance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral candidiasis:

 

  • Typically presents with white curdy plaques that can be scraped off, revealing an erythematous or bleeding base.
  • Often associated with immunosuppression, recent antibiotic/steroid use, or diabetes.
  • The lesions are not migratory and not asymptomatic.
  • The image and clinical details (no pain, no risk factors, migratory nature) are inconsistent with oral candidiasis.

 

Option C. Lichen planus:

 

  • Often presents with lacy white reticular patterns (Wickham striae) on the buccal mucosa.
  • May be painful or associated with ulcers, and commonly affects other mucosal surfaces.
  • Chronic in course, not migratory, and doesn’t typically cause sensitivity to spicy foods alone.
  • The tongue lesion shown lacks the reticular/lacy pattern seen in lichen planus.

 

Option D. Syphilitic glossitis:

 

  • Usually seen in late/tertiary syphilis.
  • Presents with atrophy of the tongue and thickened, white, or leukoplakic plaques.
  • Often associated with other systemic signs (e.g., rash, lymphadenopathy).
  • Not a recurring or migratory lesion, and discomfort with spicy food is not typical.
  • The patient denies systemic symptoms, making this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A recurring, irregular, map-like lesion on the tongue with mild discomfort to spicy foods and no systemic symptoms is characteristic of Geographic tongue (benign migratory glossitis), a benign and self-limiting condition.

choices.text: This organism frequently causes gas gangrene
The Nagler reaction is typically positive
The most important toxin is hyaluronidase
Strains that cause food poisoning form heat-resistant spores

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding clostridium perfringens is incorrect ?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The most important toxin is hyaluronidase

 

  • Clostridium perfringens is a gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming bacillus that is a common cause of gas gangrene (clostridial myonecrosis).
  • The most important and virulent toxin involved in gas gangrene is alpha-toxin (lecithinase), which causes myonecrosis and hemolysis by breaking down cell membranes.
  • While hyaluronidase is indeed produced by C. perfringens and facilitates tissue invasion, it is not the most important toxin associated with gas gangrene pathogenesis, making this the incorrect statement.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. This organism frequently causes gas gangrene: Correct. C. perfringens is a leading cause of gas gangrene, particularly in traumatic or surgical wounds contaminated with soil or feces. Its rapid tissue invasion and gas production are hallmark features.

 

Option B. The Nagler reaction is typically positive: Correct. The Nagler reaction detects alpha-toxin (lecithinase) activity of C. perfringens on egg-yolk agar, which shows opacification around colonies, confirming its identity.

 

Option D. Strains that cause food poisoning form heat-resistant spores: Correct. Certain strains of C. perfringens involved in food poisoning produce heat-resistant spores, which survive cooking and later germinate in improperly stored food.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alpha-toxin (lecithinase) is the most important virulence factor of Clostridium perfringens in gas gangrene, not hyaluronidase. 
  • Recognizing the key toxins and diagnostic tests (e.g., Nagler reaction) is critical for understanding this pathogen’s clinical implications.

questions.text: Which of the following lysosomal storage disorders is caused by a deficiency of the Golgi enzyme N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphotransferase?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) I-cell disease

 

  • C. I-cell disease (Inclusion-cell disease) is a rare lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the Golgi enzyme N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphotransferase.
  • This enzyme is essential for tagging lysosomal enzymes with mannose-6-phosphate, which directs them to lysosomes. 
  • Without this tagging, the enzymes are secreted extracellularly instead of being delivered to lysosomes, resulting in the accumulation of undigested substrates in lysosomes—hence the characteristic “inclusion cells.” 
  • Clinically, this leads to coarse facial features, gingival hyperplasia, skeletal abnormalities, growth retardation, and early death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tay-Sachs disease: Caused by a deficiency of hexosaminidase A, leading to GM2 ganglioside accumulation—not related to phosphotransferase or the Golgi.

 

Option B. Gaucher disease: Due to a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase (beta-glucosidase), leading to accumulation of glucocerebroside in macrophages.

 

Option D. Niemann-Pick disease: Caused by sphingomyelinase deficiency, leading to sphingomyelin accumulation, particularly in the liver, spleen, and CNS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • I-cell disease results from a deficiency of the Golgi enzyme N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphotransferase, impairing lysosomal enzyme targeting and leading to systemic storage defects.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with easy bruising, prolonged menstrual bleeding, and epistaxis since childhood. Her brother has similar symptoms. On examination, petechiae are present over both legs. Platelet count is mildly low. Peripheral smear is shown below. PT and aPTT are normal. Platelet aggregation is absent with ristocetin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bernard-Soulier syndrome

 

  • Inherited bleeding + large platelets + defective ristocetin aggregation = Bernard-Soulier.
  • Caused by defect in GpIb receptor, which binds von Willebrand factor.
  • Ristocetin test fails even after adding normal plasma → confirms receptor defect, not vWF deficiency.
  • Mild thrombocytopenia and giant platelets on smear are classic.
  • In contrast, vWD shows normal platelet morphology and ristocetin defect corrects with plasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Von Willebrand disease: Platelets normal number and size. Most patients have a slightly elevated aPTT.

 

Option B. Glanzmann thrombasthenia: Normal platelet count/size; defective aggregation with ADP, collagen, but normal ristocetin.

 

Option D. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) → Isolated thrombocytopenia, but normal platelet function and morphology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bernard-Soulier syndrome is inherited platelet disorder with GpIb deficiency, giant platelets, and ristocetin test that does not correct with plasma.

choices.text: Percutaneous nephrostomy and delayed stone removal

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant patient in the second trimester presents with acute flank pain and high-grade fever. Her pulse is 110/minute and BP 96/60 mm of hg. Her WBC count is 21,000. Imaging reveals a large staghorn renal calculus measuring 4.2 cm occupying the renal pelvis and calyces. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Percutaneous nephrostomy and delayed stone removal 

 

  • This patient is pregnant, febrile, hypotensive, and has leukocytosis → all signs of urosepsis due to an obstructing infected staghorn calculus. 
  • The priority is urgent decompression of the renal system to stabilize her and protect both maternal and fetal health.
  • Safest option is drains infected urine, relieves obstruction, stabilizes patient. 
  • Definitive stone removal (e.g., PCNL) is done postpartum or in second trimester if stable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extracorporeal Shockwave Lithotripsy (ESWL): Contraindicated in pregnancy due to risk of fetal injury from shockwaves. Also ineffective for large staghorn stones.

 

Option B. Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL): Standard treatment for staghorn calculi outside pregnancy.   Not safe in pregnancy, especially in unstable patients with infection.

 

Option C. Ureteroscopic Removal: May be used for distal ureteral stones in pregnancy. Not suitable for large staghorn stones occupying the renal pelvis and calyces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Immediate decompression via nephrostomy is life-saving in infected obstructive uropathy during pregnancy.
  • Definitive stone treatment is delayed until maternal and fetal safety is ensured.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is this clinical sign most characteristically associated with?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic plaque psoriasis

 

  • The clinical sign described is the Auspitz sign, which refers to the appearance of pinpoint bleeding after scraping off silvery scales from a psoriatic plaque.
  •  It is a classic diagnostic feature of chronic plaque psoriasis, which is the most common form of psoriasis.
  • In psoriasis, excessive proliferation of keratinocytes and dilated, tortuous capillaries in the dermal papillae are seen. The epidermal layer overlying these vessels is thin. 
  • When the scales are removed by scratching (known as grattage), a thin membrane (called the Bulkeley membrane) is exposed. 
  • Upon removal of this membrane, pinpoint bleeding occurs due to the exposure and rupture of capillaries in the dermal papillae—this is the Auspitz sign.
  • Though not pathognomonic, it is a highly suggestive clinical clue that aids in distinguishing chronic plaque psoriasis from other dermatoses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bullous pemphigoid: This is an autoimmune blistering disease that occurs in older adults and is characterized by tense bullae. It does not involve scaly plaques or display the Auspitz sign.

 

Option B. Pustular psoriasis: Although a variant of psoriasis, this form involves pustules on an erythematous base rather than scaly plaques. The Auspitz sign is generally absent in pustular psoriasis.

 

Option D. Pemphigus: An autoimmune disorder involving flaccid blisters and mucocutaneous erosions due to antibodies against desmogleins. The typical presentation is not of scaly plaques, and the Auspitz sign is absent. In this condition, the Nikolsky sign is positive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Auspitz sign—appearance of pinpoint bleeding upon removal of silvery-white scales—is a hallmark of chronic plaque psoriasis. 
  • This sign results from capillary rupture due to suprapapillary thinning and helps differentiate psoriasis from other dermatological conditions.

questions.text: A patient undergoing chemotherapy reports frequent episodes of watery diarrhea without signs of infection. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacologic intervention to manage this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loperamide

 

  • Loperamide is the drug of choice for treating chemotherapy-induced diarrhea, particularly that caused by agents like irinotecan.
  •  It acts on the μ-opioid receptors in the gastrointestinal tract, slowing intestinal motility and allowing for increased fluid and electrolyte absorption.
  •  It is often used in high doses under medical supervision for chemotherapy-associated cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palonosetron: This is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist primarily used for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, not for diarrhea. It has no antidiarrheal action.

 

Option C. Sucralfate:  A cytoprotective agent used primarily for gastric ulcers. It does not have utility in chemotherapy-induced diarrhea and would not address the underlying mechanism.

 

Option D. Dexamethasone: This glucocorticoid is commonly co-administered to enhance antiemetic efficacy in chemotherapy but does not provide benefit for diarrhea control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Loperamide is the first-line treatment for chemotherapy-induced diarrhea, particularly from irinotecan, due to its action on gastrointestinal μ-opioid receptors that reduce motility and fluid loss.

choices.text: Facilitates viral genome replication inside the host nucleus
Promotes initial attachment to sialic acid receptors
Cleaves sialic acid residues to release new virions from infected cells

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the function of the neuraminidase protein in influenza virus infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cleaves sialic acid residues to release new virions from infected cells

 

  • Neuraminidase (NA) is an influenza virus surface glycoprotein that hydrolyzes sialic acid residues on the host cell surface.
  • This cleaving action prevents the aggregation of newly formed virions at the cell surface and allows their release from infected cells, facilitating the spread of infection. 
  • Additionally, neuraminidase reverses hemagglutination in a process called elution by cleaving sialic acid to free hemagglutinin-bound erythrocytes in laboratory assays.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facilitates viral genome replication inside the host nucleus:
This is done by the viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase, not by neuraminidase.

 

Option B. Promotes initial attachment to sialic acid receptors:
This is mediated by hemagglutinin (HA), not neuraminidase.

 

Option D. Blocks viral uncoating after endocytosis:
Uncoating is inhibited by drugs like amantadine; neuraminidase is unrelated to uncoating.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neuraminidase of influenza virus facilitates the release of progeny virions by cleaving sialic acid residues, and also enables elution of hemagglutinated erythrocytes in laboratory testing.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient complains of persistent pain in the gum line after a dental procedure. Examination reveals inflammation around the periodontal ligament securing the tooth to the alveolar socket. Which type of joint is involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gomphosis

 

  • Gomphosis is the type of fibrous joint that connects a tooth to the alveolar socket via the periodontal ligament.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Syndesmosis: A fibrous joint involving ligaments, found between bones such as the tibia and fibula.

 

Option C. Primary cartilaginous joint: Found in areas like growth plates and not in teeth.

 

Option D. Plane joint: A type of synovial joint permitting gliding movements, unrelated to teeth.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Gomphosis is a fibrous joint securing tooth to the alveolar sockets and is prone to conditions like periodontitis.

choices.text: Hydrops fetalis due to twin-to-twin transfusion

questions.text: A 29-year-old Rh-negative G2P1 woman presents at 28 weeks gestation with a history of Rh alloimmunization in her previous pregnancy. Ultrasound Doppler shows the image below with increased peak systolic velocity in the middle cerebral artery. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fetal anemia

 

  • In fetal anemia, blood viscosity is reduced, and cardiac output increases, leading to an increase in peak systolic velocity in the middle cerebral artery (MCA). 
  • This is the standard non-invasive method to assess for anemia in Rh-isoimmunized pregnancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intrauterine growth restriction:  IUGR is associated with increased resistance in umbilical artery, not elevated MCA velocity.

 

Option C. Hydrops fetalis due to twin-to-twin transfusion: TTTS can cause anemia/polycythemia pattern, but MCA is specific for anemia.

 

Option D. Fetal polycythemia: Polycythemia shows decreased flow velocity due to increased viscosity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MCA Doppler is the gold standard non-invasive test to detect fetal anemia in Rh-isoimmunized pregnancies.

questions.text: A 20-year-old medical student comes to the emergency department after cutting her wrist. On examination, there are multiple superficial cuts. History reveals similar self-harm episodes in the past, usually triggered by minor arguments. The patient also has a history of 4 relationships, all short-lived, in the last 2 years. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Borderline Personality Disorder

 

  • The combination of recurrent self-harm behaviors triggered by minor interpersonal conflicts and a pattern of unstable, short-lived relationships points to Borderline Personality Disorder. 
  • The superficial nature of cuts and their occurrence after minor arguments suggests impulsive self-harm for emotional regulation rather than serious suicidal intent.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Depression: While self-harm can occur in depression, there is no history of sadness of mood, anhedonia, sleep/appetite changes, or other core depressive symptoms in this patient.


Option B. Dysthymia: There is no history of mild depressive symptoms in this patient, the time period of 2 years was chosen to act as a distractor in this question.


Option D. Antisocial Personality Disorder: Characterized by violation of others' rights, criminal behavior, deceitfulness, and lack of remorse. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recurrent self-harm triggered by interpersonal conflicts combined with unstable relationships is characteristic of Borderline Personality Disorder.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant presents with failure to thrive, vomiting, hepatomegaly, and a peculiar cabbage-like body odor. Laboratory evaluation reveals elevated plasma tyrosine levels and signs of liver dysfunction. Genetic testing confirms a metabolic disorder involving impaired breakdown of tyrosine. Urine succinylacetone is markedly increased. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase

 

  • Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase is the final enzyme in the tyrosine degradation pathway, catalyzing the hydrolysis of fumarylacetoacetate to fumarate and acetoacetate. 
  • A deficiency in this enzyme results in Type I Tyrosinemia, a severe autosomal recessive disorder. 
  • This leads to accumulation of fumarylacetoacetate and its derivative, succinylacetone, which are toxic to the liver and kidneys.
