  •  Clinical manifestations include vomiting, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive, and a characteristic "cabbage-like" odor.
  •  Without treatment (e.g., with nitisinone), this condition can progress to liver failure and hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Deficiency of this enzyme causes classic phenylketonuria (PKU), with intellectual disability, musty body odor, and elevated phenylalanine, not tyrosine, and does not cause elevated succinylacetone.

 

Option B. Tyrosine transaminase: Deficiency causes tyrosinemia type II, which presents with eye pain, skin lesions, and intellectual disability, but no succinylacetone accumulation or severe liver failure.

 

Option C. Parahydroxyphenylpyruvate hydroxylase partial deficiency: Deficiency causes tyrosinemia type III, which is very rare and milder, and does not feature succinylacetone elevation or liver dysfunction with cabbage-like odor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase deficiency causes tyrosinemia type I, presenting with liver dysfunction, cabbage-like odor, elevated tyrosine, and diagnostic urine succinylacetone.

questions.text: Match the following causes of AUB with their most appropriate investigation or diagnostic marker:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) a-1, b-3, c-2, d-4

 

  1. Coagulopathy → 1 (PT, aPTT, platelet count): Basic screening for bleeding disorders in adolescent girls with heavy bleeding.
  2. Ovulatory dysfunction → 3 (Mid-luteal phase serum progesterone): Measures if ovulation occurred; if low, anovulatory cycles likely. Done at day 21 to check serum progesterone. If high, ovulation has occurred.
  3. Endometrial dysfunction → 2 (Diagnosis of exclusion after other causes ruled out): No specific test; diagnosed when all structural and systemic causes are excluded.
  4. Iatrogenic → 4 (Detailed drug and contraceptive history): Hormonal therapies or anticoagulants often cause AUB; clinical history is key.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of AUB requires a cause-specific diagnostic approach, guided by the PALM-COEIN classification, ranging from lab tests to history and exclusion.

 

  • Coagulopathy → PT, aPTT, platelet count
  • Ovulatory dysfunction → Mid-luteal phase serum progesterone
  • Endometrial dysfunction → Diagnosis of exclusion, after other causes ruled out
  • Iatrogenic → Drug and contraceptive history

choices.text: Blocks presynaptic acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction
Increases intracellular cyclic AMP levels by ADP-ribosylating Gi proteins
Cleaves SNARE proteins to block inhibitory neurotransmission

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with severe coughing spells followed by episodes of vomiting. Parents mention a history of a “whooping” sound after coughing fits. Cultures confirm infection with Bordetella pertussis. Which of the following best describes the action of the toxin produced by this pathogen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increases intracellular cyclic AMP levels by ADP-ribosylating Gi proteins

 

  • Pertussis toxin (PT) is expressed only by Bordetella pertussis.
  • It is structurally and functionally similar to cholera toxin. Pertussis toxin ADP-ribosylates the inhibitory G protein (Gi), leading to disinhibition of adenylate cyclase and thus an increase in intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP).
  • This elevated cAMP alters immune cell signaling and contributes to the intense lymphocytosis seen in pertussis.
  • C – Cholera toxin, L – Labile toxin of E.coli, A – Anthrax, P – pertussis 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibits EF-2 by ADP-ribosylation: This is the mechanism of diphtheria toxin and Pseudomonas aeruginosa exotoxin A, not pertussis toxin.

 

Option B. Blocks presynaptic acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction: This describes the action of botulinum toxin. It leads to flaccid paralysis. 

 

Option D. Cleaves SNARE proteins to block inhibitory neurotransmission: This is the mechanism of tetanus toxin. It leads to spastic paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pertussis toxin, produced exclusively by Bordetella pertussis, raises intracellular cAMP by ADP-ribosylating Gi proteins, a mechanism similar to cholera toxin.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with known SLE presents with acute confusion, hallucinations, and behavioral changes for 2 days. She is afebrile, oriented only to person, and has no focal deficits. CT brain is normal. CSF shows 4 cells/mm³, mildly raised protein, and normal glucose. MRI shows bilateral frontal subcortical T2 hyperintensities. ANA is positive (1:320). Which of the following is likely to be related to the patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-ribosomal P

 

  • Anti-ribosomal P antibodies are specifically associated with lupus psychosis and depression, particularly in young women.
  • They are considered a marker for neuropsychiatric SLE and may appear even in the absence of other flares.
  • This patient has acute psychiatric symptoms without infection or structural abnormality → points toward lupus psychosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-Ro: Associated with subacute cutaneous lupus, neonatal lupus, and congenital heart block, not CNS disease.

 

Option B. Anti-dsDNA: Indicates lupus vasculitis and lupus nephritis, but not specifically linked to psychosis.

 

Option D. Anti-U1 RNP: Seen in mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD); not specific for neuropsychiatric SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anti-ribosomal P antibodies are a unique marker for lupus psychosis. 
  • Consider them in SLE patients with new-onset psychiatric symptoms and no other identifiable cause.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man reports gradually worsening shortness of breath that has limited his ability to walk even short distances. He has been a chronic smoker for 17 years. His blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Echocardiography demonstrates biventricular dilation with prominently increased left atrial size, consistent with dilated cardiomyopathy. Which of the following genetic alterations is most likely implicated in this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Titin

 

  • This 59-year-old man with dyspnoea, a history of chronic smoking for 17 years, BP 140/90, and increased atrial size on ECHO consistent with dilated cardiomyopathy most likely has a genetic alteration involving the Titin (TTN) gene. 
  • Titin is an essential giant sarcomeric protein that functions to maintain passive elasticity of cardiac muscle. Mutations in the TTN gene are the most frequent genetic cause of familial dilated cardiomyopathy. 
  • The dysfunction of titin disrupts force transmission and results in progressive dilation of the cardiac chambers, including the atria as described in this scenario.
  • Although this patient has a significant smoking history and mild hypertension, these factors alone would not fully explain the degree of biventricular and atrial dilation seen on echocardiography. Therefore, a genetic etiology with titin mutations is the most likely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Desmin: Desmin mutations are more commonly associated with desmin-related myopathy, which involves skeletal muscle weakness and restrictive or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy rather than the classic pattern of biventricular dilation and increased atrial size described here. Therefore, desmin is incorrect.

 

Option B. Lamin A/C: Lamin A/C mutations can cause dilated cardiomyopathy associated with conduction system disease, often leading to early arrhythmias. However, while lamin A/C is a recognized cause, titin mutations remain the most common and best-fitting explanation for dilated cardiomyopathy with biventricular dilation and atrial enlargement in this age group.

 

Option D. Plakoglobin: Plakoglobin mutations are classically implicated in arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC), which leads to fibrofatty replacement of the right ventricular myocardium and ventricular arrhythmias, not the typical biventricular dilation and left atrial enlargement seen with dilated cardiomyopathy. Therefore, plakoglobin is not the most likely genetic alteration in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Titin gene mutations are the most frequent genetic cause of dilated cardiomyopathy, presenting with biventricular and atrial dilation on echocardiography.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with recurrent respiratory infections, poor weight gain, and exertional dyspnea. On examination, there is a wide fixed split of the second heart sound (S2) and a systolic ejection murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border. Chest X-ray shows increased pulmonary vascular markings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atrial septal defect (ASD)

 

  • Wide fixed split of S2 is hallmark → due to constant left-to-right shunt delaying pulmonary valve closure
  • Systolic ejection murmur is due to ↑ flow across pulmonary valve (not the ASD itself)
  • Increased pulmonary vascular markings seen due to volume overload
  • Poor weight gain, recurrent infections due to pulmonary overcirculation

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Ventricular septal defect (VSD):

 

  • Murmur: Pansystolic murmur at lower left sternal border
  • No fixed split of S2
  • Pulmonary overload present, but clinical murmur location & character differ

 

Option C. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA):

 

  • Classic: Continuous “machinery” murmur at left infraclavicular area
  • Bounding pulses, widened pulse pressure
  • No fixed splitting of S2

 

Option D. Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF):

 

  • Cyanotic heart disease
  • Harsh ejection systolic murmur due to RVOT obstruction
  • Single S2 (not split)
  • Decreased pulmonary blood flow on X-ray

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that a wide fixed split of S2 with a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and signs of pulmonary overcirculation in a child strongly suggest Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) — especially the secundum type.

questions.text: A 49-year-old patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is admitted to the ICU and placed on 2 liters of oxygen via mask. He is found to be hypoventilating with a PCO2 of 64 mmHg on blood gas analysis. What is the most appropriate next step in managing his respiratory status?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start BIPAP

 

  • Starting BIPAP (Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure) is the most appropriate next step for this patient who is hypoventilating and has elevated PCO2, indicating respiratory failure. 
  • BIPAP assists by providing two levels of pressure: higher during inhalation and lower during exhalation, thereby enhancing alveolar ventilation and reducing the work of breathing in COPD patients.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase the FICO2: Increasing the FICO2 (Fraction of Inspired Carbon Dioxide) is not therapeutic in this context and could worsen the patient’s hypercapnia.

 

Option B. Decrease the FIO2: Decreasing the FIO2 (Fraction of Inspired Oxygen) addresses oxygen delivery but does not directly help with the removal of carbon dioxide, which is the primary issue here.

 

Option D. Intubate immediately: Intubating immediately might be necessary if the patient’s condition deteriorates further or if non-invasive ventilation like BIPAP fails to improve respiratory status.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In COPD patients experiencing an exacerbation leading to hypoventilation and hypercapnia, non-invasive ventilation such as BIPAP is a preferred initial approach to manage respiratory failure, as it can effectively stabilize breathing and gas exchange without the risks associated with intubation.

choices.text: CBD lies below the R-4-U line
Safe dissection is above and ventral to R-4-U line
Rouviere sulcus marks the position of the right posterior hepatic duct
Cystic duct and artery lie below the R-4-U line

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about surgical landmarks in laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cystic duct and artery lie below the R-4-U line 

 

  • This is incorrect, the cystic duct and artery are typically located above the R4U line. 
  • Misidentifying their position can lead to serious complications during dissection. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CBD lies below the R-4-U line: The R4U line (from segment IV of liver to the umbilical fissure) helps avoid injury to the common bile duct (CBD).   CBD lies below this line, making this statement correct.

 

Option B. Safe dissection is above and ventral to R-4-U line: Dissection above and ventral to the R4U line avoids critical structures like the CBD. This is the recommended zone for safe laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

 

Option C. Rouviere sulcus marks the position of the right posterior hepatic duct:  Rouviere’s sulcus is a horizontal cleft on the liver, often visible during surgery. It serves as a landmark for the right posterior hepatic duct, helping avoid bile duct injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • R4U line guides safe dissection above and ventral to it.
  • Cystic duct and artery lie above, not below, the R4U line — making option D incorrect.

choices.text: Monthly income of the family

questions.text: Based on the program's operational guidelines, which of the following criteria is primarily used to select beneficiaries under the Ayushman Bharat scheme in urban localities?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Occupational status

 

  • Under the Ayushman Bharat – PMJAY, the selection of beneficiaries differs based on rural vs. urban settings.
  •  In urban areas, the Socio-Economic and Caste Census (SECC) 2011 is used, and occupational categories serve as the primary basis for inclusion. 
  • The rationale is that many people working in informal sectors (e.g., ragpickers, street vendors, domestic workers, construction laborers, transport workers, artisans, cobblers, hawkers, cleaners, helpers, etc) lack formal income records, so their occupation serves as a practical proxy for socioeconomic vulnerability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Number of family members: The PMJAY scheme includes entire families as units, but family size does not influence eligibility under the urban selection framework.

 

Option B. Monthly income of the family: Income is difficult to verify in informal sectors. Thus, income levels are not used as a primary criterion in urban areas under Ayushman Bharat.

 

Option C. Proximity to healthcare services: This may affect access to care but is not a determinant for inclusion under PMJAY.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the Ayushman Bharat scheme (PMJAY), beneficiaries in urban areas are primarily selected based on occupational categories listed in the SECC 2011, not income, proximity, or family size.
  • Defined Benefit Cover under this scheme:
    • Rupees 5 lakh per family per year
    • Secondary and Tertiary care hospitalization
    • To subsume the existing RSBY
    • No cap on the family size and age
    • Cashless and paperless scheme
    • Public hospitals and empanelled private hospitals
    • Include 1,354 packages (Including Bypass, stenting, knee replacements)
    • 15-20% cheaper rates than CGHS

questions.text: A 35-year-old man employed in a high-demand engineering role experiences recurrent nasal congestion, sneezing, and itchy eyes each spring, consistent with seasonal allergic rhinitis. Because his work requires sustained focus and cognitive accuracy, he prefers a treatment that will not cause sedation or impair attention. Which of the following medications is most suitable to manage his symptoms without compromising his cognitive performance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fexofenadine

 

  • Fexofenadine is a second-generation antihistamine with potent peripheral H1 receptor antagonism, indicated for the symptomatic treatment of seasonal allergic rhinitis.
  •  It is classified as non-sedating because it does not significantly cross the blood–brain barrier, minimizing central nervous system side effects such as drowsiness and cognitive slowing.
  • This makes it an ideal choice for patients whose occupations demand sustained mental sharpness and concentration, as described in the scenario.
  •  Fexofenadine effectively addresses nasal congestion, sneezing, and itchy eyes in allergic rhinitis without affecting performance in cognitively demanding work environments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meclizine: Meclizine is a first-generation antihistamine with significant central nervous system depressant activity, traditionally used for motion sickness and vertigo. Because it readily crosses the blood–brain barrier, meclizine causes marked drowsiness and cognitive impairment, making it inappropriate for a patient who must remain mentally focused while working.

 

Option C. Promethazine: Promethazine, another first-generation antihistamine, also crosses the blood–brain barrier and has profound sedative and anticholinergic side effects. While it is effective for allergic symptoms, its sedative profile is excessive for someone who needs to stay alert and mentally clear in a high-performance job.

 

Option D. Cinnarizine: Cinnarizine is mainly used for vertigo and motion sickness. Like other first-generation antihistamines, it has central depressant and sedative effects, making it unsuitable for a patient who requires high cognitive functioning during working hours and specifically wishes to avoid drowsiness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fexofenadine is a second-generation antihistamine that selectively blocks peripheral H1 receptors and is minimally sedating because it does not significantly penetrate the blood–brain barrier, making it the drug of choice for allergic rhinitis in individuals who need to maintain cognitive focus and avoid drowsiness.

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypertensive woman presents with headache, vomiting, and transient visual blurring for 2 days. BP is 220/120 mmHg. Fundoscopy shows grade III hypertensive changes. MRI brain is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome 

 

  • Acute BP rise with visual symptoms, seizures/headache, and posterior white matter changes =  Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES)   
  • MRI: T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in parieto-occipital regions.
  • Associated with eclampsia, renal failure, immunosuppressives.
  • Management: BP control, withdrawal of offending drugs.
  • Reversible with early treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertensive encephalopathy: Diffuse brain edema, not localized.

 

Option C. Intracerebral hemorrhage: Would have focal signs and mass effect.

 

Option D. Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis: CVST shows hemorrhagic infarcts in atypical areas, + risk factors like thrombophilia, neurosurgeries, OCPs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

PRES presents with visual and neurological symptoms in hypertensive patients and is characterized by posterior brain edema on MRI.

questions.text: A regional community health initiative organizes a glucose tolerance test campaign for all pregnant women attending prenatal services to identify those at risk of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). What type of screening does this represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Selective screening

 

  • This type of screening targets a specific subgroup of the population that is at higher risk of a particular condition. 
  • In this case, pregnant women represent a high-risk group for gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). 
  • Screening all individuals within this at-risk subgroup using a glucose tolerance test fits the definition of selective screening. 
  • It is not applied to the general population but is specific to a group based on known risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Opportunistic screening: Opportunistic screening refers to tests done while an individual is already visiting for another health issue, not as part of a planned initiative. Since this is a planned screening program for a specific group (pregnant women), this option is incorrect.

 

Option C. Multiphasic screening: This refers to the use of multiple screening tests at once to detect several diseases or conditions. The described scenario involves only a single test (glucose tolerance test) for GDM, so it is not multiphasic.

 

Option D. Mass screening:  Mass screening targets the entire population regardless of risk. The glucose tolerance test in this question is specifically aimed at pregnant women, not the general public, which excludes this option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Selective screening is used for identifying diseases in a specific high-risk group, such as pregnant women for gestational diabetes mellitus using glucose tolerance tests.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of productive cough, dyspnea, intermittent fever, night sweats, and a 9-kg weight loss. On examination, she has diffuse crackles and expiratory wheeze. Labs: Eosinophil count in peripheral blood = 5240/mm³, and BAL fluid shows, 74% eosinophils. Aspergillus serology and ANCA are Negative. CXR is done and it is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia 

 

  • Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia (CEP) is a classic cause of subacute to chronic respiratory symptoms (weeks to months) with marked peripheral and BAL eosinophilia.
  • The “photographic negative of pulmonary edema” pattern on chest X-ray (i.e., peripheral infiltrates) is highly suggestive of CEP.
  • CEP commonly affects middle-aged women, and systemic symptoms like weight loss, fever, and night sweats are typical.
  • BAL eosinophilia >40% is diagnostic, and response to corticosteroids is rapid and dramatic.
  • Negative Aspergillus serology and ANCA help exclude ABPA and EGPA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute eosinophilic pneumonia: Acute presentation (days), often precipitated by environmental exposures (e.g., smoke). Peripheral eosinophilia is often absent early, and imaging shows diffuse alveolar infiltrates, not peripheral ones.

 

Option C. Hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES): Requires ≥6 months of eosinophilia and evidence of multi-organ involvement (e.g., heart, skin, GI). No systemic organ dysfunction here; disease is lung-limited.

 

Option D. Loeffler’s syndrome: Transient pulmonary eosinophilia caused by parasitic larval migration (e.g., Ascaris). Symptoms are usually short-lived (days), not chronic. Imaging shows fleeting, not fixed, infiltrates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia (CEP) should be suspected in middle-aged women with subacute pulmonary symptoms, marked eosinophilia, BAL eosinophils >40%, and peripheral infiltrates on CXR. 
  • The “photographic negative of pulmonary edema” is a classic radiologic clue. 
  • Responds rapidly to steroids.
